title: mol-theme-generate: Custom name pool generation via cognition
description:
Currently polecat name themes are hardcoded in namepool.go. Simple theme selection is fine as static config, but custom name generation should be a molecule.

Examples requiring cognition:
- "Generate 50 polecat names in the style of [book/movie/game]"
- "Create names that match the project's domain (medical, financial, etc.)"
- "Extend the mad-max theme with 20 more obscure characters"

## Molecule: theme-generate
Generate custom polecat names for a rig.

## Step: analyze-request
Understand the naming request:
- Theme style or source material
- Number of names needed
- Any constraints (length, format)

## Step: generate-candidates
Generate candidate names matching the style.
Aim for 2x the requested count.

## Step: validate-names
Filter candidates:
- No duplicates with existing themes
- Appropriate length (3-15 chars)
- No problematic terms

## Step: create-theme
Write the custom theme to rig config or beads.
Register in name pool.
Needs: validate-names

## Notes
- Output is a new theme entry in BuiltinThemes equivalent
- Could be stored as a pinned bead for persistence

title: Design: Collapse mail into beads
description:
## Proposal

Replace the separate mail system (JSONL inboxes) with beads issues using a naming convention.

## Rationale

If all state should be in beads (work items, swarm state, dependencies), why have a separate system for messages? Mail is just:
- Handoffs (agent → self)
- Commands (Mayor → Refinery)
- Escalations (Witness → Mayor)

These can all be beads issues with a special prefix.

## Design

### Convention
- Messages use `@-` prefix: `@-witness-1734012345`
- Assignee = recipient
- Status: open = unread, closed = read/acknowledged
- Priority 0 = urgent

### Commands (thin wrappers)
```bash
gt mail send witness -s "Subject" -m "Body"
  → bd create --prefix=@ --title="Subject" --assignee=witness --description="Body"

gt mail inbox
  → bd list --prefix=@ --assignee=$(gt whoami) --status=open

gt mail read @-abc
  → bd show @-abc && bd close @-abc
```

### Notification
Daemon watches for new `@-` issues and pokes relevant sessions.
Or: agents poll on heartbeat (simpler).

## What We Remove
- `mail/inbox.jsonl` files
- Mail JSONL read/write code
- Separate delivery mechanism

## What We Keep
- `gt mail` CLI (as wrapper)
- Handoff semantics
- Notification (via daemon or polling)

## Benefits
- One system, one sync, one query interface
- All communication in git history
- Simpler architecture

## Risks
- Beads prefix filtering must be efficient
- Namespace collision with user prefixes
- Performance for high-frequency messages (probably fine for handoffs)

## Decision Point
Do we need first-class mail support in beads (`bd mail` commands) or is convention sufficient?

title: Worker cleanup: Beads sync on shutdown
description:
Add beads sync verification to worker cleanup checklist and Witness verification.

## Update to Decommission Checklist (gt-sd6)

Add to pre-done verification:
- bd sync --status must show 'Up to date'
- git status .beads/ must show no changes

## Beads Edge Cases

Uncommitted beads changes:
  bd sync
  git add .beads/
  git commit -m 'beads: final sync'

Beads sync conflict (rare):
  git fetch origin main
  git checkout main -- .beads/
  bd sync --force
  git add .beads/
  git commit -m 'beads: resolve sync conflict'

## Update to Witness Verification (gt-f8v)

When capturing worker state:
  town capture <polecat> "bd sync --status && git status .beads/"

Check for:
- bd sync --status shows 'Up to date'
- git status .beads/ shows no changes

If beads not synced, nudge:
  WITNESS CHECK: Beads not synced. Run 'bd sync' then commit .beads/. Signal done when complete.

title: Unify tmux session lifecycle: prefer exec-over-shell pattern
description:
## Context

When `gt crew at` is run from INSIDE the target session, it uses `execClaude()` which
replaces the shell with Claude directly. This is actually preferable behavior:
- Cleaner exit (no intermediate shell prompt)
- More reliable for programmatic worker recycling
- Better UX for humans

But currently this only happens accidentally when you run `gt crew at` while already
in the session at a shell prompt.

## Current behavior

1. Session created: `tmux new-session` starts with shell
2. Claude started via `send-keys` → shell spawns claude as child
3. Exit claude → return to shell → exit shell → session ends

With exec path (only if already in session):
1. `execClaude()` replaces shell with claude
2. Exit claude → session ends (no intermediate shell)

## Desired behavior

Consider making exec-the-shell the DEFAULT for all crew/persistent sessions:
- Spawn session with shell
- Wait for ready
- Use `respawn-pane -k` with claude command (kills shell, starts claude directly)

This gives the cleaner lifecycle without requiring the user to be inside the session.

## Related

Part of tmux control plane unification - ability to manage workers from any session.

title: Replace WaitForClaudeReady with gt peek for steady-state agent observation
description:
## Problem

WaitForClaudeReady uses regex to detect Claude's prompt, which is a ZFC violation.

## Architectural Fix

**Bootstrap (ZFC violation acceptable):**
During cold town startup, no AI is available. Regex to get Deacon online is acceptable.

**Steady State (proper ZFC):**
Once any agent is running, AI should observe AI:
- Deacon starting polecats → Deacon uses gt peek
- Deacon restarting → Mayor watches via gt peek
- Mayor restarting → Deacon watches via gt peek

## Implementation

1. Keep WaitForClaudeReady for daemon bootstrap only
2. Update gt deacon trigger-pending to use gt peek
3. Document bootstrap vs steady-state distinction

title: Document Overseer role (human operator)
description:
Document the Overseer role in Gas Town architecture.

## The Overseer

The **Overseer** is the human operator of Gas Town. Not an agent - a person.

## Responsibilities

| Area | Overseer Does | Mayor/Agents Do |
|------|---------------|-----------------|
| Strategy | Define project goals | Execute toward goals |
| Priorities | Set priority order | Work in priority order |
| Escalations | Final decision on stuck work | Escalate to Overseer |
| Resources | Provision machines | Use allocated resources |
| Quality | Review & approve swarm output | Produce output |
| Operations | Run gt commands, monitor dashboards | Do the work |

## Key Interactions

### Overseer → Mayor
- Start/stop Mayor sessions
- Direct Mayor via conversation
- Review Mayor recommendations
- Approve cross-rig decisions

### Mayor → Overseer (Escalations)
- Stuck workers after retries
- Resource decisions (add machines, polecats)
- Ambiguous requirements
- Architecture decisions

## Operating Cadence

Typical Overseer workflow:
1. Morning: Check status, review overnight work
2. During day: Monitor, respond to escalations, adjust priorities
3. End of day: Review progress, plan next batch

## Commands for Overseers

```bash
gt status              # Quick health check
gt doctor              # Detailed diagnostics  
gt doctor --fix        # Auto-repair issues
gt inbox               # Messages from agents
gt stop --all          # Emergency halt
```

## Documentation Updates

Add to docs/architecture.md:
- Overseer section under Agent Roles
- Clarify Mayor reports to Overseer
- Add Overseer to workflow diagrams

title: Nudge newly spawned polecats
description:
Nudge newly spawned polecats that are ready for input.

When polecats are spawned, their Claude session takes 10-20 seconds to initialize.
The spawn command returns immediately without waiting. This step finds spawned
polecats that are now ready and sends them a trigger to start working.

```bash
# For each rig with polecats
for rig in gastown beads; do
    gt polecats $rig
    # For each working polecat, check if Claude is ready
    # Use tmux capture-pane to look for "> " prompt
done
```

For each ready polecat that hasn't been triggered yet:
1. Send "Begin." to trigger UserPromptSubmit hook
2. The hook injects mail, polecat sees its assignment
3. Mark polecat as triggered in state

Use WaitForClaudeReady from tmux package (polls for "> " prompt).
Timeout: 60 seconds per polecat. If not ready, try again next cycle.

title: Messaging infrastructure: lists, queues, and channels
description:
## Problem

Current messaging is point-to-point only:
- Mail: A → B (durable, polling)
- Nudge: A → B (ephemeral, real-time)

No support for broadcast, work queues, or pub/sub patterns.

## Design

### Addressing Syntax

| Prefix | System | Resolution | Storage | Claim? |
|--------|--------|------------|---------|--------|
| `agent/` | Mail | Direct | Recipient inbox | N/A |
| `@group` | Mail | Dynamic (filesystem) | Fan-out (N copies) | No |
| `list:name` | Mail | Static config | Fan-out (N copies) | No |
| `queue:name` | Mail | Static config | Shared (1 copy) | Yes |
| `announce:name` | Mail | Static config | Shared (1 copy) | No |
| `#channel` | Nudge | Dynamic (tmux) | None (ephemeral) | No |

### Dynamic Aliases

- `@rig/gastown` → scan ~/gt/gastown/ for agent dirs (witness, refinery, crew/*, polecats/*)
- `@town` → scan ~/gt/ for all agent dirs
- `@witnesses` → for each rig, include <rig>/witness
- `@crew/gastown` → scan ~/gt/gastown/crew/*
- `#rig/gastown` → scan tmux for gastown/* sessions
- `#town` → scan tmux for all Gas Town sessions

**Mail** resolves against filesystem (agents that exist)
**Channels** resolve against tmux (agents that are running)

### Static Config

Location: `~/gt/config/` (JSON format, machine-edited)

```json
// lists.json
{
  "oncall": ["mayor/", "gastown/witness", "beads/witness"],
  "cleanup/gastown": ["gastown/witness", "deacon/"]
}
```

### Work Queue Semantics

- `gt mail send queue:cleanup/gastown -s "Task" -m "..."`
- `bd update <msg-id> --claim` → atomic claim (sets assignee + in_progress)
- If already claimed, returns error "already claimed by X"

### Use Cases

1. **Polecat spawn**: `gt mail send @rig/gastown` → Witness + Deacon both notified
2. **Polecat cleanup**: `gt mail send queue:cleanup/gastown` → first to claim handles it
3. **Town broadcast**: `gt mail send @town -s "Handoff now"` → everyone gets copy
4. **Real-time alert**: `gt channel publish #witnesses "Swarm incoming"`

## Implementation Tasks

1. Create ~/gt/config/ directory structure
2. Implement dynamic alias resolution (filesystem scan)
3. Implement static list lookup (config/lists.json)
4. Add fan-out at send time for @/list: addresses
5. Implement queue: with shared storage
6. Add `bd update --claim` for work queue semantics
7. Implement channel resolution (tmux scan)
8. Add `gt channel publish` command

title: Doctor check: Zombie session cleanup
description:
Detect and clean up zombie tmux sessions via gt doctor.

## Problem

Zombie sessions occur when:
- Agent crashes without cleanup
- gt kill fails mid-operation
- System restart leaves orphan sessions
- Session naming collision

## Checks

### ZombieSessionCheck
- List all tmux sessions matching gt-* pattern
- Cross-reference with known polecats
- Flag sessions with no corresponding polecat state
- Flag sessions for removed polecats
- Check session age vs polecat creation time

### Detection Criteria
- Session exists but polecat directory doesn't
- Session name doesn't match any registered polecat
- Polecat state=idle but session running
- Multiple sessions for same polecat

## Output

```
[WARN] Zombie tmux sessions detected:
  - gt-wyvern-OldPolecat (polecat removed)
  - gt-beads-Unknown (no matching polecat)
  - gt-wyvern-Toast (duplicate session)

  Run 'gt doctor --fix' to clean up
```

## Auto-Fix (--fix flag)

- Kill orphan tmux sessions
- Update polecat state to match reality
- Log all cleanup actions

## Safety

- Never kill sessions where polecat state=working
- Prompt before killing if --fix used without --force
- Create audit log of killed sessions

title: gt refinery start: doesn't actually start a session
description:
## Problem

`gt refinery start gastown` reports success but doesn't start a tmux session.

## Evidence

```
$ gt refinery start gastown
Starting refinery for gastown...
✓ Refinery started for gastown

$ tmux list-sessions | grep refinery
(nothing)

$ gt refinery status gastown
State: ○ stopped
```

## Expected

Should start a tmux session (e.g., gt-gastown-refinery) with Claude processing the merge queue.

## Related

- gt-kcee: Witness commands also need implementation
- The refinery 'start' may just be updating state.json without spawning a session

title: Document Boot vs Deacon lifecycle and fix design confusion
description:
## Problem

The Boot/Deacon relationship is confusing and possibly over-engineered:

### Current Design
```
Daemon (Go process, 3-min heartbeat)
    │
    └─► Boot (ephemeral triage dog)
            │
            └─► Decides: start/wake/nudge/interrupt Deacon?
                    │
                    └─► Deacon (persistent patrol agent)
                            │
                            └─► health-scan: restart witness/refinery
```

### Questions

1. **Why two agents?** Boot exists to avoid waking Deacon unnecessarily in idle towns. But is this complexity worth it?

2. **Session ownership**: Boot should run in `gt-deacon-boot`, Deacon in `gt-deacon`. But current behavior is confused.

3. **Handoff**: When Boot starts Deacon, what happens to Boot? Does it exit? Hand off?

4. **Fallback**: Daemon has `checkDeaconHeartbeat()` as belt-and-suspenders. When does this fire vs Boot?

## Options

### Option A: Keep Boot/Deacon separation (fix implementation)
- Boot is ephemeral, spawns fresh each heartbeat
- Boot runs in `gt-deacon-boot`, exits after triage
- Deacon runs in `gt-deacon`, persistent patrol
- Clear session boundaries, clear lifecycle

### Option B: Merge Boot into Deacon
- Single `gt-deacon` session
- Deacon handles its own 'should I be awake?' logic
- Simpler, fewer moving parts
- Trade-off: Deacon consumes context even when idle

### Option C: Replace with simpler watchdog
- Daemon directly monitors witness/refinery
- No Boot, no Deacon AI agents for health checks
- Just Go code: if session dead, restart it
- AI agents only for complex decisions (escalations)

## Recommendation

Option A with clear documentation. The separation has merit for cost control in idle towns. But the implementation needs fixing.
close_reason: Documentation complete: created docs/watchdog-chain.md with full lifecycle explanation, design decision (keep separation), and cross-references

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: Unify gt sling and gt spawn with --args support
description:
## Summary

Complete the unification: `gt sling` becomes THE way to assign work. Remove top-level `gt spawn`.

## Current State (Partially Done)

- `gt sling` auto-spawns polecats when target is a rig
- `gt sling --args` stores args in bead (no-tmux mode, gt-vc3l4)
- `gt spawn` still exists with flags not yet in sling

## Remaining Work

### 1. Move spawn-only flags to sling

| Flag | Current | Action |
|------|---------|--------|
| `--naked` | spawn only | Move to sling |
| `--create` | spawn only | Move to sling |
| `--molecule` | spawn only | Move to sling |
| `--force` | spawn only | Move to sling |
| `--account` | spawn only | Move to sling |
| `--no-start` | spawn only | Evaluate if needed |

### 2. Remove top-level gt spawn

- Keep `gt spawn pending` as subcommand if still needed
- Remove `gt spawn` from root commands
- Update all docs and CLAUDE.md references

### 3. Unified UX Design

Target resolution (smart defaults):
```bash
gt sling gt-abc                    # Self (current agent)
gt sling gt-abc crew               # Crew worker in current rig  
gt sling gt-abc gastown            # Auto-spawn polecat in rig
gt sling gt-abc gastown/Toast      # Specific polecat
gt sling gt-abc mayor              # Mayor
```

Key flags:
```bash
gt sling gt-abc --args "patch release"   # Natural language context
gt sling gt-abc --naked                  # No-tmux mode (manual start)
gt sling gt-abc --create                 # Create polecat if missing
gt sling gt-abc --molecule mol-review    # Use specific workflow
```

### 4. Update Witness/Refinery/Deacon

These agents currently use `gt spawn`. Update to use `gt sling`:
- Witness: spawning polecats for work
- Refinery: spawning merge workers  
- Deacon: any spawn logic

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All spawn flags available in sling
- [ ] `gt spawn` removed (or hidden/deprecated)
- [ ] Witness uses `gt sling <rig>` for polecat work
- [ ] Docs updated
- [ ] Both human and agent UX is clean

title: Mayor restart loop: auto-prime and mail check on attach
description:
When mayor session cycles (after /exit, gt mayor attach reconnects), the new session lacks context.

## Current Behavior
- Mayor exits, shell script loop restarts claude
- New session starts cold - no gt prime, no mail check
- Mayor is disoriented, doesn't know prior context
- Strong 'antimemetic properties' - we discuss fixing it, then forget

## Expected Behavior
After restart, mayor should automatically:
1. Run gt prime (load role context)
2. Check gt mail inbox (find handoff messages)
3. Look for 🤝 HANDOFF messages from predecessor

## Possible Fixes
1. Startup hook in Claude Code settings that runs gt prime
2. CLAUDE.md instructions that say 'FIRST THING: run gt prime'
3. Shell script wrapper that injects context before attach
4. Modify gt mayor attach to inject prime command

## Related
- gt-vci: Mayor handoff mail template
- gt-sye: Mayor startup protocol prompting

title: gt crew next: Return self when only window in cycle group
description:
## Problem
`gt crew next --session 'gt-mayor'` returns exit code 1 when the Mayor is the only window in that cycle group.

## Expected Behavior
When an agent is the only member of its cycle group (or not in any configured cycle group), `gt crew next` should return the current session itself rather than failing.

## Context
- C-b n in Mayor's session triggers this command
- Currently only rig crews have configured cycle groups
- Mayor is not part of any crew cycle group, so it should just return itself

## Fix
If no other windows exist in the cycle group, return the current session name instead of error.

title: Spawn inject: Enter not submitted after multiline paste
description:
When gt spawn injects a multiline context (85+ lines), Claude Code shows 
'[Pasted text #1 +85 lines]' but the prompt is not submitted.

The tmux SendKeys function does include 'Enter' but it appears to not work
for long pasted text:

```go
func (t *Tmux) SendKeys(session, keys string) error {
    _, err := t.run("send-keys", "-t", session, keys, "Enter")
    return err
}
```

Possible fixes:
1. Use tmux paste-buffer instead of send-keys for long text
2. Send Enter separately after the text
3. Use bracketed paste mode correctly

Reproduction:
```bash
gt spawn gastown/Nux --issue gt-u1j.13 --create
# Session shows pasted text but waits at prompt
```

title: Add gt role command group with env-based role detection
description:
# gt role Command Group

Make role detection less fragile by using env var injection instead of cwd detection.

## Env Vars
- `GT_ROLE` - authoritative role name (mayor, witness, refinery, polecat, crew)
- `GT_ROLE_HOME` - canonical home directory for the role

## Detection Precedence
1. `$GT_ROLE` env var (authoritative)
2. Fall back to cwd-based detection (legacy/manual)
3. Warn if they disagree

## Subcommands
- `gt role` / `gt role show` - show current role
- `gt role home [ROLE]` - show home dir for role
- `gt role detect` - force cwd-based detection (debugging)
- `gt role list` - list all known roles
- `gt role env` - print export statements

## Integration Points
- gt prime - show role, warn on mismatch
- gt mol status - use gt role instead of own detection
- gt handoff - preserve GT_ROLE, reset to home
- All spawners - inject GT_ROLE and GT_ROLE_HOME

## Background
Mayor wandered to refinery dir, handoff preserved it, role detection broke.
Env var injection makes role stable across cd operations.

title: mol-polecat-lease
description:
Semaphore tracking a single polecat's lifecycle.
Vars: {{polecat}}, {{issue}}

Used by Witness to track polecat lifecycle during patrol. The Witness bonds
this proto for each active polecat, creating a lease that tracks the polecat
from spawn through work to cleanup.

## Step: boot
Spawned. Verify it starts working.

Check if the polecat is alive and working:
```bash
gt peek {{polecat}}
```

If idle for too long, nudge:
```bash
gt nudge {{polecat}} "Please start working on your assigned issue."
```

Timeout: 60s before escalation to Mayor.

## Step: working
Actively working. Monitor for stuck.

The polecat is processing its assigned issue ({{issue}}).
Monitor via peek. Watch for:
- Progress on commits
- Status updates in beads
- SHUTDOWN mail when done

Wait for SHUTDOWN signal from the polecat.
Needs: boot

## Step: done
Exit received. Ready for cleanup.

The polecat has completed its work and sent SHUTDOWN.
Perform cleanup:
```bash
gt session kill {{polecat}}
gt worktree prune {{polecat}}
```

Update beads state and close the lease.
Needs: working

title: boot
description:
Spawned. Verify the polecat starts working.

Check if the polecat is alive and working:
```bash
gt peek {{polecat}}
```

If idle for too long (>60s), nudge:
```bash
gt nudge {{polecat}} "Please start working on your assigned issue."
```

Timeout: 60s before escalation to Mayor.
Variables: {{polecat}}, {{issue}}

title: working
description:
Actively working. Monitor for stuck.

The polecat is processing its assigned issue ({{issue}}).
Monitor via peek. Watch for:
- Progress on commits
- Status updates in beads
- SHUTDOWN mail when done

Wait for SHUTDOWN signal from the polecat.
Variables: {{polecat}}, {{issue}}

title: gt mail inbox doesn't find crew worker mail - identity mismatch
description:
## Problem

Crew workers don't see their handoff messages when running `gt mail inbox` from their working directory.

## Root Cause

gt derives identity from cwd path, but crew workers have a different path structure:
- **cwd**: `/Users/stevey/gt/beads/crew/dave`
- **gt derives**: `beads/crew/dave` (wrong)
- **should be**: `beads/dave` (crew workers use `rig/name` format)

Messages sent to `beads/dave` don't show up because gt is looking for `beads/crew/dave`.

## Workaround

Use explicit identity flag:
```bash
gt mail inbox --identity "beads/dave"
```

## Fix

Identity detection in gt should handle crew/ subdirectory:
- Path `<rig>/crew/<name>` should derive identity as `<rig>/<name>`
- This matches how polecats work: `<rig>/polecats/<name>` → `<rig>/<name>`

## Affected

All crew workers in all rigs.

title: Epic: Async Gates for Agent Coordination
description:
## Summary

Agents need an async primitive for waiting on external events (CI completion,
API responses, human approval). Currently they either poll wastefully or cant
resume after handoff.

## Design: Deacon-Managed Gates

### Core Concepts

**Gate** = wisp issue that blocks until external condition is met
- Type: `gate`
- Phase: wisp (never synced, ephemeral)
- Assignee: `deacon/` (Deacon monitors it)
- Fields: `await_type`, `await_id`, `timeout`, `waiters[]`

**Await Types:**
- `gh:run:<id>` - GitHub Actions run completion
- `gh:pr:<id>` - PR merged/closed
- `timer:<duration>` - Simple delay (e.g., "5m", "1h")
- `human:<prompt>` - Human approval required
- `mail:<pattern>` - Wait for mail matching pattern

### Commands

```bash
bd gate create --await <type>:<id> --timeout <duration> --notify <addr>
bd gate show <id>
bd gate list
bd gate close <id> --reason "completed"
bd gate wait <id> --notify <addr>
```

## Children (suggested breakdown)

1. Add `gate` issue type to beads
2. Add gate fields: await_type, await_id, timeout, waiters
3. Implement `bd gate create/show/list/close/wait` commands
4. Add gate checking to Deacon patrol loop
5. Implement await type handlers (gh:run, gh:pr, timer, human, mail)
6. Add gate timeout tracking and notification
7. Integration test: agent waits for CI via gate

## Open Questions

- Should gates live in wisp storage or main storage with wisp flag?
- Do we need a gate catalog (like molecule catalog)?
- Should `waits-for` dep type work with gates?

title: Standardize wisp creation syntax across role templates
description:
## Task

Role templates use inconsistent syntax for creating wisps.

## Current State

**Deacon template:**
```bash
bd mol wisp create mol-deacon-patrol
bd update <wisp-id> --status=pinned --assignee=deacon
```

**Witness template (BROKEN - see gt-xxx):**
```bash
bd mol wisp mol-witness-patrol --assignee={{ .RigName }}/witness
```

## Recommended Pattern

All patrol roles should use the same two-step pattern:
```bash
bd mol wisp create mol-<role>-patrol
bd update <wisp-id> --status=pinned --assignee=<identity>
```

Or we should add `--assignee` flag to `bd mol wisp` (file in beads repo if preferred).

## Templates to Update

- witness.md.tmpl (broken, needs immediate fix)
- Verify consistency in refinery.md.tmpl if it also creates wisps

## Related

This is a consistency task; the witness template bug is tracked separately as P0.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: ZFC: Auto-close convoys when tracked issues close via bd close
description:
When bd close closes an issue, check if this issue was tracked by any convoy. If all tracked issues in a convoy are now closed, auto-close the convoy.

## Background
PR #236 attempted to fix stale convoys by calling gt convoy check in the refinery merge handler. This is a ZFC violation - it couples the refinery to convoy semantics and uses the wrong trigger point.

## Proper ZFC approach
The closure event should propagate at the source:
1. bd close closes an issue
2. Check if this issue is tracked by any open convoy
3. For each convoy tracking this issue, check if all tracked issues are now closed
4. If so, auto-close the convoy

## Implementation notes
- Add convoy-check logic to bd close command
- The deacon patrol step check-convoy-completion remains as backup

## Related
- PR #236 (closed - ZFC violation)
- Deacon patrol step: check-convoy-completion

**nudge-N**:

```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: Epic: Wisp Molecule Integration
description:
## Vision

Integrate Beads wisp molecules into Gas Town. All orchestration work runs as wisp molecules - patrols, polecat workflows, batch operations. Only digests reach main beads.

## The Steam Engine Metaphor

```
Engine does work → generates steam
Steam wisps rise → execution trace
Steam condenses → digest (distillate)  
Steam dissipates → cleaned up (burned)
```

## Architecture

```
Proto Molecules (templates)
    ↓ bd mol bond
Wisps (.beads-wisps/ or inline)
    ↓ bd mol squash + AI summary
Main Beads (digests only)
```

## Vocabulary

| Term | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| bond | Attach proto to work (creates wisps) |
| wisp | Temporary execution step (steam rising) |
| squash | Condense wisps into digest |
| burn | Destroy wisps without record |
| digest | Permanent condensed record (distillate) |

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Wisp location**: Per-rig or inline in main beads with wisp flag
2. **Summary generation**: Agent that did work generates summary (inversion of control)
3. **Squash timing**: Final step of molecule workflow, before signaling done
4. **Crash recovery**: Wisps persist, Witness detects stalls, new agent resumes
5. **Patrols**: Each cycle is fresh wisp molecule, squashed on completion

## Digest Contents

- Molecule type and instance ID
- Assignee, start/end times
- Source issue reference
- AI-generated summary
- Outcomes (issues closed, commits, branches)

## Integration Points

- gt rig init: Configure wisp storage
- gt spawn --molecule: Bond creates wisps
- gt prime: Show wisp molecule context
- Polecat CLAUDE.md: Summary + squash protocol
- gt doctor: Wisp health checks
- Deacon/Witness/Refinery: Patrol molecules

## Phases

Phase 1: Wisp setup infrastructure
Phase 2: Spawn integration
Phase 3: Completion flow (summary + squash)
Phase 4: Patrol integration
Phase 5: Documentation and polish

title: Phase 1.1: gt rig init creates .beads-ephemeral/
description:
Add ephemeral beads repo creation to rig initialization.

## Implementation

In `gt rig init` (or equivalent setup):
1. Create `<rig>/.beads-ephemeral/` directory
2. Initialize as git repo
3. Create minimal beads config (no sync-branch needed)
4. Add to .gitignore if not already

## Config

```yaml
# .beads-ephemeral/config.yaml
ephemeral: true
# No sync-branch - ephemeral is local only
```

## Verification

```bash
gt rig init gastown
ls gastown/.beads-ephemeral/  # Should exist
```

title: Phase 5.1: Document ephemeral architecture
description:
Update docs with ephemeral molecule architecture.

## Files to Update

### docs/architecture.md
- Add Ephemeral Molecules section
- Diagram: Proto → Ephemeral → Digest flow
- Explain inversion of control for summaries

### docs/molecules.md (new or update)
- Proto molecule catalog
- Ephemeral vs main beads
- Molecule lifecycle
- Summary generation guidelines

### Agent CLAUDE.md files
- Polecat: molecule workflow protocol
- Deacon: patrol cycle pattern
- Witness: patrol cycle pattern
- Refinery: patrol cycle pattern

## Key Concepts to Document

1. Everything is a molecule
2. Orchestration molecules are ephemeral
3. Only digests reach main beads
4. Agents generate their own summaries
5. Crash recovery via ephemeral persistence

title: Phase 1.2: Configure bd for ephemeral molecule bonding
description:
Ensure bd mol bond --ephemeral works with Gas Town setup.

## Questions for Dave

1. Does bd automatically find .beads-ephemeral/ or need explicit path?
2. How does bd mol bond --ephemeral know which repo to use?
3. Is there a redirect mechanism for ephemeral like main beads?

## Integration

From polecat/crew working directory:
```bash
bd mol bond mol-polecat-work --ephemeral --assignee $(gt whoami)
```

Should create molecule in rig's .beads-ephemeral/, not main beads.

title: Phase 1.3: gt doctor checks for ephemeral health
description:
Add doctor checks for ephemeral beads repo.

## Checks

1. **ephemeral-exists**: .beads-ephemeral/ directory exists for each rig
2. **ephemeral-git**: It's a valid git repo
3. **ephemeral-orphans**: Molecules started but never squashed (>24h old)
4. **ephemeral-size**: Warn if ephemeral repo is >100MB (should be cleaned)
5. **ephemeral-stale**: Molecules with no activity in last hour

## Auto-fix

--fix can:
- Create missing ephemeral repo
- Clean up old completed molecules (already squashed)
- NOT auto-squash incomplete molecules (needs AI summary)

title: Phase 2.1: gt spawn --molecule bonds in ephemeral
description:
Make gt spawn molecule-aware with ephemeral bonding.

## New Flag

```bash
gt spawn --issue gt-xxx --molecule mol-polecat-work
```

## Behavior

1. Create polecat with fresh worktree (existing)
2. Bond molecule in ephemeral: `bd mol bond mol-polecat-work --ephemeral`
3. Link molecule root to source issue
4. Include molecule context in work assignment mail
5. Start session

## Work Assignment Mail

```
Subject: Work Assignment: Fix lifecycle bug [MOLECULE]

You are working on gt-rixa as part of molecule mol-polecat-work.

Molecule instance: eph-abc123
Current step: read-assignment (1/8)

Follow the molecule workflow. When complete, generate summary and squash.
```

title: Phase 2.2: gt prime shows ephemeral molecule context
description:
Update gt prime to detect and display ephemeral molecule state.

## Detection

1. Check for active ephemeral molecule assigned to current identity
2. Parse molecule progress (current step, total steps)
3. Show in prime output

## Output

```
🔧 Polecat furiosa, checking in.

📦 Molecule: mol-polecat-work (eph-abc123)
   Step 3/8: do-work
   Source: gt-rixa
   Started: 10 minutes ago

Run 'bd mol status' for full molecule state.
```

title: Phase 2.3: Polecat CLAUDE.md molecule workflow protocol
description:
Update polecat prompting for molecule-based work.

## CLAUDE.md Updates

Add section on molecule workflow:

```markdown
## Molecule Workflow

When assigned a molecule (check gt prime output):

1. Follow molecule steps in order
2. Mark steps complete: bd mol step complete <step-id>
3. Before signaling done:
   a. Generate summary of work performed
   b. Run: bd squash <molecule-root> --summary "<your summary>"
4. Then signal done as normal

### Summary Guidelines

Your summary should include:
- What was the task?
- What did you do?
- What was the outcome?
- Any issues or follow-ups?

Keep it to 2-4 sentences. This becomes the permanent record.
```

title: Phase 3.1: Summary generation protocol
description:
Define how agents generate summaries for squash.

## The Problem

Beads doesn't make AI calls (inversion of control). Gas Town agents must:
1. Generate their own summary before calling squash
2. Pass summary to bd squash command

## Summary Template

```
Task: <source issue title>
Action: <what was done - fix/implement/refactor/etc>
Outcome: <result - tests pass, committed, needs follow-up, etc>
Details: <1-2 sentences of specifics if needed>
```

## Example

```
Task: Fix lifecycle parser matching bug (gt-rixa)
Action: Reordered conditional checks in parseLifecycleRequest
Outcome: Tests passing, committed to polecat/furiosa
Details: The 'cycle' keyword was matching 'lifecycle:' prefix. Now checks restart/shutdown first, uses word boundary for cycle.
```

## Command

```bash
bd squash eph-abc123 --summary "Task: Fix lifecycle parser..."
```

title: Phase 3.2: mol-polecat-work squash step
description:
Add summary+squash as final steps in mol-polecat-work.

## Current Steps

1. read-assignment
2. understand-task
3. implement-solution
4. verify-tests
5. commit-work
6. signal-done

## Updated Steps

1. read-assignment
2. understand-task
3. implement-solution
4. verify-tests
5. commit-work
6. **generate-summary** ← NEW
7. **squash-molecule** ← NEW
8. signal-done

## Step Definitions

### generate-summary
Agent writes a concise summary following the template.
Save to a local variable or temp file.

### squash-molecule
Run: bd squash $MOLECULE_ROOT --summary "$SUMMARY"
This creates digest in main beads, cleans ephemeral.

## Update Location

This requires updating the mol-polecat-work definition in beads molecule catalog.

title: Phase 4.1: mol-deacon-patrol uses ephemeral
description:
Deacon patrol cycles run as ephemeral molecules.

## Current Deacon Loop

```
while running:
    check_heartbeat()
    check_mail()
    sleep(interval)
```

## Molecule-Based Loop

```
while running:
    mol = bd mol bond mol-deacon-patrol-cycle --ephemeral
    execute_cycle(mol):
        check_heartbeat()
        check_mail()
        log_status()
    summary = generate_cycle_summary()
    bd squash mol --summary summary
    sleep(interval)
```

## Benefits

- Each cycle is tracked
- Digests show daemon health over time
- Can query: 'show me patrol cycles from last hour'
- Crash mid-cycle → ephemeral shows where we were

title: Update Refinery to use Beads merge queue
description:
Replace branch discovery with Beads queue in the Refinery module:

Current (internal/refinery/manager.go):
- Scans for polecat/* branches
- Creates MR objects on-the-fly

New:
- Pull from Beads: bd ready --type=merge-request
- Process each MR
- Close with merge commit: bd close <id> --reason="Merged at <sha>"
- Handle failures: bd update <id> --status=blocked --reason="..."

The Engineer (agent) becomes Beads-native.
The Refinery (module) provides the infrastructure.

title: Engineer main loop: poll for ready merge-requests
description:
Implement the Engineer's main processing loop.

Loop structure:
1. Query: bd ready --type=merge-request
2. If empty: sleep(poll_interval), continue
3. Select highest priority, oldest MR
4. Claim: bd update <id> --status=in_progress
5. Process (delegate to other subtasks)
6. Repeat

Configuration:
- poll_interval: from rig config (default 30s)
- max_concurrent: from rig config (default 1)

The loop should be interruptible and handle graceful shutdown.

Reference: docs/merge-queue-design.md#engineer-processing-loop

title: Fetch and conflict check: git operations for MR
description:
Implement git operations for MR processing.

Steps:
1. git fetch origin <mr.branch>
2. git checkout <mr.target> (main or integration/xxx)
3. git merge --no-commit --no-ff <mr.branch> (test merge)
4. Check for conflicts
5. If conflicts: abort and return Failure(conflict, files)
6. If clean: abort (actual merge in next step)

Helper functions:
- FetchBranch(branch string) error
- CheckConflicts(source, target string) ([]string, error)

Reference: docs/merge-queue-design.md#process-merge-steps

title: Merge execution: merge, test, push
description:
Implement the actual merge execution.

Steps:
1. git checkout <mr.target>
2. git merge <mr.branch> --no-ff -m 'Merge <branch>: <title>'
3. If config.run_tests:
   - Run test_command (from config)
   - If failed: git reset --hard HEAD~1, return Failure(tests_failed)
4. git push origin <mr.target>
5. Return Success(merge_commit=HEAD)

Configuration:
- run_tests: bool (default true)
- test_command: string (default 'go test ./...')

Handle push failures with retry logic.

Reference: docs/merge-queue-design.md#process-merge-steps

title: Failure handling: assign back to worker, add labels
description:
Handle merge failures appropriately.

Failure types and actions:
| Failure     | Action                                      |
|-------------|---------------------------------------------|
| conflict    | Add needs-rebase label, assign to worker    |
| tests_fail  | Add needs-fix label, assign to worker       |
| build_fail  | Add needs-fix label, assign to worker       |
| flaky_test  | Retry once, then treat as tests_fail        |
| push_fail   | Retry with backoff, escalate if persistent  |

Actions:
1. bd update <id> --status=open --assignee=<worker>
2. bd update <id> --labels=<failure-label>
3. Send mail to worker explaining failure
4. Log failure details

Reference: docs/merge-queue-design.md#handling-failures

title: Success handling: close MR, close source issue, cleanup
description:
Handle successful merge completion.

Steps:
1. Update MR with merge_commit SHA:
   bd update <id> --body='...\nmerge_commit: <sha>'
2. Close MR with reason:
   bd close <id> --reason='merged'
3. Close source issue (the work item):
   bd close <source_issue> --reason='Merged in <mr_id>'
4. Delete source branch (if configured):
   git push origin --delete <mr.branch>
5. Log success

Configuration:
- delete_merged_branches: bool (default true)

Reference: docs/merge-queue-design.md#process-merge-steps

title: Polecats must not create GitHub PRs
description:
Polecats should never use 'gh pr create' or create GitHub pull requests.

## Correct Workflow
1. Polecat works on polecat/<name> branch
2. Commits and pushes to origin
3. Creates beads MR issue (type: merge-request)
4. Refinery processes the MR and merges to main

## Wrong Workflow
- Using gh pr create
- Creating GitHub pull requests directly

## Why
- Refinery is our merge queue processor
- GitHub PRs bypass our workflow
- Beads MRs are the coordination mechanism

title: gt spawn should use bd mol run for molecule attachment
description:
Simplify Gas Town to use bd mol run for work tracking.

## Key Insight
Two distinct mechanisms, not duplicative:

| Mechanism | Purpose | Query |
|-----------|---------|-------|
| **Pinned molecule** (bd mol run) | What am I working on? | `bd list --pinned --assignee=me` |
| **Handoff mail** | Context notes for restart | `gt mail read` (self-addressed) |

The handoff is just **mail to yourself** - optional context notes.
The molecule is **the actual work** - required state.

## Current State (Overengineered)
Gas Town has custom attachment system:
- Permanent "Foo Handoff" pinned beads per identity
- AttachMolecule(pinnedBeadID, moleculeID) 
- Attachment fields parsed from description
- Separate from beads pinning

## New Model (Simplified)
Use bd mol run directly:

```bash
# Spawn polecat with molecule
bd mol run mol-polecat-work --var issue=gt-xyz
# This: spawns, assigns to caller, pins root, sets in_progress
```

Query current work:
```bash
bd list --pinned --assignee=gastown/furiosa --status=in_progress
```

Handoff context (when needed):
```bash
gt mail send gastown/furiosa -s "Context notes" -m "Was on step 4..."
```

## Changes Required

### Remove from Gas Town
- AttachMolecule() / DetachMolecule()
- AttachmentFields struct and parsing
- GetAttachment() / SetAttachmentFields()
- Permanent pinned handoff beads per identity
- Daemon attachment detection (checkDeaconAttachment)

### Update gt spawn
```go
// Old: custom molecule instantiation + attachment
// New: just call bd mol run
cmd := exec.Command("bd", "mol", "run", protoID, "--var", "issue="+issueID)
```

### Update gt prime / agent context
```go
// Old: find handoff bead, parse attachment
// New: query for pinned molecule
cmd := exec.Command("bd", "list", "--pinned", "--assignee="+identity, "--status=in_progress", "--json")
```

### Update documentation
- Remove handoff bead attachment docs
- Clarify: handoff = mail, molecule = work
- Update CLAUDE.md templates

## Benefits
1. One system for work tracking (beads)
2. Simpler Gas Town code
3. bd mol squash works naturally
4. Handoff is just mail (already works)

## Related
- gt-3x0z: Wisp Molecule Integration
- gt-rana: Patrol System
- gt-lek6: gt rig reset --stale
- gt-ay1r: gt molecule current

title: gt rig reset: clear stale mail on reset/land
description:
## Problem

When resetting or landing a rig/town, stale mail messages can confuse agents on startup. Old handoff messages, daemon notifications, and inter-agent mail should be cleaned up as part of reset.

## Current State

- `gt rig reset` exists but doesn't clear mail
- Stale messages accumulate (e.g., daemon SHUTDOWN messages)
- Agents may read outdated context on startup

## Proposed Behavior

`gt rig reset` and `gt town reset` should:
1. Close all open messages (`--type=message`) in the relevant beads
2. Optionally preserve pinned handoff beads (clear content, keep bead)
3. Log what was cleaned up

```bash
gt rig reset gastown          # Clears gastown mail
gt rig reset gastown --mail   # Only clear mail, keep other state
gt town reset                 # Clears all town-level mail
gt town reset --all           # Clears mail in all rigs too
```

## Implementation

1. Query `bd list --type=message --status=open`
2. Close each with reason 'Cleared during reset'
3. For pinned handoffs: `bd update <id> --description=''` instead of close

title: gt nudge should accept flexible session identifiers
description:
Currently `gt nudge` requires the exact tmux session name (e.g., `gt-gastown-furiosa`).

It should also accept:
- `gastown/furiosa` (rig/polecat format)
- `furiosa` (polecat name, infer rig from cwd or require if ambiguous)

The session list command shows `gastown/furiosa` format, but nudge rejects it:
```
gt session list → shows 'gastown/furiosa'
gt nudge gastown/furiosa 'msg' → 'session not found'
gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa 'msg' → works
```

Should normalize all these formats to the tmux session name internally.

title: Implement gt sling command
description:
The unified work dispatch command.

```bash
gt sling <thing> <target> [options]
```

Implements spawn + assign + pin in one operation. See sling-design.md.

Acceptance:
- [ ] Parse thing (proto name, issue ID, epic ID)
- [ ] Parse target (agent address)  
- [ ] Spawn molecule if proto
- [ ] Assign to target agent
- [ ] Pin to agent's hook (pinned bead)
- [ ] Support --wisp flag for ephemeral
- [ ] Support --molecule flag for issue+workflow
- [ ] Error if hook already occupied (unless --force)

title: Doctor check: Worker health and stuck detection
description:
Detect and report stuck workers via gt doctor.

## Checks

### WorkerHealthCheck
- List all active workers (polecats with state=working)
- Check last activity timestamp for each
- Flag as potentially stuck if no progress for configurable threshold (default: 30 min)
- Check if Witness is running for the rig
- Verify Witness last heartbeat time

### Stuck Detection Criteria
- Polecat state=working but session not running
- Polecat state=working but output unchanged for threshold
- Witness not responding to health checks
- Multiple polecats in same rig all stuck

## Output

```
[WARN] Workers in rig 'wyvern' may be stuck:
  - Toast: working for 45m, no recent output
  - Capable: working for 52m, session not found
  - Witness: last heartbeat 20m ago
  
  Suggestions:
  - gt witness status wyvern
  - gt capture wyvern/Toast 50
  - gt stop --rig wyvern (kill all)
```

## Auto-Fix

Cannot auto-fix stuck workers (risk of data loss), but can:
- Restart Witness daemon if crashed
- Send warning mail to Mayor

title: Molecules: Composable Workflow Beads
description:
## Summary

Molecules are crystallized workflow patterns stored as Beads issues.
When instantiated, the molecule creates child beads forming a DAG.

## Key Insight: Molecules ARE Beads

Per HOP Decision 001: Beads IS the ledger. Molecules don't get a separate YAML format - they're issues with `type: molecule` containing prose-based step definitions.

Agents don't need rigid schemas. They parse natural language natively. A molecule is just instructions with enough structure for tooling.

## Example: Engineer in a Box

```markdown
id: mol-xyz
type: molecule
title: Engineer in a Box

This workflow takes a task from design to merge.

## Step: design
Think carefully about architecture. Consider existing patterns, 
trade-offs, testability.

## Step: implement
Write clean code. Follow codebase conventions.
Needs: design

## Step: review  
Review for bugs, edge cases, style issues.
Needs: implement

## Step: test
Write and run tests. Cover happy path and edge cases.
Needs: implement

## Step: submit
Submit for merge via refinery.
Needs: review, test
```

## Instantiation

```bash
# Attach molecule when spawning
gt spawn --issue gt-abc --molecule mol-xyz

# Creates child beads atomically:
gt-abc.design     ← ready first
gt-abc.implement  ← blocked by design  
gt-abc.review     ← blocked by implement
gt-abc.test       ← blocked by implement
gt-abc.submit     ← blocked by review, test
```

Each step issue gets an `instantiated-from` edge to the molecule (with step metadata).

## Why This Matters

1. **Unified data plane**: Everything in Beads, no parallel YAML channel
2. **AI-native**: Prose instructions, not rigid schemas
3. **Error isolation**: Each step is a checkpoint - failure doesn't lose progress
4. **Scales with AI**: As agents get smarter, they handle more complex molecules

## Implementation Primitives

- `ParseMoleculeSteps()`: Extract steps from prose (convention-based)
- `InstantiateMolecule()`: Atomic transaction creating all steps + edges  
- `instantiated-from` edge type: Track provenance
- Parameterization: `{{variable}}` substitution from context map

title: Molecule schema: YAML format for workflow definitions
description:
Define the YAML schema for molecule definitions:

```yaml
molecule: <name>
version: 1
description: "Human description"
steps:
  - id: <step-id>
    title: "Step title"
    prompt: "Instructions for agent"
    depends: [<other-step-ids>]  # optional
    tier: haiku|sonnet|opus      # optional, default from config
    timeout: 30m                 # optional
```

Store molecules in:
- `<rig>/molecules/<name>.yaml` for rig-specific
- `<town>/molecules/<name>.yaml` for town-wide

Built-in molecules to ship:
- engineer-in-box: design→code→review→test→submit
- quick-fix: implement→test→submit
- research: investigate→document

title: Molecule instantiation: create child beads from template
description:
When instantiating a molecule on a work bead:

## Transaction Flow

1. Parse molecule's `## Step:` sections from description
2. Begin SQLite transaction
3. For each step, create child issue:
   - ID: `{parent-id}.{step-ref}` or generated
   - Title: step title (from header or first line)
   - Description: step prose instructions
   - Type: task
   - Priority: inherit from parent
4. Add `instantiated-from` edge from each step to molecule:
   ```sql
   INSERT INTO dependencies (issue_id, depends_on_id, type, metadata)
   VALUES (step_id, mol_id, 'instantiated-from', '{"step": "implement"}');
   ```
5. Wire inter-step dependencies from `Needs:` lines
6. Commit transaction (atomic - all or nothing)

## Parsing Conventions

```markdown
## Step: <ref>
<prose instructions>
Needs: <step>, <step>  # optional
Tier: haiku|sonnet|opus  # optional hint
```

## Parameterization

Steps can have `{{variable}}` placeholders:
```markdown
## Step: implement
Implement {{feature_name}} in {{target_file}}.
```

Context map provided at instantiation time.

## API

```go
func (s *Store) InstantiateMolecule(mol *Issue, parent *Issue, ctx map[string]string) ([]*Issue, error)
func ParseMoleculeSteps(description string) ([]MoleculeStep, error)
```

Implementation lives in `internal/beads/molecule.go`.

title: Molecule CLI: bd molecule commands
description:
Add molecule commands to bd:

## Commands

```bash
bd molecule list              # List molecules (type: molecule)
bd molecule show <id>         # Show molecule with parsed steps
bd molecule parse <id>        # Validate and show parsed structure  
bd molecule instantiate <mol-id> --parent=<issue-id>  # Create steps
bd molecule instances <mol-id>  # Show all instantiations
```

## gt spawn integration

```bash
gt spawn --issue <id> --molecule <mol-id>
```

This should:
1. Call `bd molecule instantiate` (creates child beads atomically)
2. Spawn polecat on first ready step
3. Polecat grinds through via `bd ready`

## Output Examples

```
$ bd molecule show mol-abc

mol-abc: Engineer in a Box
Type: molecule

Steps (5):
  design      → (ready first)
  implement   → Needs: design
  review      → Needs: implement
  test        → Needs: implement  
  submit      → Needs: review, test
  
Instances: 3
```

```
$ bd molecule instances mol-abc

Parent          Status    Created
gt-xyz          done      2025-12-15
gt-abc          active    2025-12-17 (3/5 complete)
gt-def          pending   2025-12-18
```

title: Built-in molecules: engineer-in-box, quick-fix, research
description:
Create built-in molecules as Beads issues:

## engineer-in-box

```markdown
id: mol-engineer-in-box
type: molecule
title: Engineer in a Box

Full workflow from design to merge.

## Step: design
Think carefully about architecture. Consider:
- Existing patterns in the codebase
- Trade-offs between approaches  
- Testability and maintainability

Write a brief design summary before proceeding.

## Step: implement
Write the code. Follow codebase conventions.
Needs: design

## Step: review
Self-review the changes. Look for:
- Bugs and edge cases
- Style issues
- Missing error handling
Needs: implement

## Step: test
Write and run tests. Cover happy path and edge cases.
Fix any failures before proceeding.
Needs: implement

## Step: submit
Submit for merge via refinery.
Needs: review, test
```

## quick-fix

```markdown
id: mol-quick-fix
type: molecule  
title: Quick Fix

Fast path for small changes.

## Step: implement
Make the fix. Keep it focused.

## Step: test
Run relevant tests. Fix any regressions.
Needs: implement

## Step: submit
Submit for merge.
Needs: test
```

## research

```markdown
id: mol-research
type: molecule
title: Research

Investigation workflow.

## Step: investigate
Explore the question. Search code, read docs, 
understand context. Take notes.

## Step: document
Write up findings. Include:
- What you learned
- Recommendations
- Open questions
Needs: investigate
```

## Storage

Built-in molecules live in `<town>/.beads/` as regular issues.
Created during `gt install` or `bd init`.

title: gt sling to town roles should use Town beads
description:
## Problem

When Mayor starts from ~/gt (town root), `gt mol status` couldn't find beads pinned in rig beads.

## Solution

Added cross-rig scanning for town-level roles (mayor, deacon):
1. First check local beads directory  
2. If nothing found AND target is a town-level role, scan all registered rigs
3. Return first pinned bead found

This makes `gt mol status` work correctly regardless of where Mayor is when checking hook status.

## Tested

1. `gt sling gt-552hb mayor` from gastown/mayor/rig/ - pins in rig beads ✓
2. `gt mol status` from ~/gt - finds the pinned bead via cross-rig scan ✓

title: Refinery as Worktree: Local MR Integration
description:
Move refinery from separate clone to git worktree. Polecats stop pushing to origin - refinery sees their branches locally. MRs become wisps (ephemeral). Only main gets pushed after merge.

## Goals
- Origin stays clean (only main + beads-sync branches)
- No orphaned polecat branches ever
- Simpler mental model for MR coordination
- Faster integration (no network for local MR ops)

## Trade-offs
- Machine crash = redo pending work (acceptable, beads track state)
- Future federation needs different approach (bundles or integration branch)

## Components Affected
- Rig initialization (refinery setup)
- Spawn/polecat workflow (remove origin push)
- Refinery manager (local branch access)
- Documentation (architecture, workflows)
- Molecule templates (remove push instructions)

title: Update rig init to create refinery as worktree
description:
Modify rig initialization to create refinery as a git worktree instead of a separate clone.

## Changes
- internal/rig/init.go or similar - change refinery setup
- Create worktree at <rig>/refinery/ with branch 'refinery'
- Remove clone logic for refinery
- Update any path assumptions

## Considerations
- Refinery worktree should track main (or its own branch?)
- May need to handle existing rigs (migration path)

title: Remove origin push from polecat workflow
description:
Polecats should no longer push their branches to origin.

## Changes
- internal/cmd/done.go - remove 'git push origin HEAD'
- internal/cmd/mq_submit.go - remove branch push
- Molecule templates - remove push instructions
- Any hooks that push polecat branches

## Verification
- Polecat completes work without pushing
- Branch stays local
- Refinery can still see the branch (via shared .git)

title: Update refinery to read local branches
description:
Refinery manager needs to access polecat branches locally instead of fetching from origin.

## Changes
- internal/refinery/manager.go - remove origin fetch for MR branches
- internal/refinery/engineer.go - local branch access
- Remove DeleteRemoteBranch calls (branches are local now)
- Update merge workflow to work with local refs

## Key insight
All worktrees share the same .git - refinery can see polecat/nux branch directly.

title: Convert MR queue to wisp storage
description:
MR queue should use wisp storage (.beads-wisp/) instead of durable beads.

## Design (Simplified)

With refinery as worktree, polecats and refinery share the same machine. No cross-machine MR coordination needed. Wisps are the natural fit.

### Storage
- Location: `.beads-wisp/mq/<mr-id>.json`
- Format: Same MRFields structure (branch, target, source_issue, worker, rig)
- Lifecycle: Create on submit, delete after merge

### Code Changes

1. **MR Creation** (done.go, mq_submit.go)
   - Write to `.beads-wisp/mq/` instead of `bd create --type=merge-request`
   - Generate ID: `mr-<timestamp>-<random>` or similar

2. **Refinery Query** (refinery/manager.go, engineer.go)
   - Read from `.beads-wisp/mq/` directory
   - List files, parse JSON, process in order

3. **Cleanup**
   - Delete MR file after successful merge
   - On failure, leave file (refinery retries)

### What Stays in Beads
- Source issues (the work being merged) - still tracked in beads
- Merge commits reference source issue ID
- `bd close <issue>` still happens on merge

### Benefits
- No sync overhead for transient MR state
- Simpler model (file per MR, delete when done)
- Consistent with wisp philosophy (ephemeral operational state)

### Not Needed
- Digest squashing (MRs are deleted, not accumulated)
- Cross-machine visibility (single-machine architecture)

title: Update architecture documentation
description:
Update all documentation to reflect refinery-as-worktree model.

## Files to update
- docs/architecture.md (if exists)
- CLAUDE.md references to refinery
- mayor/rig/docs/*.md - any refinery docs
- wisp-architecture.md - add MR wisp details
- README files mentioning clone vs worktree

## Key messages
- Refinery is worktree, not clone
- Polecat branches stay local
- Only main pushed to origin
- MRs are wisps (ephemeral)

title: Design future federation model
description:
Document how remote/federated refinery would work in the future.

## Options to document
1. Git bundles - portable patches, no branches on origin
2. Dedicated integration branch pattern (integration/*)
3. Hybrid - local for same-machine, bundles for remote

## Deliverable
Design doc in docs/federation-refinery.md or similar.
Not implementing now - just capturing the design for when needed.

3. Deprecation: Old rigs work but warn, new rigs use worktree

## Considerations
- Don't break existing setups
- Clear upgrade path
- Handle in-flight MRs during migration

title: Ephemeral protos: Remove proto-as-bead storage, cook inline
description:
## Summary

Refactor the molecular chemistry stack so protos are ephemeral in-memory data structures, not persisted beads with `[template]` labels.

## Current State

```
Formula (.formula.json)  → cook → Proto (bead with [template]) → pour/wisp → Mol/Wisp
```

Protos are stored as beads issues with `labels: ["template"]`, polluting the DB with template definitions that duplicate the formula files.

## Target State

```
Formula (.formula.json)  → pour/wisp (cook inline) → Mol/Wisp
```

Protos exist only as in-memory data structures during the cook→pour/wisp pipeline. Formula catalog IS the proto library.

## Changes Required

1. **Remove template bead storage** - `bd cook` no longer writes to DB
2. **`bd cook` becomes preview** - outputs proto JSON to stdout (like --dry-run)
3. **`bd pour`/`bd wisp` cook inline** - take formula name, cook on the fly
4. **`bd mol bond` accepts formula names** - cooks inline when bonding templates
5. **Remove `[template]` label handling** - no more template beads
6. **Update docs** - molecular-chemistry.md, molecule-algebra.md

## Benefits

- No DB pollution from template beads
- Single source of truth (formulas in .beads/formulas/)
- Simpler mental model: formulas → instances
- Faster (no DB round-trip for protos)

## Deferred

Staged parameterization (proto currying) - punt until someone needs it:
```bash
bd cook mol-feature --var team=backend  # Partially bound proto
bd pour <proto-id> --var priority=high  # Further binding
```

## Depends On

- gt-8tmz (Molecule Algebra) core work should be mostly complete first

## Context

Discussion: Mayor session 2025-12-25, ultrathink on proto storage

title: Witness MVP: Automated Polecat Lifecycle
description:
Implement the Witness agent - per-rig 'pit boss' that manages polecat lifecycles.

The Witness enables hands-free swarming by automating:
- Spawning polecats for ready work
- Monitoring worker health
- Processing shutdown requests  
- Cleaning up worktrees when done
- Escalating stuck workers to Mayor

Without Witness, humans must manually spawn, monitor, and kill each polecat.

## Core Loop

```
while True:
  # Handle pending shutdowns
  for polecat in polecats where state == pending_shutdown:
    verify git clean
    kill session  
    remove worktree
    delete branch
    
  # Spawn for ready work
  ready = bd ready --parent=<epic> if epic else bd ready
  for issue in ready:
    if active_workers < max_workers:
      gt spawn --issue <id>
      
  # Check worker health
  for polecat in active polecats:
    if stuck (no progress for 30 min):
      nudge or escalate
      
  sleep 60
```

## Blocking Bugs to Fix
- gt-dsfi: handoff deadlock
- gt-n7z7: refinery foreground race condition
- gm-c6b: mail coordination (town vs rig beads)

title: Molecule-based Witness Patrol
description:
Wire up mol-witness-patrol as a tracking ledger for the Go-based witness.

## Key Insight

The molecule is NOT an executor - it's a **tracking structure**. The existing
Go code in internal/witness/manager.go continues to run the patrol loop.
The molecule instance provides visibility, audit trail, and polecat tracking.

## Current State

- Witness runs as Go code with direct patrol logic
- mol-witness-patrol and mol-polecat-arm exist as molecule definitions
- gt mol bond creates dynamic children
- No molecule tracking of actual witness operations

## Target State

1. When witness starts → instantiate mol-witness-patrol on its hook
2. When Go code discovers polecat → bond mol-polecat-arm child
3. When polecat completes/dies → close that arm issue
4. gt mol progress shows current patrol state
5. Molecule survives wisp burns via handoff bead

## Benefits

- Visibility: gt mol status gastown/witness shows active arms
- Audit: Each polecat inspection is a trackable issue
- Consistency: Same tracking model as polecats with molecules
- Progress: gt mol progress works for witness too

## Non-Goals

- NOT replacing Go code with Claude session
- NOT running molecule steps as prompts
- NOT requiring Claude for witness operation

title: mol sling command: attach molecule to agent hook
description:
Add `gt mol sling <molecule-id>` command to attach a molecule to the current agent's hook.

## Behavior

```bash
gt mol sling mol-witness-patrol
```

1. Find agent identity from cwd (witness, polecat, crew, etc.)
2. Find or create agent's handoff bead
3. Attach molecule to handoff bead (attached_molecule field)
4. Create root issue for this molecule instance
5. Instantiate molecule steps under the root

## Difference from mol attach

- `mol attach` attaches to an existing pinned bead
- `mol sling` creates a fresh instance for execution

## Output

```
🧬 Slung mol-witness-patrol on gastown/witness
  Instance: gt-xyz (9 steps)
  First step: inbox-check
```

## Implementation

- Reuse InstantiateMolecule from molecule.go
- Create wrapper issue for the instance
- Set attached_molecule on handoff bead

title: mol progress: track dynamically bonded children
description:
Extend `gt mol progress` to show dynamically bonded children.

## Current Behavior

```
gt mol progress gt-abc
```

Shows progress through pre-defined steps from InstantiateMolecule.

## New Behavior

Also show dynamically bonded children:

```
📊 Progress: mol-witness-patrol (gt-abc)

  Steps (9):
    ✓ inbox-check
    ✓ check-refinery
    ✓ load-state
    ◐ survey-workers (bonded 3 children)
    ○ aggregate (WaitsFor: all-children)
    ○ save-state
    ○ generate-summary
    ○ context-check
    ○ burn-or-loop

  Bonded Children (3):
    ✓ arm-toast (5/5 steps)
    ◐ arm-nux (3/5 steps)
    ○ arm-furiosa (0/5 steps)

  Progress: 4/9 steps, 3 arms (1 complete, 1 in-progress, 1 pending)
```

## Implementation

1. Find children with bonded_to: <parent-id> in description
2. Recursively get progress for each bonded child
3. Aggregate into parent progress display

title: Witness: instantiate mol-witness-patrol on start
description:
When witness starts, create a mol-witness-patrol instance and pin it to the witness hook.

## Changes to witness/manager.go

In Start() or run():
1. Check if patrol instance exists on hook
2. If not, call beads.InstantiateMolecule(mol-witness-patrol, handoffBead)
3. Store instance ID for later reference

## Hook Structure

The witness handoff bead gets:
- attached_molecule: gt-patrol-xyz
- attached_at: timestamp

## Idempotency

If patrol already exists (from previous session), reuse it.
Don't create duplicate instances on restart.

title: Witness: bond mol-polecat-arm when discovering polecat
description:
When witness discovers a polecat during healthCheck(), bond a mol-polecat-arm child.

## Changes to witness/manager.go

In healthCheck() when iterating polecats:
1. Check if arm already exists for this polecat (arm-{name})
2. If not, call: gt mol bond mol-polecat-arm --parent=$PATROL_ID --ref=arm-{name} --var polecat_name={name} --var rig={rig}
3. Track arm issue ID in handoff state

## Arm Lifecycle

- Created when polecat first seen
- Updated as inspection happens (nudges, state changes)
- Closed when polecat cleaned up

## Deduplication

Check handoffState.WorkerStates[name].ArmID before creating.
Needs: gt-59zd.3

title: Witness: close arm when polecat completes
description:
When witness cleans up a polecat, close its mol-polecat-arm issue.

## Changes to witness/manager.go

In cleanupPolecat():
1. Get arm ID from handoffState.WorkerStates[name].ArmID
2. If exists, call: bd close {armID} --reason='polecat cleaned up'
3. Clear ArmID from handoff state

## Arm Close Reasons

- 'polecat cleaned up' - normal completion
- 'polecat killed - stuck' - killed due to inactivity
- 'polecat killed - escalated' - killed after Mayor escalation

## State Update

The arm's description could be updated with final outcome before closing.
Needs: gt-59zd.4

title: Deacon: Hierarchical health-check orchestrator
description:
Replace daemon heartbeats with Deacon - an AI agent that keeps Gas Town running.

## Core Concept

The Deacon is a **Claude agent** (not just a Go process) that:
- Lives at town root in gt-deacon session
- Has its own mailbox (deacon/ identity in town beads)
- Is poked by a minimal Go daemon every ~60s (if idle)
- Monitors Mayor and Witnesses proactively
- Handles lifecycle requests (restart/cycle) from Mayor, Witnesses, AND Crew

## Architecture

```
Minimal Go Daemon (just watches Deacon)
         |
         v
     Deacon (Claude agent)
         |
    +----+----+
    v         v
  Mayor    Witnesses --> Polecats (Witness-managed)
    |         |
    +----+----+
         |
      Crew (lifecycle only, not monitored)
```

## Deacon Responsibilities

**Proactive monitoring:**
- Mayor health (tmux session, keepalive freshness)
- Witness health (tmux sessions, keepalive freshness)

**Reactive lifecycle:**
- Process restart/cycle requests from Mayor, Witnesses, Crew
- Kill session, create new, prime, verify startup

**Escalation:**
- Mail human (configurable) if issues can't be resolved

## Key Files

- ~/gt/DEACON.md - Role context
- ~/gt/deacon/ - State directory
  - heartbeat.json - Written each wake cycle (daemon checks this)
  - state.json - Health tracking, last scan results
- ~/gt/.beads/ - Town beads with deacon/ mail identity

## Wake Cycle

1. Write heartbeat (prevents daemon from poking)
2. Check mail (lifecycle requests)
3. Quick health scan (Mayor, Witnesses)
4. Process lifecycle requests
5. Remediate unhealthy agents
6. Update state

## Session Patterns

- Deacon: gt-deacon
- Mayor: gt-mayor
- Witness: gt-<rig>-witness
- Crew: gt-<rig>-<name> (e.g., gt-gastown-max)

## Relation to Policy Beads

Future: Deacon behavior configurable via policy beads (gt-3zw).
Initial implementation uses sensible defaults.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---
bonded_from: mol-polecat-arm
bonded_to: gt-5glf
bonded_ref: arm-toast
bonded_at: 2025-12-23T10:00:00Z

title: gt mol step done: Auto-continue molecule on step completion
description:
## Summary

Implement `gt mol step done <step-id>` command that enables polecats to close a molecule step and automatically continue to the next step without waiting for witness orchestration.

## Problem

Currently, when a polecat completes a molecule step:
1. Polecat sends POLECAT_DONE to witness
2. Witness (in patrol cycle) eventually reads mail
3. Witness spawns next step
4. **Minutes of latency possible**

Polecats also forget to close beads steps (using internal TodoWrite instead), breaking the activity feed.

## Solution

`gt mol step done <step-id>` handles everything:

1. Close the beads step (`bd close <step-id>`)
2. Extract molecule ID from step (bd-mol-xga.1 → bd-mol-xga)
3. Find next ready step (dependency-aware)
4. If next step exists:
   - Update hook file to point to next step
   - Write handoff context
   - tmux respawn-pane (fresh claude session)
5. If molecule complete:
   - Clear hook
   - Send POLECAT_DONE to witness
   - Exit session

## Key Insight

Step-to-step transitions are **mechanical**, not **cognitive**. No AI needed in the critical path. Pure Go automation.

## Related Commands

- `gt mol next <mol-id>` - Show next ready step(s)
- `gt mol progress <mol-id>` - Already exists

## Polecat Protocol Update

```markdown
When your hook contains a molecule step:
1. Read the step: `bd show <step-id>`
2. Execute the work described
3. When complete: `gt mol step done <step-id>`

That is it. Do NOT manually close steps. Do NOT work multiple steps.
```

## Benefits

- **Instant step transitions** (~5-10s vs minutes)
- **Activity feed works** (steps closed as completed)
- **Witness freed up** (safety net only, not critical path)
- **Fresh context per step** (better attention, no accumulated confusion)

title: Remove legacy .beads-wisp/ infrastructure
description:
The wisp simplification (gt-fgms + bd-bkul) changed wisps to be just a flag on issues in the main .beads/ database. JSONL export filters Wisp=true issues. No separate directory needed.

But legacy .beads-wisp/ infrastructure still exists and should be removed:

## Gas Town (gt) cleanup:
- `internal/rig/manager.go`: Remove `initWispBeads()` call from `AddRig()`
- `internal/wisp/io.go`: Delete entire file (old abstraction layer)
- `internal/cmd/install.go`: Remove any .beads-wisp setup
- `docs/wisp-architecture.md`: Update to reflect 'just a flag' model

## Beads (bd) cleanup:
- `cmd/bd/doctor/wisp_check.go`: Remove WispExistsCheck, WispGitCheck, WispSizeCheck (check .beads-wisp dirs)
- Keep WispOrphansCheck and WispStaleCheck but rewrite to query main DB for Wisp=true issues

## Filesystem cleanup:
- Delete ~/gt/.beads-wisp/
- Delete ~/gt/gastown/.beads-wisp/
- Delete all per-rig .beads-wisp/ directories
- Remove .beads-wisp from .gitignore entries

## Verify:
- `gt mail send --wisp` still works (creates issue with Wisp=true in main DB)
- `bd sync` still filters wisps from JSONL
- `bd mol squash/burn` still work on Wisp=true issues
