title: Patrol step: check parked molecules for unblock
description:
Add patrol step to Deacon for checking parked molecules:

```yaml
- step: check-parked-molecules
  action: |
    For each molecule with:
      - status: in_progress
      - assignee: null
      - has step with external: blocked_by
    Check if external deps are now satisfied.
    If yes: spawn polecat to resume the molecule.
```

This automates the resume process - no manual intervention needed when
upstream dependencies ship.

Part of cross-project dependency system.
See: docs/cross-project-deps.md

title: Update vision.md with proto/mol/wisp terminology
description:
Update the Steam Engine Metaphor section to use consistent phase terminology:

Current (vision.md):
- Proto molecules = fuel (templates)
- Wisps = steam (transient execution traces)  
- Digests = distillate (permanent records)

New terminology:
- **Proto** = crystal/solid - frozen template
- **Mol** = liquid - reified durable instance (tracked in git)
- **Wisp** = gas - ephemeral instance (evaporates after squash)
- **Digest** = distillate - compressed summary after squash

Key clarification needed:
- Proto → bond → creates either Mol (durable) or Wisp (ephemeral)
- The choice of Mol vs Wisp depends on --wisp flag
- Default is Mol (durable, recorded in main beads)
- Wisp lives in .beads-ephemeral/, squashes away

title: Shutdown request handler
description:
Handle polecat shutdown requests:

When polecat runs 'gt handoff --shutdown':
1. Polecat sends mail to <rig>/witness requesting shutdown
2. Witness receives mail
3. Witness verifies:
   - Git working tree is clean
   - Work is submitted (MR exists or in queue)
   - No uncommitted beads changes
4. If clean:
   - gt session stop <rig>/<polecat>
   - git worktree remove polecats/<name>
   - git branch -d polecat/<name>
5. If not clean:
   - Send nudge back to polecat
   - Track retry count

Depends on fixing gt-dsfi (handoff deadlock).

title: Document session cycling protocol in all templates
description:
Add explicit lifecycle request protocol to all agent templates.

## Problem
Templates mention 'request session refresh' but don't show HOW.
Agents don't know the protocol for requesting a cycle.

## Protocol to document
1. Write handoff mail to self (for continuity)
2. Set requesting_cycle=true in state.json
3. Send LIFECYCLE mail to deacon/:
   Subject: 'LIFECYCLE: <role> requesting cycle'
   Body: Reason for cycle request

## Templates to update
- prompts/roles/polecat.md
- prompts/roles/crew.md  
- prompts/roles/witness.md
- prompts/roles/refinery.md

## Also add
- Example state.json location for each role
- When to request cycle (context full, work complete, etc.)
- What happens after (daemon kills, respawns, new session primes)

title: Molecule Phase Terminology Documentation
description:
Document the three-phase molecule lifecycle with consistent terminology:

## The Phases (States of Matter)

| Phase | State | Nature |
|-------|-------|--------|
| **Proto** | Solid/Crystal | Frozen template, static definition in catalog |
| **Mol** | Liquid | Reified instance, malleable, tracked in git (durable) |
| **Wisp** | Gas | Evaporates after squash, ephemeral orchestration |

## Documentation Gaps Identified

### High Priority
1. Update vision.md Steam Engine metaphor to use proto/mol/wisp terminology
2. Add lifecycle diagram: Proto → bond → Mol or Wisp → squash → Digest
3. Document Go types for phases (ProtoMolecule, etc.)
4. Document .beads-ephemeral/ structure and purpose

### Medium Priority
5. Update CLAUDE.md files (polecat, witness, refinery) with molecule workflow
6. Document bd mol bond/squash/burn CLI API with examples
7. Add polecat guide: Executing molecules and generating summaries

### Low Priority
8. Add terminology glossary to architecture.md
9. Create troubleshooting playbook for stuck molecules
10. Add reference diagrams for state transitions

## Current State
- architecture.md has good molecule basics but uses inconsistent terminology
- vision.md has Steam Engine metaphor (proto=fuel, wisp=steam, digest=distillate)
- molecules.md has detailed reference but needs phase clarity
- builtin_molecules.go has 8 molecules but no phase documentation in code

title: Swarm: report generation
description:
Generate markdown reports for completed swarms.

## Command
```
gt swarm report <swarm-id> [--save <file>]
```

## Report Content

### Header
- Swarm ID and title
- Created/completed timestamps
- Duration
- Rig name

### Task Summary
| Task | Assignee | Status | Duration |
|------|----------|--------|----------|
| gt-xxx | Toast | merged | 15m |
| gt-yyy | Nux | merged | 22m |

### Worker Contributions
- Commits per worker
- Issues closed per worker
- Lines changed (optional)

### Timeline
- Chronological events from events.jsonl
- Key milestones (started, first merge, landing)

### Issues Encountered
- Conflicts resolved
- Failed tasks (if any)
- Escalations

## Implementation
```go
func GenerateReport(swarmID string) (*SwarmReport, error)
func (r *SwarmReport) ToMarkdown() string
```

## Storage
- Save to <rig>/.gastown/swarms/<id>/report.md
- Or user-specified path with --save

## PGT Reference
gastown-py/src/gastown/swarm/manager.py generate_report()

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Markdown report generated
- [ ] Includes all sections above
- [ ] Auto-saved to swarm directory
- [ ] --save allows custom path

title: Deacon primes pending workers instead of spawn nudge
description:
## Problem

When gt spawn starts a polecat, it tries to send a nudge message immediately:
1. Starts tmux session with Claude Code
2. Waits 3 seconds (hardcoded)
3. Sends nudge via NudgeSession

But Claude Code takes 10-20+ seconds to be ready. The message arrives before
the prompt is ready, so it appears as part of the prompt string instead of
being executed.

## Solution

Move priming responsibility to the Deacon patrol cycle:

1. gt spawn: Mark polecat as pending_prime=true in state, return immediately
2. Deacon patrol: New step prime-pending-workers that:
   - Scans all rigs for workers with pending_prime=true
   - Uses WaitForClaudeReady() to poll for "> " prompt (already exists in tmux.go)
   - Once ready, sends gt prime + assignment nudge
   - Clears pending_prime flag

## Implementation

### spawn.go changes
- Remove the 3-second sleep (line 368)
- Remove the NudgeSession call (lines 375-383)
- Instead: Update polecat state with pending_prime=true

### Polecat state addition
status: assigned, pending_prime: true, issue: gt-xxx

### Deacon patrol addition
Add step between inbox-check and plugin-run:
prime-pending-workers: Check all rigs for workers marked pending_prime.
For each pending worker: WaitForClaudeReady(60s), then gt prime + nudge

### Benefits
- No race condition - we poll until actually ready
- Deacon already does health checks - priming is natural fit
- Works for polecats, witnesses, refineries, crew (unified approach)
- Timeout handling built in

## Depends on
- Existing WaitForClaudeReady() in tmux.go (lines 384-403)

title: Interrupt vs Queue mail semantics
description:
Add priority/delivery semantics to mail messages.

## Semantics

| Type | Delivery | Use Case |
|------|----------|----------|
| Interrupt | tmux send-keys | Lifecycle, URGENT, stuck detection |
| Queue | Create message only | Normal mail, status, heartbeat |

## Implementation

- `bd mail send --interrupt` uses tmux send-keys notification
- Default is queue (agent checks with `gt mail check`)
- Urgent flag on messages for interrupt delivery

## Agent Side

- `gt mail check --quiet` - non-blocking check for queued mail
- `gt mail wait` - block until mail arrives (for idle agents)
- Heartbeats become queued, agent checks at natural breakpoints

title: Refinery: event-driven merge queue
description:
## Problem
Refinery only acts on explicit requests, no queue management.

## ZFC-Compliant Solution
Add steps to `mol-refinery-patrol.formula.toml`:

```toml
[[step]]
id = "check-merge-requests"
title = "Process merge queue from inbox"
description = """
1. Check inbox for MERGE_READY messages: gt mail inbox
2. For each merge request:
   - Read branch name from message
   - Add to local queue (track in state.json or temp file)
3. Process queue in order:
   - git fetch origin
   - git checkout main && git pull
   - git merge --no-ff origin/polecat/<name>
   - If conflict: mail Mayor with details, skip
   - If success: git push && delete remote branch
4. For each merged branch:
   - gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "MERGED: polecat/<name>" -m "Branch merged successfully"
   - Delete the MERGE_READY mail
"""
depends_on = ["inbox-check"]
```

## Queue State
Refinery agent tracks queue in `state.json`:
```json
{
  "merge_queue": ["polecat/foo", "polecat/bar"],
  "last_merged": "polecat/baz"
}
```

## Why This Works
- Refinery Claude agent runs formula
- Agent handles conflicts with judgment
- Mail is coordination primitive
- State persists in agent's state.json

## Files
- formulas/mol-refinery-patrol.formula.toml

title: Polecat mood command and status line display
description:
CLI and status line support for polecat mood.

## CLI Command
```
gt polecat mood <name> <emoji>   # Set mood
gt polecat mood <name>           # Get mood
```

Sets GT_MOOD environment variable in the polecat's tmux session.

## Status Line Integration
Update runWorkerStatusLine() to read mood:
```go
mood, _ := t.GetEnvironment(session, "GT_MOOD")
if mood != "" {
    icon = mood  // Use mood emoji instead of default
} else {
    icon = AgentTypeIcons[AgentPolecat]  // Fallback to 😺
}
```

## Storage
Mood stored in tmux session environment (ephemeral, per-session).
No persistence needed - mood is reassessed each patrol cycle.

Depends on: gt-u818 (plugin system)

title: Patrols: Cyclic molecules for autonomous maintenance
description:
## Vision

Patrols are **cyclic molecules** - workflow loops that give Gas Town its autonomous nervous system. While regular molecules are DAGs that terminate, patrols loop forever, performing maintenance tasks at varying cadences.

This is the "steam engine" of Gas Town: converting episodic Claude sessions into continuous autonomous operation.

## Core Concepts

### 1. Cyclic Molecules

Regular molecule:     A -> B -> C -> done
Patrol molecule:      A -> B -> C --+
                      ^             |
                      +-------------+

Patrols have a loop_to field specifying where to restart.

### 2. Cooldown-Aware Steps (Atoms)

Steps encode their own cadence. When patrol reaches a step:
1. Check: now - last_run > cooldown?
2. If yes: execute, update last_run
3. If no: skip (immediately close)

The patrol runner is simple - steps self-skip. Complexity distributed into atoms.

### 3. The Beacon

The heartbeat that fires patrol triggers:
- Internal ticker in Deacon (goroutine)
- Or external cron firing gt deacon tick
- Or mail-based triggers

Without beacon, nothing proactive happens.

### 4. Session Reset as Patrol Step

Connects to auto-handoff (gt-bcwn). Session reset is a patrol step, not a separate mechanism.

### 5. Multi-Role Patrols

Each supervisor has its own patrol:

**Deacon patrol:** health-check (30s), session-gc (5m), beacon-tick (10s)
**Witness patrol:** orphan-scan (10m), stuck-check (2m), molecule-progress (1m)
**Refinery patrol:** queue-check (30s), pr-status (1m), merge-ready (30s)

### 6. Cadence Tiers

- Critical (10-30s): Health checks
- Active (1-5m): Progress, nudges
- Maintenance (10-30m): Orphans, GC
- Periodic (1h+): Reports

### 7. Best-Effort Scheduling

Not real-time - more like cron. No hard deadlines. Catch-up, dont pile-up.
Priority preemption (mail interrupts patrol). Graceful degradation under load.

## Open Questions

1. State persistence: Beads (self-describing) or file (faster)?
2. Interruption: How does urgent mail preempt patrol?
3. Error recovery: Backoff? Escalate? Circuit breaker?
4. Coordination: Can patrols send mail to trigger other patrols?

## Related

- gt-bcwn: Auto-handoff (session reset is a patrol step)
- Molecule system (patrols extend molecules with loops)
- Deacon lifecycle management

## Metaphor

Claude was fire. Claude Code was steam. Gas Town is the steam engine. Beads is the train tracks.

The steam engine converts episodic combustion into continuous rotary motion.
Gas Town converts episodic Claude sessions into continuous autonomous work.

title: Fix failing beads tests: TestIntegration and TestPolecatWorkMolecule
Create mol-refinery-patrol with test failure gates
description:
## Problem

The Refinery role lacks:
1. A formal patrol molecule (Deacon has mol-deacon-patrol)
2. Engineer identity/philosophy guidance
3. Structural enforcement of failure handling (not just documentation)

When tests fail during merge processing, the current guidance doesn't prevent 'disavowal' - noting a problem exists and proceeding without tracking it.

## The Structural Solution

Create `mol-refinery-patrol` with **verification gates** that make disavowal structurally impossible:

```markdown
## Molecule: mol-refinery-patrol

## Step: inbox-check
Check mail for MR submissions, escalations, messages.
Process any urgent items first.

## Step: queue-scan
Fetch remote, identify polecat branches waiting.
If queue empty, skip to context-check.
Track branch list for this cycle.
Needs: inbox-check

## Step: process-branch
Pick next branch. Rebase on current main.
If rebase conflicts: notify polecat, skip to next branch.
Needs: queue-scan

## Step: run-tests
Run go test ./...
Track results (pass/fail count).
Needs: process-branch

## Step: handle-failures
**GATE**: If tests passed, this step auto-completes.
If tests failed:
- Diagnose: branch regression or pre-existing?
- Branch regression → abort, notify polecat
- Pre-existing → EITHER fix OR \`bd create --type=bug\`
**VERIFY**: Fix committed OR bead filed before proceeding.
Needs: run-tests

## Step: merge-push
Merge to main (ff-only preferred).
Push immediately.
Delete polecat branch.
Needs: handle-failures

## Step: loop-check
More branches? Return to process-branch.
Otherwise continue to summary.
Needs: merge-push

## Step: generate-summary
Summarize cycle: branches processed, tests results, issues filed.
Needs: loop-check

## Step: context-check
Check context usage.
If high: write handoff, prepare for burn/respawn.
Needs: generate-summary

## Step: burn-or-loop
If context LOW and queue non-empty: loop (return to queue-scan)
If context HIGH or queue empty: burn and exit
Needs: context-check
```

## Implementation Tasks

### 1. Add RefineryPatrolMolecule() to builtin_molecules.go
- Copy pattern from DeaconPatrolMolecule
- Include all steps with proper `Needs:` dependencies
- Emphasize handle-failures gate in description

### 2. Update Refinery CLAUDE.md
Add sections:
- **The Engineer Mindset** (identity/philosophy)
- **The Scotty Test** (Would Scotty walk past this?)
- **Patrol Molecule** reference (mol-refinery-patrol)
- **Test Failure Protocol** (explicit decision tree)

### 3. Create prompts/roles/refinery.md
- Follow pattern of deacon.md
- Include patrol execution loop diagram
- Reference the molecule

### 4. Consider mol-witness-patrol
- Witness has detailed heartbeat protocol but no formal molecule
- Similar pattern could apply

## Why This Matters

GUPP: 'If you have work on your hook, you have to run it.'
The patrol molecule puts failure handling ON THE HOOK as a mandatory step.
You can't skip handle-failures to get to merge-push.
The structure enforces good behavior.

## Related
- gt-7919: Fix failing beads tests (discovered during this session)
- mol-deacon-patrol (existing pattern to follow)
- docs/molecular-chemistry.md (chemistry concepts)
- docs/wisp-architecture.md (wisp vs mol decision)

title: Dynamic wisp modification: insert, reorder, bond mid-execution
description:
## Vision

Wisps should be living documents that adapt mid-execution, not static scripts.

## Operations Needed

### bd mol insert
Insert a step into a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol insert <wisp-id> --after <step> --step 'security-gate: Review auth changes'
```

### bd mol reorder  
Change step order in a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol reorder <wisp-id> --move process-branch --before current
```

### bd mol bond (to wisp)
Attach an entire molecule to a running wisp:
```bash
bd mol bond mol-weekly-maintenance <wisp-id> --after await-work
```

### bd mol skip
Skip a step (with reason):
```bash
bd mol skip <wisp-id> <step> --reason 'Queue empty, skipping summary'
```

## Use Cases

1. **Hotfix priority**: Reorder queue to process urgent MR first
2. **Security gate**: Insert review step when PR touches sensitive files
3. **Scheduled maintenance**: Bond maintenance mol on schedule
4. **Context adaptation**: Skip steps when they don't apply

## Why This Matters

Engine room problems emerge dynamically. The wisp's flexibility lets agents model situations as they evolve, not execute rigid scripts.

GUPP still applies: whatever's on your hook, you run. But the hook contents can adapt.

## Implementation

This requires Beads changes to support wisp mutation:
- Track step ordering in wisp storage
- Support step insertion/deletion/reordering
- Handle bond-to-wisp (spawn steps into existing wisp)
- Preserve audit trail of modifications

title: gt rig add / gt doctor: patrol awareness and wiring
description:
## Problem

When a rig is installed or audited, we need to ensure all built-in patrols and role hooks are properly wired up.

## gt rig add Changes

When adding a rig, automatically:

1. **Create patrol molecules** for each role:
   - mol-deacon-patrol (town-level)
   - mol-witness-patrol (per-rig)
   - mol-refinery-patrol (per-rig)

2. **Set up hooks** that trigger patrols:
   - Deacon: daemon timer / heartbeat
   - Witness: daemon timer / polecat lifecycle events
   - Refinery: MR submission events / daemon timer

3. **Configure daemon** to manage these patrols:
   - Register patrol molecules in daemon config
   - Set up respawn behavior for each role

4. **Create plugin directories**:
   - ~/gt/plugins/ (town-level)
   - <rig>/plugins/ (rig-level, if needed)

## gt doctor Changes

Add patrol health checks:

### patrol-molecules-exist
- Verify mol-deacon-patrol, mol-witness-patrol, mol-refinery-patrol exist
- Check they parse correctly (valid steps, dependencies)

### patrol-hooks-wired
- Verify hooks trigger patrol execution
- Check daemon is configured to manage patrols

### patrol-not-stuck
- Detect wisps that have been in-progress too long
- Flag orphaned patrol molecules (no active session)

### patrol-plugins-accessible
- Verify plugin directories exist and are readable
- Check plugin frontmatter parses correctly

### patrol-roles-have-prompts
- Verify prompts/roles/*.md exist for each role
- Check they reference the correct patrol molecule

## Auto-fix

gt doctor --fix can:
- Create missing patrol molecules
- Wire up missing hooks
- Create plugin directories
- NOT restart stuck patrols (needs human decision)

## Related
- gt-7920 (mol-refinery-patrol)
- gt-7921 (await-work and plugin-run)
- docs/wisp-architecture.md

title: Ephemeral polecats: spawn fresh, delete on completion
description:
## Design Decision

Switch from pooled/idle polecats to ephemeral model:
- Spawn creates fresh worktree from main
- Polecat requests shutdown when done (bottom-up)
- Witness verifies handoff, kills session, deletes worktree
- No 'idle' state - polecats exist only while working

## Rationale

1. **Git worktrees are fast** - pooling optimization is obsolete
2. **Pooling creates maintenance burden:**
   - Git stashes accumulate
   - Untracked artifacts pile up
   - Branches drift from main
   - Beads DB gets stale
3. **PGT sync problems** came from persistent branches
4. **Support infrastructure exists** - Witness, Refinery, Mayor handle continuity
5. **Simpler mental model** - polecat exists = work in progress

## Lifecycle

```
Spawn:
  gt spawn --issue <id>
  → Creates fresh worktree: git worktree add polecats/<name> -b polecat/<name>
  → Initializes beads in worktree
  → Starts session, assigns work

Working:
  Polecat does task
  → Pushes to polecat/<name> branch
  → Submits to merge queue when ready

Completion (POLECAT-INITIATED):
  Polecat runs: gt handoff
  → Verifies git state clean
  → Sends mail to Witness: "Ready for shutdown"
  → Marks itself done, waits for termination

Cleanup (WITNESS-OWNED):
  Witness receives shutdown request
  → Verifies PR merged or in queue
  → Verifies no uncommitted changes
  → Kills session: gt session stop <rig>/<polecat>
  → Deletes worktree: git worktree remove polecats/<name>
  → Deletes branch: git branch -d polecat/<name>
  → Optionally: Notifies Mayor of completion
```

## Key Insight: Bottom-Up Shutdown

**Old model (wrong)**: Top-down batch shutdown - "cancel the swarm"
**New model (right)**: Bottom-up individual shutdown - polecat requests, Witness executes

This enables streaming:
- Workers come and go continuously
- No "swarm end" to trigger cleanup
- Each worker manages its own lifecycle
- Witness is the lifecycle authority

## Implementation

1. Add `gt handoff` command for polecats to request shutdown
2. Modify gt spawn to always create fresh worktree
3. Run bd init in new worktree (beads needs initialization)
4. Add shutdown request handler to Witness
5. Witness verifies handoff, then cleans up:
   - Kill session
   - Remove worktree
   - Delete branch
6. Remove 'idle' state from polecat state machine
7. Simplify gt polecat list (only shows active)

## Impact on Other Tasks

- gt-17r (Zombie cleanup): Becomes trivial - orphan worktrees
- gt-4my (Worker health): Simpler - no idle/stuck ambiguity
- gt-f9x.5/f9x.6 (Doctor): Fewer states to validate
- gt-eu9 (Witness handoff): Witness receives polecat shutdown requests

title: gt mail send should tmux-notify recipient
description:
## Problem

When mail is sent via gt mail send, the recipient session does not get a tmux notification. In Python Gas Town (PGT), mail delivery triggers a tmux display-message or similar notification so the agent knows mail arrived.

## Expected Behavior

When gt mail send <addr> is called:
1. Mail is delivered to recipient inbox
2. If recipient has an active tmux session, send notification
3. Notification should be visible (display-message or bell)

## Current Behavior

Mail is delivered but no notification. Agent has to poll inbox to discover new mail.

## Impact

- Agents miss time-sensitive messages
- Heartbeat pokes from daemon will not wake agents
- Coordination is slower (polling vs push)

## Implementation Notes

After successful mail delivery, check if recipient has active session:
- gt session list can identify active sessions
- tmux display-message or send-keys can notify
- Could inject a visible prompt like "[MAIL] New message from <sender>"

## Reference

Check PGT implementation for how it handles this.

title: gt mail: Cross-level routing is broken
description:
**Problem:**
When Mayor (at ~/gt) sends mail to a rig worker (gastown/crew/max), the message lands in town-level beads (~/.beads/) but the recipient checks rig-level beads (crew/max/.beads/).

**Reproduction:**
```bash
cd ~/gt
gt mail send gastown/crew/max -s 'Test' -m 'body'
# Message goes to ~/gt/.beads/ with prefix hq-*

cd ~/gt/gastown/crew/max  
gt mail inbox
# Does NOT see the message - it's looking in crew/max/.beads/
```

**Root cause:**
`findBeadsWorkDir()` walks up from CWD to find .beads. `Router.Send()` runs `bd create` in that directory. This means messages always go to the sender's beads, not the recipient's.

**Fix options:**
1. Route based on recipient address - if sending to rig/*, use that rig's .beads
2. Use a single shared beads database for all mail (simpler but less isolated)
3. Teach agents to check both levels (workaround, not fix)

**Related:**
- gt-ngu1: Pinned beads sorting (done but pointless if mail doesn't route)
- This blocks all cross-level mail functionality

title: Swarms of One: Lightweight single-worker task dispatch
description:
Design and implement a lightweight pattern for firing off single workers to handle tasks without full swarm overhead.

## Context

Currently we have:
- town spawn: Creates a polecat in a rig with issue assignment
- Swarms (sw-*): Full lifecycle tracking with manifest, state, events, reports
- Ephemeral rigs (rig-*): Temporary worker groups for swarms

What's missing: A simple way to say 'fire off a worker to do X' without swarm ceremony.

## Design Questions

1. Should this be a new command like 'gt fire' or an option on existing commands?
2. Should single tasks still get swarm IDs (sw-N) for consistency/queryability?
3. Should it default to creating new workers or support --reuse for idle polecats?
4. How does this relate to crew workers (gt-cik)?

## Possible Interface

gt fire --rig gastown --issue gt-xyz [--prompt '...']
gt fire gastown/QuickTask --issue gt-xyz

## Related

- gt-cik: Overseer Crew (user-managed persistent workspaces)
- gt-kmn: Swarm System epic

title: Bug: MRs appearing in bd ready output
description:
merge-request beads are showing up in `bd ready` output alongside actual work items.

## Problem
`bd ready` is meant to show work available for polecats to claim. MRs are internal workflow items processed by the Refinery, not polecat work.

## Example
```
| P1 | merge-request | bd-3zzh | Merge: bd-tvu3 |
| P1 | merge-request | bd-fcl1 | Merge: bd-au0.5 |
```

## Possible Fixes
1. **Filter by type** - `bd ready` excludes type=merge-request, type=gate, type=molecule
2. **Set assignee on submit** - MR assigned to refinery/ when created, so not 'unassigned'
3. **Set status=in_progress** - MR starts in_progress since it's queued for processing

## Related
- gate beads also showing (bd-hyp6, bd-wu62) - same issue

title: Design: Swarm shutdown and worker cleanup
description:
Design for graceful swarm shutdown, worker cleanup, and session cycling.

## Key Decisions

1. Pre-kill verification uses model intelligence (not framework rules)
2. Witness can request restart when context filling (mail self, exit)
3. Mayor NOT involved in per-worker cleanup (Witness responsibility)
4. Clear responsibility boundaries between Mayor/Witness/Polecat

## Subtasks (implementation)

- gt-sd6: Polecat decommission checklist prompting
- gt-f8v: Witness pre-kill verification protocol
- gt-eu9: Witness session cycling and handoff
- gt-gl2: Mayor vs Witness cleanup responsibilities

**Design complete.** Each subtask has full specification in its description.

title: mol-witness-patrol molecule definition
description:
Create mol-witness-patrol in builtin_molecules.go.

## Steps (10 total)
1. inbox-check - Process witness mail (lifecycle, help requests)
2. load-state - Read handoff bead, get nudge counts
3. survey-workers - gt polecat list, categorize by status
4. inspect-workers - tmux capture-pane for each 'working' polecat
5. decide-actions - Apply nudge matrix, queue actions
6. execute-actions - Nudge, kill, or escalate as decided
7. save-state - Update handoff bead with new states
8. generate-summary - Summarize cycle for digest
9. context-check - Check own context usage
10. burn-or-loop - Squash wisp, then loop or cycle session

## Key Behaviors
- Uses wisp storage (.beads-wisp/)
- Reads/writes witness handoff bead for state persistence
- Progressive nudging (3 levels before escalate)
- Pre-kill verification before killing polecats

## Reference
- See prompts/roles/witness.md for protocol details
- See mol-refinery-patrol for similar structure
- Parent epic: gt-aqd8

title: mol-witness-patrol
description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop using the Christmas Ornament pattern.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

## The Christmas Ornament Shape

This molecule uses dynamic bonding to create inspection arms per-polecat:

```
                    ★ mol-witness-patrol (trunk)
                   /|\
            ┌─────┘ │ └─────┐
         PREFLIGHT DISCOVERY CLEANUP
            │       │        │
        ┌───┴───┐ ┌─┴─┐  ┌───┴───┐
        │inbox  │ │sur│  │aggreg │
        │refnry │ │vey│  │save   │
        │load   │ └─┬─┘  │summary│
        └───────┘   │    │contxt │
                    │    │loop   │
          ┌─────────┼─────────┐ └───────┘
          │         │         │
          ●         ●         ●     mol-polecat-arm (dynamic)
         ace       nux      toast
          │         │         │
       ┌──┴──┐   ┌──┴──┐   ┌──┴──┐
       │cap  │   │cap  │   │cap  │
       │ass  │   │ass  │   │ass  │
       │dec  │   │dec  │   │dec  │
       │exec │   │exec │   │exec │
       └──┬──┘   └──┬──┘   └──┬──┘
          │         │         │
          └─────────┴─────────┘
                    │
                 ⬣ base (cleanup)
```

## Phases

### PREFLIGHT (fixed steps)
1. inbox-check - Process lifecycle requests, help messages
2. check-refinery - Ensure MQ is alive and processing
3. load-state - Read persistent state (nudge counts, etc.)

### DISCOVERY (spawns dynamic arms)
4. survey-workers - List polecats, bond mol-polecat-arm per polecat
5. run-plugins - Bond mol-plugin-runner for each witness plugin

### CLEANUP (gate + fixed steps)
6. aggregate - GATE: WaitsFor all arms + plugins to complete
7. save-state - Persist nudge counts, action log
8. generate-summary - Create digest content
9. context-check - Check if context is high
10. burn-or-loop - Squash/burn wisp, then loop or exit

## Dynamic Arms

Each polecat gets mol-polecat-arm bonded as a wisp child:
- capture - Capture tmux output
- assess - Categorize state (working/idle/error/done)
- load-history - Get nudge counts for this polecat
- decide - Apply nudge matrix
- execute - Take action (nudge/kill/escalate/none)

Arms run in PARALLEL. The aggregate step waits for all to complete.

## Activity Feed

This design enables real-time visibility:

```
[14:32:08] + patrol-x7k.arm-ace bonded (5 steps)
[14:32:09] → patrol-x7k.arm-ace.capture in_progress
[14:32:10] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace.capture completed
[14:32:14] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace.decide completed (action: nudge-1)
[14:32:17] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace COMPLETE
```

## Storage

- Wisp storage: .beads-wisp/ (ephemeral, gitignored)
- Persistent state: witness handoff bead (nudge counts, etc.)
- Digests: Squashed summaries in permanent beads

## Dependencies

- bd-xo1o: Dynamic Molecule Bonding epic (in beads rig)
  - bd mol bond with variable substitution
  - WaitsFor directive for fanout gates
  - Activity feed query

title: Adaptive backoff for daemon heartbeat
description:
Track agent responsiveness and adjust heartbeat frequency.

## Per-Agent State

```go
type AgentBackoff struct {
    BaseInterval    time.Duration  // 60s default
    CurrentInterval time.Duration  // grows when busy
    MaxInterval     time.Duration  // 10min cap
    ConsecutiveMiss int            // pokes with no response
}
```

## Strategy Options

- **Fixed**: Always 60s (current, simple)
- **Geometric**: 60s → 90s → 135s → 202s (factor 1.5)
- **Exponential**: 60s → 120s → 240s (factor 2, aggressive)

## Recovery

When agent responds (runs a command):
- Reset ConsecutiveMiss to 0
- Return to BaseInterval immediately

## Benefits

- Reduces noise for busy agents
- Saves resources during quiet periods
- Still catches stuck agents (max interval cap)

title: Add role-specific subcommands that delegate to core commands (agent UX)
description:
## Problem

Agents naturally guess command patterns like:
- `gt witness nudge <polecat>`
- `gt polecat nudge <name>`
- `gt crew restart <member>`

But these don't exist - the actual commands are:
- `gt nudge <session> <message>`
- `gt polecat reset <name>`

This creates friction in agent UX. Agents shouldn't have to memorize the 'correct' command structure.

## Proposal

Add subcommands to each role that delegate to core commands with argument reordering:

```
gt witness nudge furiosa "Start working"
  → gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Start working"

gt polecat nudge gastown/furiosa "Check mail"
  → gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Check mail"

gt crew nudge gastown/max "Wake up"
  → gt nudge gt-crew-gastown-max "Wake up"
```

## Benefits

1. **Discoverable**: Agents explore `gt witness --help` and find nudge
2. **Lenient**: Multiple valid ways to express the same intent
3. **Role-contextual**: Commands under the role namespace feel natural
4. **Extensible**: Pattern works for future subcommands (status, reset, etc.)

## Implementation

Each role command (witness, polecat, crew, refinery) gets thin wrapper subcommands:

```go
// In witness.go
witnessCmd.AddCommand(&cobra.Command{
    Use:   "nudge <polecat> <message>",
    Short: "Nudge a polecat (delegates to gt nudge)",
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        session := formatSession(rig, args[0])
        return runNudge(session, args[1])
    },
})
```

## Future Candidates

Other subcommands to add as role-specific aliases:
- `gt polecat status <name>` (already exists, good pattern)
- `gt witness check <polecat>` → trigger a manual check
- `gt refinery merge <mr-id>` → process specific MR
- `gt crew send <member> <message>` → mail to crew member

title: gt mail send: --priority flag should work like bd mail send
description:
UX inconsistency: gt mail send passes flags that bd mail send doesn't support.

## Root Cause

router.go line 42 passes `--priority` to bd:
```go
args = append(args, "--priority", fmt.Sprintf("%d", beadsPriority))
```

But `bd mail send` only has `--urgent` (boolean), not `--priority`.

## Fix Options

1. Add `--priority` flag to `bd mail send` (preferred - more expressive)
2. Change router to only use `--urgent` when priority=0

## Also Affected

- `--type` flag (line 46) - bd mail send doesn't have this
- `--thread-id` flag (line 51) - bd mail send doesn't have this  
- `--reply-to` flag (line 56) - bd mail send doesn't have this

The router assumes bd mail send has features it doesn't have.

title: Town Doctor molecule for harness health checks
description:
Create a Town Doctor molecule that any Gas Town agent can run to diagnose and repair harness issues.

## Concept

Instead of just `gt doctor` as a CLI command with hardcoded checks, create a **molecule** (checklist workflow) that:
- Any agent (Mayor, Witness, Polecat) can instantiate
- Walks the agent through diagnostic steps
- Agent uses judgment to fix issues found
- Works as a structured troubleshooting guide

## Why a Molecule?

1. **Agent-driven**: The agent running it becomes "the doctor" temporarily
2. **Extensible**: Add new checks by updating the molecule, not code
3. **Contextual**: Agent can reason about issues, not just run scripts
4. **Self-healing**: Agent can fix problems it finds, not just report them

## Proposed Checks (molecule steps)

1. Verify harness structure (mayor/, .beads/, CLAUDE.md exist)
2. Validate config files (town.json, rigs.json parse correctly)
3. Check beads health (bd doctor, redirect validity)
4. Verify git state (clean working tree, proper remotes)
5. Check rig integrity (each registered rig exists, has config.json)
6. Validate agent clones (mayor/rig/, refinery/rig/ exist and are valid)
7. Check for orphaned worktrees/branches
8. Verify daemon state (if running)

## Integration

- `gt doctor` could instantiate the molecule for the current agent
- Or agent can run `bd ready` and pick up doctor tasks when prioritized
- Results logged to beads for audit trail

## Related

- gt-cr9: Harness Design & Documentation (completed)
- Molecules design in architecture.md

title: Molecule Algebra: Work Composition DSL
description:
Implement the molecule algebra - a declarative language for composing, transforming, and executing structured work. Enables mechanical composition without AI.

The Three Phases: Rig → Cook → Run

- **Rig**: Source-level composition (formula YAML with extends/compose)
- **Cook**: Instantiation (formula → proto → mol/wisp)
- **Run**: Execution (agents complete steps)

Two Composition Operators:
- **Rig** operates on formulas (source level)
- **Bond** operates on artifacts (protos, mols, wisps)

Key components:
- Formulas: YAML source with composition rules (.formula.yaml)
- Cook: Pre-expand macros/aspects to flat proto
- Phase verbs (pour, wisp)
- Bond: Artifact-level polymorphic composition
- Composition operators (sequence, parallel, branch, loop, gate)
- Advice operators (before, after, around - Lisp style)
- Expansion operators (macros like Rule of Five)
- Aspects (AOP cross-cutting concerns)

See docs/rig-cook-run.md for the lifecycle spec.
See docs/molecule-algebra.md for full algebra specification.
Example formulas in .beads/formulas/

title: Phase verbs: pour and wisp commands
description:
Implement the phase transition verbs:
- bd pour <proto> - instantiate as persistent mol
- bd wisp <proto> - instantiate as ephemeral wisp
- Update bd mol bond to inherit phase from target

These replace the current --wisp flag with cleaner verb semantics.

title: Rename Engineer in Box to Shiny
description:
Rename mol-engineer-in-box to mol-shiny (or just 'shiny').

Mad Max reference - the canonical 'right way to engineer'.
Update all references in docs and code.

title: Rule of Five expansion template
description:
Create rule-of-five as an expansion template:
- Jeffrey's discovery: agents converge in 4-5 iterations
- Template expands any step into 5-pass refinement
- draft → refine-1 → refine-2 → refine-3 → refine-4

First example of a macro-style expansion proto.

title: Formula parser and YAML schema
description:
Implement formula parsing from YAML:
- Define YAML schema for .formula.yaml files
- Parse steps, compose rules, vars
- Support extends for formula inheritance
- Validate formula structure

Schema should support:
- formula: name
- description: text
- version: number
- type: workflow|expansion|aspect
- vars: variable definitions
- steps: step definitions
- compose: composition rules

**Beads issue: bd-weu8**

title: bd cook command: Formula to Proto
description:
Implement the 'bd cook' command that transforms formulas into protos.

Usage: bd cook <formula-file> [options]
       bd cook .beads/formulas/*.formula.yaml

Process:
1. Parse formula YAML (uses formula parser)
2. Resolve extends (formula inheritance)
3. Expand macros (expansion rules)
4. Apply aspects (cross-cutting concerns)
5. Generate flat proto bead

Output:
- Creates proto bead in .beads/ with mol-prefix
- Proto has all steps pre-expanded
- Proto is ready for pour/wisp instantiation

**Beads issue: bd-wa2l**

title: bd formula list/show commands
description:
Implement formula management commands:

  bd formula list
  # Lists formulas from all search paths

  bd formula show rule-of-five
  # Shows formula details, steps, compose rules

Search paths (in order):
1. .beads/formulas/ (project)
2. ~/gt/.beads/formulas/ (town)
3. ~/.beads/formulas/ (user)
4. Built-in formulas (embedded)

title: Formula cycle detection during cooking
description: Detect and error on circular extends chains during bd cook. E.g., if formula A extends B extends A, cooking should fail with clear error message pointing to the cycle.

title: Prevent aspect self-matching (infinite recursion)
description: Aspects should only match original steps, not steps inserted by the same aspect application. Document this and implement guard during cooking. Without this, a pointcut like *.implement that inserts security-prescan could match its own insertion infinitely.

title: Max expansion depth limit (default 5)
description: Add maxExpansionDepth config (default 5) to prevent runaway nested expansions. This still allows massive work generation but with a safety bound. Note: distinguish compile-time cooking (produces proto with placeholders) vs runtime cooking (produces mol with real issue IDs). Compile-time is for modeling/estimation/contractor handoff.

title: Cooking metadata: source tracing
description: Add source_formula and source_location metadata to cooked steps so you can trace a step in a proto back to its origin formula. Useful for debugging complex compositions.

title: Meta-formulas: formula generators
description: Support meta-formulas that generate multiple formulas from a template. Example: multi-lang-shiny that generates shiny-go, shiny-python, shiny-typescript from a for-each loop over languages. Enables DRY formula libraries.

title: Advice operators: before, after, around
description:
Implement Lisp-style advice operators for molecules:
- before(target, step) - insert step before target
- after(target, step) - insert step after target
- around(target, wrapper) - wrap target with before/after

Support glob patterns for targeting (*.implement, shiny.*, etc).

title: Formula inheritance trees for organizational policies
description: Support organizational formula hierarchies where teams extend a company-base-formula. Each team can add required aspects (accessibility audit for frontend, SQL injection scan for backend). Enables policy enforcement across an organization.

title: Conditional aspects (feature flags)
description: Apply aspects conditionally based on environment or config. Example: apply security-audit only when env.SECURITY_SCANNING == enabled. Adds 'when' clause to aspect composition.

title: Review dimensions as aspects
description: Refactor code-review molecule to use aspects for each review dimension (security, performance, accessibility). More flexible than current pluggable molecule approach - add/remove checks by composing aspects.

title: Compile-time vs runtime cooking
description: Distinguish two cooking modes: 1) Compile-time: produces proto with variable placeholders, for modeling/estimation/contractor handoff. 2) Runtime: produces mol with real issue IDs. Compile-time lets you pre-decompose work for untrusted executors or planning purposes.

title: Document Rig/Cook/Run lifecycle
description: The rig-cook-run.md spec is written. Propagate terminology to all relevant docs: - molecule-algebra.md (done) - molecular-chemistry.md (done) - vision.md (done) - propulsion-principle.md - sling-design.md - Any agent templates that reference cooking/instantiation

title: Implement bd bond command for artifact-level composition
description:
Implement the artifact-level bond operator distinct from source-level rigging.

Bond accepts:
- Formula names (cooks inline to ephemeral proto, then bonds)
- Mol IDs (existing liquid work)
- Wisp IDs (existing vapor work)

See molecular-chemistry.md for the full bond table semantics.

**Updated 2025-12-25**: With ephemeral protos (gt-4v1eo), bond takes formula names directly and cooks inline. No pre-cooked proto beads.

title: Direct formula-to-wisp instantiation (skip proto)
description:
For massive ephemeral workflows (e.g., million-step Towers of Hanoi), allow:

bd wisp towers-of-hanoi --var disks=20

This would cook + wisp in one step, never materializing the proto. Useful when:
- The proto would be huge (1M+ steps)
- The work is ephemeral (wisp, not mol)
- You don't need the intermediate artifact

Implementation: streaming cook that emits directly to wisp storage.

Related: towers-of-hanoi.formula.yaml demonstrates the use case.

title: Computed range expansion (for-each over expressions)
description:
Support for-each expansion over computed ranges, not just static lists:

for-each:
  var: move_num
  range: "1..2^{disks}"  # Computed at cook time

This enables formulas like Towers of Hanoi where the step count is a function of input variables. The range expression is evaluated during cooking.

Related: towers-of-hanoi.formula.yaml demonstrates the need.
Depends on: gt-8tmz.8 (Runtime dynamic expansion)

title: Expansion operators: expand and map (macros)
description:
Implement macro-style expansion operators:
- expand(target, template) - apply template to single step
- map(molecule, template) - apply template to all matching steps

Templates use {target} substitution for step references.
Rule of Five is the canonical example.

title: Consolidate molecular-chemistry.md with rig-cook-run.md
description:
Merge rig-cook-run.md into molecular-chemistry.md as the canonical chemical algebra spec:
- Rig/Cook/Run as the lifecycle backbone
- Full generation graph: Formula → Compound Formula → Proto → Mol/Wisp
- Bond table at artifact level (symmetric)
- Rig operator at source level
- Unified vocabulary
- Archive or redirect rig-cook-run.md

title: Map expansion should match nested child steps
Expansion var overrides not implemented
description:
ExpandRule.Vars field exists in schema but is ignored during expansion.

## Current State

The vars map in expand rules should override the expansion formula default variables, but currently the Vars field is not used.

## Implementation

1. In ApplyExpansions, pass rule.Vars to expandStep
2. Merge vars with formula defaults (rule.Vars wins)
3. Substitute vars in template placeholders
4. Add test: expansion with var overrides

## Files

- internal/formula/expand.go: ApplyExpansions, expandStep
- internal/formula/expand_test.go: add test case

title: Inline step expansion (Step.Expand field)
description:
Step.Expand and Step.ExpandVars fields exist in schema but are not implemented.

## Current State

Steps can declare inline expansion:

    steps:
      - id: design
        expand: rule-of-five
        expand_vars:
          iterations: 3

This is more convenient than compose.expand for single-step expansions.

## Difference from compose.expand

- compose.expand: Centralized, applies after all steps parsed
- Step.Expand: Inline, step declares its own expansion

## Implementation

1. During cooking, detect steps with Expand field
2. Load referenced expansion formula
3. Replace step with expanded template (like compose.expand)
4. Pass ExpandVars as variable overrides
5. Handle recursion depth (reuse DefaultMaxExpansionDepth)

## Files

- internal/formula/types.go: Step.Expand, Step.ExpandVars (already defined)
- internal/formula/expand.go: Add inline expansion handling
- internal/formula/expand_test.go: Add test cases

## Depends On

- gt-8tmz.34 (var overrides) should be done first

title: Validate expanded step IDs are unique
Fanout gate: waits-for children aggregation
description:
Formalize the fanout gate pattern where a step waits for all dynamically-bonded children.

## Current State

Formulas already use this pattern informally:

    step: aggregate
    waits_for: "all-children"

But it is not in the algebra spec or implemented in the cooker.

## Proposed Syntax

    step: aggregate
    needs: [survey-workers]
    waits-for: children-of(survey-workers)

Or simpler:

    step: aggregate
    needs: [survey-workers]
    waits-for: all-children

## Semantics

- Step cannot start until ALL children of the referenced step have completed
- Children are dynamically bonded via for-each (gt-8tmz.8)
- This is the "aggregation" half of the Christmas Ornament pattern
- If no children were bonded, the gate passes immediately

## Use Cases

**Witness Patrol:**
- survey-workers bonds N polecat-arms
- aggregate waits for all arms to complete
- Then proceeds to save-state

**Refinery Patrol:**
- Less common (sequential processing), but useful for parallel test runs

## Relationship to gate

This is a variant of gate where the condition is "all children complete" rather than
an arbitrary expression. Could be implemented as:

    gate:
      condition: "children-of(survey-workers).all(status == complete)"

But dedicated syntax is cleaner for this common pattern.

## Dependencies

- Depends on gt-8tmz.8 (for-each creates the children)
- Depends on gt-8tmz.4 (gate infrastructure)

title: Control flow: loop, gate, branch
description:
Implement control flow operators for the molecule algebra.

## Core Operators

| Operator | Syntax | Purpose |
|----------|--------|---------|
| loop (fixed) | loop: { count: N, body: [steps] } | Fixed iteration |
| loop (conditional) | loop: { until: COND, max: N, body: [steps] } | Bounded conditional iteration |
| gate | gate: { before: step, condition: COND } | Wait for condition before proceeding |
| branch | branch: { from: step, steps: [a,b,c], join: step } | Parallel paths that rejoin |

Conditions evaluated mechanically (step status, output fields) per gt-8tmz.7.

## Design Review (2025-12-25)

Analyzed patrol patterns (witness, deacon, refinery) to verify these constructs
can express real Gas Town workflows. Key findings:

### Insight: Patrol Loop is OUTSIDE the Algebra

The daemon respawns patrols. Each formula describes ONE cycle. This means:
- Formulas don't need "infinite loop with burn-and-respawn"
- loop is only for **inner loops** (refinery's per-branch processing)
- "burn-or-loop" = complete cycle; daemon decides next action
- Context cycling is external, not algebraic

This significantly simplifies the algebra.

### Gap: for-each is Missing

The current proposal doesn't include for-each, but it's essential for patrol patterns:

| Pattern | Use Case |
|---------|----------|
| Witness survey-workers | For each polecat, bond an arm (parallel) |
| Refinery process-branch | For each branch in queue, run merge pipeline (sequential) |
| Deacon plugin-run | For each plugin where gate open, execute |

Proposed syntax:

    for-each:
      collection: "survey-workers.output.polecats"
      bond: mol-polecat-arm
      vars:
        polecat_name: "{item.name}"
      parallel: true

This overlaps with gt-8tmz.8 (runtime dynamic expansion). Decision needed:
- Include for-each here as control flow, OR
- Ensure gt-8tmz.8 covers these patterns adequately

### Gap: waits-for Gate Variant

The "fanout gate" pattern (aggregate waits for all dynamically-bonded children)
needs formalization:

    step: aggregate
    waits-for: children-of(survey-workers)

Currently exists in formulas as waits_for: "all-children" but not in the algebra spec.

### What This Covers

With these operators (plus for-each), patrols become fully expressible:

**Witness Patrol:**
- for-each polecat -> bond mol-polecat-arm (parallel)
- gate with waits-for: all-children for aggregation

**Refinery Patrol:**
- for-each branch -> process pipeline (sequential)
- gate for test verification before merge

**Deacon Patrol:**
- for-each plugin -> execute if gate open
- Simple sequence otherwise

### Scope Decision

**Option A**: Implement loop, gate, branch now. Track for-each and waits-for separately.

**Option B**: Expand scope to include for-each and waits-for formalization.

Recommendation: Option A - implement core constructs, create child issues for gaps.

title: Aspects: AOP cross-cutting concerns
description:
Implement aspect-oriented composition:
- Define aspects with pointcuts and advice
- Apply aspects at bond time: bd bond mol --with-aspect security
- Pointcuts use glob patterns to match join points

Enables security-audit, logging, etc. as reusable concerns.

title: Selection operators: glob, filter, children
description:
Implement selection operators for targeting:
- step(id) - specific step
- glob(pattern) - pattern match (*.implement)
- filter(predicate) - status/output predicates
- children(step), descendants(step) - tree traversal

Used by advice, expansion, and aspects for targeting.

title: Condition evaluator for gates and loops
description:
Implement mechanical condition evaluation:
- step.status == 'complete'
- step.output.field == value
- children(step).all(status == 'complete')
- file.exists(path), env.VAR

Keep decidable: no arbitrary code, bounded evaluation.

title: Runtime dynamic expansion (for-each)
description:
Implement runtime expansion for discovered work (the for-each construct).

## Syntax

    step: survey-workers
    on-complete:
      for-each: output.polecats
      bond: mol-polecat-arm
      vars:
        polecat_name: "{item.name}"
        rig: "{item.rig}"
      parallel: true  # or sequential: true

## Design Context (from gt-8tmz.4 review)

This is **control flow**, not just expansion. It affects execution order:
- for-each with parallel: true = concurrent child execution
- for-each with sequential: true = ordered child execution

Key patrol patterns that require this:

| Pattern | Use Case |
|---------|----------|
| Witness survey-workers | For each polecat, bond an arm (parallel) |
| Refinery process-branch | For each branch in queue, run merge pipeline (sequential) |
| Deacon plugin-run | For each plugin where gate open, execute |

## Relationship to gt-8tmz.4

gt-8tmz.4 implements loop, gate, branch (static control flow).
This issue implements for-each (dynamic control flow over runtime-discovered collections).

Together they cover the full control flow needs for patrol formulas.

## Implementation Notes

- Bonds N instances based on step output
- Christmas Ornament pattern: fanout from single step to N parallel children
- Pairs with waits-for gate (gt-8tmz.38) for aggregation
- Collection must be iterable (array in step output)
- Each iteration gets item, index, and parent context in vars

title: gt sling --on flag for wisp scaffolding
description:
Add --on flag to gt sling for applying forms to existing work:
  gt sling shiny gastown/Toast --on gt-abc123

When --on is specified, implies --wisp (scaffolding existing work).
The form shapes execution of the target bead.

title: Daemon: integration test with real lifecycle
description:
Need an end-to-end test that:
1. Starts daemon
2. Starts a test agent session
3. Sends lifecycle request to daemon
4. Verifies session was killed and restarted
5. Cleans up

title: Molecule execution support for polecats and crew
description:
Enable agents to run bonded molecules through the full lifecycle.

## The Model
1. BOND - bd mol bond <template> --assignee <identity>
   Creates concrete issues, assigns root to agent

2. DISCOVER - Agent finds assigned molecules via bd ready
   DAG structure shows unblocked steps

3. WORK - Agent works through DAG, closing steps as done
   Can delegate children to lower-tier agents (haiku)

4. SURVIVE - Agent dies → beads persist
   Any agent resumes from DAG state

5. SUPERVISE - Witness monitors for stalled molecules
   Nudges owner or reassigns if dead

## Questions to Resolve
- Seed node terminology: seed vs root vs pole vs nucleus
- Assignee inheritance: single owner vs delegation model
- Stall detection: heartbeat vs activity timeout vs session monitoring

## Implementation
- Polecat startup: check for assigned molecules
- Polecat work loop: follow molecule DAG
- Witness: monitor molecule progress, detect stalls
- Mayor: can assign molecules, handle escalations

## Depends On
- beads: bd mol bond command (bd-usro in beads repo)

title: gt daemon: Background service management
description:
## Summary

ONE daemon for all Gas Town - a simple Go process (not a Claude agent) that:
1. Pokes agents periodically (heartbeat)
2. Processes lifecycle requests
3. Restarts sessions when agents request cycling

## Architecture

Daemon (gt daemon)
- Pokes Mayor: "HEARTBEAT: check your rigs"
- Pokes each Witness: "HEARTBEAT: check your workers"
- Has inbox at daemon/ for lifecycle requests
- Restarts sessions on cycle requests

## NOT the daemon's job:
- Making decisions (Witnesses do that)
- Running Claude (it's a Go process)
- Processing work (polecats do that)
- Direct polecat management (Witnesses do that)

The daemon is a **dumb scheduler** - poke things, execute lifecycle requests. All intelligence is in agents.

## Commands

- gt daemon start: Start daemon (background)
- gt daemon stop: Stop daemon
- gt daemon status: Show daemon status
- gt daemon logs: View daemon logs

## Daemon Loop

Every heartbeat interval:
1. Poke Mayor
2. For each rig: Poke Witness
3. Process lifecycle requests from daemon/ inbox
4. Check for dead sessions, restart if cycle requested

## Lifecycle Request Handling

Daemon checks its inbox (daemon/) for lifecycle requests:
- From Mayor: cycle/restart Mayor session
- From Witnesses: cycle/restart Witness session

On request:
1. Verify agent state shows requesting_cycle
2. Kill session
3. Start new session
4. Clear requesting_cycle flag

## Poke Protocol

Poke = tmux inject "HEARTBEAT: do your job"
- Agent ignores if already working
- Agent wakes up if idle
- Idempotent - multiple pokes are fine

## Lifecycle Hierarchy

- Daemon manages: Mayor, all Witnesses
- Witness manages: Polecats, Refinery (per rig)
- Crew: self-managed (human workspace)

## Related Issues

- gt-kmn.11: Daemon heartbeat details
- gt-gby: gt handoff command (unified lifecycle)
- gt-u1j.9: Fold witness daemon into this

title: Federation: Wasteland architecture for cross-town coordination
description:
## Overview

Federation enables Gas Town to scale across machines via **Outposts** - remote compute environments that can run workers.

**Design doc**: docs/federation-design.md

## Outpost Types

| Type | Description | Cost Model |
|------|-------------|------------|
| Local | Current model (tmux panes) | Free |
| SSH/VM | Full Gas Town clone on VM | Always-on |
| CloudRun | Container workers on GCP | Pay-per-use |

## Key Concepts

### Outpost Abstraction
```go
type Outpost interface {
    Name() string
    Type() OutpostType  // local, ssh, cloudrun
    MaxWorkers() int
    Spawn(issue string, config WorkerConfig) (Worker, error)
    Workers() []Worker
    Ping() error
}
```

### Cloud Run Workers
- Persistent HTTP/2 connections solve zero-to-one cold start
- Pay only when working (~$0.017 per 5-min session)
- Scale 0→N automatically
- Git clone via persistent volumes

### SSH/VM Outposts  
- Full Gas Town clone on remote machine
- SSH for commands, git for sync
- Good for long-running autonomous work

## Design Principles

1. **Outpost abstraction** - support multiple backends
2. **Local-first** - remote is for overflow/burst
3. **Git as source of truth** - code and beads sync everywhere
4. **HTTP for Cloud Run** - dont force mail onto containers
5. **Graceful degradation** - works with any subset of outposts

## Related

- gt-f9x.7-10: Connection interface (lower-level abstraction)
- docs/federation-design.md: Full architectural analysis

title: Outpost/Worker interfaces: Core abstractions for remote compute
description:
## Overview

Define the core interfaces that all outpost types implement.

## Interfaces

```go
type OutpostType string
const (
    OutpostLocal    OutpostType = "local"
    OutpostSSH      OutpostType = "ssh"
    OutpostCloudRun OutpostType = "cloudrun"
)

type Outpost interface {
    Name() string
    Type() OutpostType
    MaxWorkers() int
    ActiveWorkers() int
    Spawn(issue string, config WorkerConfig) (Worker, error)
    Workers() []Worker
    Ping() error
    SendMail(worker string, msg Message) error  // optional
}

type Worker interface {
    ID() string
    Outpost() string
    Status() WorkerStatus  // idle, working, done, failed
    Issue() string
    Attach() error         // for interactive outposts
    Logs() (io.Reader, error)
    Stop() error
}

type WorkerConfig struct {
    RigPath    string
    BeadsDir   string
    GitBranch  string
    Context    map[string]string  // hints for worker
}
```

## Files

- `internal/outpost/outpost.go` - Outpost interface
- `internal/outpost/worker.go` - Worker interface
- `internal/outpost/config.go` - WorkerConfig, OutpostType

## Notes

This is the foundation for all federation work. Keep interfaces minimal - we can extend later.

title: VM outpost setup: Terraform and documentation
description:
## Overview

Documentation and optional Terraform for setting up VM outposts.

## Manual Setup Guide

```markdown
# Setting Up a VM Outpost

## Prerequisites
- GCE VM (or any Linux machine with SSH access)
- SSH key pair
- Git configured on VM

## Steps

1. Install Claude Code on VM:
   ```bash
   ssh user@vm
   npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
   ```

2. Clone Gas Town:
   ```bash
   mkdir -p ~/ai
   cd ~/ai
   gt install .
   ```

3. Configure Git credentials:
   ```bash
   git config --global user.name "Your Name"
   git config --global credential.helper store
   ```

4. Add outpost to local config:
   ```bash
   gt outpost add ssh \
     --name gce-burst \
     --host 10.0.0.5 \
     --user steve \
     --key ~/.ssh/gce_worker \
     --town-path /home/steve/ai \
     --max-workers 8
   ```

5. Test connectivity:
   ```bash
   gt outpost ping gce-burst
   ```
```

## Terraform Module (Optional)

```hcl
# deploy/terraform/vm-outpost/main.tf

variable "project" {}
variable "zone" { default = "us-central1-a" }
variable "machine_type" { default = "e2-standard-4" }

resource "google_compute_instance" "outpost" {
  name         = "gastown-outpost"
  machine_type = var.machine_type
  zone         = var.zone

  boot_disk {
    initialize_params {
      image = "ubuntu-2204-lts"
      size  = 100
    }
  }

  network_interface {
    network = "default"
    access_config {}
  }

  metadata_startup_script = file("${path.module}/startup.sh")
}

output "external_ip" {
  value = google_compute_instance.outpost.network_interface[0].access_config[0].nat_ip
}
```

## Files

- `docs/vm-outpost-setup.md`
- `deploy/terraform/vm-outpost/` (optional)

Depends on: gt-9a2.5 (SSHOutpost)

title: HTTP work server: gt worker serve command
HTTP work client: CloudRun dispatch client
CloudRun persistent connections: HTTP/2 keepalive
CloudRun cost tracking: Usage monitoring and limits
description:
## Overview

Track Cloud Run usage costs and enforce spending limits.

## Cost Model

Cloud Run pricing (approximate):
- CPU: ~$0.000024/vCPU-second
- Memory: ~$0.0000025/GiB-second
- Requests: ~$0.40/million

For 5-minute worker (2 vCPU, 4GB):
- CPU: 300 × 2 × $0.000024 = $0.0144
- Memory: 300 × 4 × $0.0000025 = $0.003
- **Total: ~$0.017 per session**

## Implementation

```go
type CostTracker struct {
    cpuRate    float64  // per vCPU-second
    memRate    float64  // per GiB-second
    sessions   []SessionCost
    mu         sync.RWMutex
}

type SessionCost struct {
    WorkerID  string
    StartTime time.Time
    EndTime   time.Time
    CPUs      float64
    MemoryGiB float64
}

func (t *CostTracker) RecordSession(workerID string, start, end time.Time, cpus, mem float64) {
    t.mu.Lock()
    defer t.mu.Unlock()
    t.sessions = append(t.sessions, SessionCost{...})
}

func (t *CostTracker) CurrentCost() float64 {
    t.mu.RLock()
    defer t.mu.RUnlock()
    var total float64
    for _, s := range t.sessions {
        duration := s.EndTime.Sub(s.StartTime).Seconds()
        total += duration * s.CPUs * t.cpuRate
        total += duration * s.MemoryGiB * t.memRate
    }
    return total
}
```

## Cost Cap Enforcement

```go
func (o *CloudRunOutpost) Spawn(...) (Worker, error) {
    if o.costCap > 0 && o.costTracker.CurrentCost() >= o.costCap {
        return nil, ErrCostCapExceeded
    }
    // ... spawn worker
}
```

## Config

```yaml
outposts:
  - name: cloudrun-burst
    type: cloudrun
    cost_cap_hourly: 5.00   # Stop spawning if hourly cost exceeds $5
    cost_cap_daily: 50.00   # Daily limit
```

## CLI

```bash
gt outpost status cloudrun-burst
# Shows: Cost (today): $0.42 / $50.00 cap
```

## Files

- `internal/cloudrun/cost.go`

## Dependencies

Depends on: gt-9a2.8 (basic CloudRunOutpost)

CloudRun worker container: Dockerfile and entrypoint
description:
## Overview

Docker container image for Cloud Run workers.

## Dockerfile

```dockerfile
FROM golang:1.21-alpine AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY . .
RUN go build -o gt ./cmd/gt

FROM ubuntu:22.04

# Install Claude Code
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y     curl git nodejs npm     && npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code     && apt-get clean

# Install gt
COPY --from=builder /app/gt /usr/local/bin/gt

# Worker entrypoint
COPY deploy/cloudrun/entrypoint.sh /entrypoint.sh
RUN chmod +x /entrypoint.sh

EXPOSE 8080
ENTRYPOINT ["/entrypoint.sh"]
```

## Entrypoint

```bash
#!/bin/bash
git config --global user.name "$GIT_USER"
git config --global user.email "$GIT_EMAIL"
exec gt worker serve --port 8080
```

- `deploy/cloudrun/README.md`

title: CloudRun protocol types: WorkRequest, WorkEvent, WorkResult
description:
## Overview

HTTP protocol types for Cloud Run work dispatch. **Types only** - server and client are separate tasks.

## Request Type

```go
type WorkRequest struct {
    IssueID string          `json:"issue_id"`
    Rig     RigConfig       `json:"rig"`
    Beads   BeadsConfig     `json:"beads"`
    Branch  string          `json:"worker_branch"`
    Context map[string]any  `json:"context,omitempty"`
}

type RigConfig struct {
    URL    string `json:"url"`
    Branch string `json:"branch"`
}

type BeadsConfig struct {
    URL    string `json:"url"`
    Branch string `json:"branch"`
}
```

## Response Types (streaming NDJSON)

```go
type WorkEvent struct {
    Type     string `json:"type"`  // status, log, progress, result, error
    Status   string `json:"status,omitempty"`
    Line     string `json:"line,omitempty"`
    Percent  int    `json:"percent,omitempty"`
    Branch   string `json:"branch,omitempty"`
    PRURL    string `json:"pr_url,omitempty"`
    Code     string `json:"code,omitempty"`
    Message  string `json:"message,omitempty"`
}

type WorkResult struct {
    Status  string `json:"status"`  // done, failed
    Branch  string `json:"branch"`
    PRURL   string `json:"pr_url,omitempty"`
    Error   string `json:"error,omitempty"`
}
```

## Files

- `internal/cloudrun/protocol.go` - All types above

## Notes

This is just types. Server (gt-9a2.7b) and client (gt-9a2.7c) are separate tasks.
Small, focused task - can complete quickly.

title: CloudRunOutpost: Basic implementation
description:
## Overview

Basic CloudRunOutpost implementation. Persistent connections and cost tracking are separate tasks.

## Implementation

```go
type CloudRunOutpost struct {
    name        string
    project     string
    region      string
    service     string
    maxWorkers  int
    client      *WorkClient
    workers     map[string]*CloudRunWorker
    mu          sync.RWMutex
}

func NewCloudRunOutpost(cfg OutpostConfig) (*CloudRunOutpost, error) {
    serviceURL := fmt.Sprintf(
        "https://%s-%s.a.run.app",
        cfg.Service, cfg.Region,
    )
    return &CloudRunOutpost{
        name:       cfg.Name,
        project:    cfg.Project,
        region:     cfg.Region,
        service:    cfg.Service,
        maxWorkers: cfg.MaxWorkers,
        client:     NewWorkClient(serviceURL),
        workers:    make(map[string]*CloudRunWorker),
    }, nil
}
```

## Spawn

```go
func (o *CloudRunOutpost) Spawn(issue string, cfg WorkerConfig) (Worker, error) {
    req := WorkRequest{
        IssueID: issue,
        Rig:     RigConfig{URL: cfg.RigURL, Branch: cfg.GitBranch},
        Beads:   BeadsConfig{URL: cfg.BeadsURL, Branch: "beads-sync"},
        Branch:  "polecat/" + issue,
    }
    
    events, err := o.client.DispatchWork(context.Background(), req)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    
    worker := &CloudRunWorker{
        id:      uuid.New().String(),
        outpost: o.name,
        issue:   issue,
        events:  events,
        status:  WorkerStatusWorking,
    }
    
    o.mu.Lock()
    o.workers[worker.id] = worker
    o.mu.Unlock()
    
    go worker.monitor()
    return worker, nil
}
```

## CloudRunWorker

```go
type CloudRunWorker struct {
    id      string
    outpost string
    issue   string
    status  WorkerStatus
    events  <-chan WorkEvent
    logs    []string
}

func (w *CloudRunWorker) Attach() error {
    return errors.New("Cloud Run workers do not support attach")
}

func (w *CloudRunWorker) Logs() (io.Reader, error) {
    return strings.NewReader(strings.Join(w.logs, "\n")), nil
}
```

## Files

- `internal/outpost/cloudrun.go`

## Dependencies

Depends on: gt-9a2.1 (interfaces), gt-9a2.12 (HTTP client)
Blocks: gt-9a2.13 (persistent connections), gt-9a2.14 (cost tracking)

title: Polecat wisp architecture: Proto → Wisp → Mol pattern
description:
Design the three-layer architecture for polecat lifecycle:

## The Insight

Polecats should run a ONE-SHOT WISP (not looping like patrols):

**Step 1: Onboard**
- Read full polecat protocol (polecat.md template)
- Learn Gas Town operation, exit strategies, molecule protocol
- This is the 'how to be a polecat' education

**Step 2: Execute Mol**
- Run the assigned molecule (the actual work item)
- Could span multiple sessions via session continuity
- The mol is pure work content (epic, issue, feature)

**Step 3: Cleanup**
- Run final step of the wisp
- Self-delete / request shutdown

## Three Layers

- **Proto**: polecat.md template (instructions for being a polecat)
- **Wisp**: One-shot harness instantiated from proto (wraps the mol)
- **Mol**: The work item (issue/epic being processed)

## Why This Matters

1. **Separation of concerns**: Protocol (how) vs Work (what)
2. **Reusability**: Same wisp harness wraps any mol
3. **Extensibility**: Plugin points for custom behavior
4. **Session continuity**: Wisp handles multi-session, not the mol
5. **Blurred control/data planes**: Intentional in Gas Town

## Design Questions

1. How does proto (polecat.md) become a wisp instance?
2. What are the plugin/extension points?
3. Should all 'engineer in a box' mols use proto → wisp → mol?
4. How does this relate to refinery/deacon patterns?

title: gt spawn should create fresh polecat worktree, never reuse
description:
Currently gt spawn tries to reuse existing polecats, which causes:

1. Stale beads database
2. Stale code (behind main/integration)
3. Old inbox messages
4. Git history pollution

## Current Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Looks for idle polecat in pool
2. If found, reuses existing worktree
3. Assigns new issue

## Desired Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Always create FRESH polecat from current main/integration
2. Fresh worktree with clean beads
3. No reuse of old worktrees

## Name Pool Still Useful

Keep name pool for:
- Allocating themed names (mad-max, etc.)
- Tracking which names are in use

But worktrees should be created fresh each time.

## Implementation

In spawn.go, before starting work:
1. If worktree exists: remove it first
2. Create fresh worktree from integration branch
3. Sync beads from rig to polecat
4. Then proceed with work assignment

This ensures polecats always start with latest code and beads.

title: Deacon tmux status bar: heartbeat timing and patrol state
description:
## Problem

The deacon shows patrol output but lacks real-time observability:
- No indication of when last heartbeat occurred
- No indication of when next heartbeat is scheduled
- No visibility into current patrol step

## Desired Behavior

The tmux status bar for gt-deacon should show:

```
⛪ Deacon | ❤️ 2m ago | ⏰ 3m | 📍 health-scan (3/7)
```

Components:
- **Role icon**: ⛪ (deacon identity)
- **Last heartbeat**: ❤️ 2m ago (time since last heartbeat file update)
- **Next heartbeat**: ⏰ 3m (time until daemon would poke)
- **Current step**: 📍 health-scan (3/7) (current patrol atom, step N of M)

## Implementation

1. **Read heartbeat.json** for last update time
2. **Calculate next poke** based on daemon interval (default 5m)
3. **Read current wisp** from .beads-wisp/ to get patrol progress
4. **Update tmux status** periodically or on state change

Options:
- tmux status-right with shell script
- gt deacon status --tmux for formatted output
- Hook into patrol step completion

## Related

- gt-id36: Deacon Kernel epic
- gt-3x0z: Wisp Molecule Integration

title: Mol Mall: Molecule marketplace distribution
description:
Design the Mol Mall distribution mechanism for sharing molecules.

## Core Insight

Mol Mall is just a registry of molecules.jsonl fragments. No special format needed.

## Distribution Model

```
Mol Mall (registry)
    │
    │ bd mol search "security"
    ▼
Molecule catalog (searchable index)
    │
    │ bd mol install mol-security-scan
    ▼
Download molecules.jsonl fragment
    │
    │ Append to ~/.beads/molecules.jsonl
    ▼
Available locally: bd mol list
```

## Registry Format

Simple JSON index served from HTTPS:

```json
{
  "molecules": [
    {
      "id": "mol-security-scan",
      "title": "Security Scan",
      "description": "OWASP Top 10 vulnerability checker",
      "labels": ["plugin", "code-review", "tier:sonnet"],
      "author": "anthropic",
      "version": "1.0.0",
      "url": "https://mol-mall.anthropic.com/molecules/mol-security-scan.jsonl"
    }
  ]
}
```

## CLI Commands

```bash
bd mol search <query>           # Search registry
bd mol info <id>                # Show molecule details
bd mol install <id>             # Download and install
bd mol uninstall <id>           # Remove from catalog
bd mol update                   # Update all installed molecules
```

## Installation Locations

```
~/.beads/molecules.jsonl        # User-level (default install location)
~/gt/.beads/molecules.jsonl     # Town-level (shared across rigs)
.beads/molecules.jsonl          # Project-level (team-specific)
```

## Version Management

Molecules can have versions via labels: `version:1.0.0`
Install specific version: `bd mol install mol-security-scan@1.0.0`

## Auth (Future)

Private registries could require auth token.
Enterprise Mol Malls for internal distribution.

## Related

- gt-u818: Plugin System (plugins ARE molecules)
- molecular-chemistry.md: Format documentation

title: Daemon must delete LIFECYCLE messages after processing
description:
## Problem

Crew workers were being killed every 5 minutes.

## Root Cause

Old stale LIFECYCLE messages from days ago were sitting in the deacon's inbox. The daemon's ProcessLifecycleRequests() was re-finding and re-processing them every 5-minute heartbeat cycle.

The closeMessage() function in lifecycle.go calls 'gt mail delete' but failures are silent - the message stays in the inbox and gets reprocessed on the next heartbeat.

## Fix Required

1. Ensure closeMessage() actually deletes the message
2. If delete fails, log the error AND mark the message as read so it's not reprocessed
3. Consider adding a 'processed' label or moving to a processed folder

## Files

- internal/daemon/lifecycle.go: closeMessage() function
- internal/daemon/lifecycle.go: ProcessLifecycleRequests() loop

Add molecule execution guidance to polecat context:

## What to Add

### Molecule Awareness

- The work assignment mail includes molecule context
- Current step is tracked in the wisp

### Workflow Protocol
1. Read assignment (includes molecule ID and current step)
2. Execute current step
3. Update step status via bd mol step
4. Generate summary when all steps complete
5. Run bd mol squash to compress wisp into digest

### Key Commands
- bd mol show <wisp-id> - view current molecule state
- bd mol step <wisp-id> --status=complete - mark step done
- bd mol squash <wisp-id> --summary='...' - complete molecule

- Lists what was accomplished
- Notes any deviations from the plan
- Captures key decisions made
- This becomes the permanent digest

title: Refinery background daemon mode
description:
Refinery currently only works in foreground mode. Background daemon is stubbed.

## Current State
manager.go line 128-129:
```go
// Background mode: spawn a new process
// For MVP, we just mark as running - actual daemon implementation in gt-ov2
return nil
```

## Requirements

### 1. Background Process Spawning
```go
func (m *Manager) Start(foreground bool) error {
    if !foreground {
        // Spawn gt refinery start --foreground as subprocess
        cmd := exec.Command(os.Args[0], "refinery", "start", m.rig.Name, "--foreground")
        cmd.Start()  // Don't wait
        // Record PID
    }
}
```

### 2. PID File Management
- Write PID to .gastown/refinery.pid
- Check PID validity on status
- Clean up stale PID files

### 3. Log Output
- Redirect stdout/stderr to .gastown/refinery.log
- Log rotation (optional for MVP)

### 4. Graceful Shutdown
- Handle SIGTERM/SIGINT
- Complete current merge before exit
- Update state to stopped

### 5. Health Check
- Process existence check via kill -0
- Optional: heartbeat file with timestamp

## Files to Modify
- internal/refinery/manager.go: Start(), Status(), process spawning

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] gt refinery start <rig> spawns background process
- [ ] gt refinery status shows running with PID
- [ ] gt refinery stop sends SIGTERM and waits
- [ ] Logs written to .gastown/refinery.log
- [ ] Survives terminal close

title: gt sling: use mail queue for patrol roles (witness, refinery, deacon)
description:
When slinging work to patrol agents, queue via mail instead of replacing hook.

**Rationale:**
Patrol agents run continuous loops. Replacing their hook with discrete work breaks patrol continuity - when the task completes, the patrol stops.

**New behavior for patrol roles (witness, refinery, deacon):**
1. Check if patrol is running (hook has patrol molecule attached)
2. If patrol running:
   - Don't touch hook (patrol stays pinned)
   - Send work assignment mail
   - Print 'Queued for next patrol cycle'
3. If patrol NOT running:
   - Start default patrol for that role (mol-witness-patrol, mol-refinery-patrol, mol-deacon-patrol)
   - Send work assignment mail
   - Print 'Started patrol and queued work'

**New flags:**
- --urgent: Interrupt current patrol cycle, process this work immediately
- --replace: Explicitly terminate patrol and pin discrete work (break-glass)

**No change for:**
- Polecat, Crew, Mayor (discrete task agents - current behavior)

**Dependencies:**
- Patrol templates must have 'check inbox' step (verify/add)
- Need to know default patrol molecule for each role

title: gt sling: auto-sync beads in new polecat worktrees
description:
## Problem
`gt sling <bead> <rig>` could fail to pin because polecat worktree branches persisted and diverged from current state.

## Root Cause
- Polecat branches (`polecat/<name>`) were reused across runs
- Stale branches could diverge from main and beads-sync
- Branch reuse logic was complex with fallback behavior

## Solution Implemented
**Fresh unique branches per polecat run**

Instead of syncing beads (Options A/B/C), we changed the branch model:

1. **Unique timestamped branches**: Each polecat run creates `polecat/<name>-<timestamp>`
2. **No branch reuse**: Each spawn starts fresh from current HEAD
3. **Simplified code**: Removed branch existence checks and reset logic
4. **Garbage collection**: Added `gt polecat gc <rig>` to clean up old branches

### Why This Works
- Polecats already use beads redirect (`../../mayor/rig/.beads`)
- Mayor's beads are authoritative - polecats read from there
- Fresh branches ensure clean starting state
- Old branches are ephemeral (never pushed to origin)

### Files Changed
- `internal/polecat/manager.go`: Add/Recreate/CleanupStaleBranches
- `internal/git/git.go`: ListBranches helper
- `internal/cmd/polecat.go`: `gt polecat gc` command

### Commands Added
```
gt polecat gc <rig>           # Clean up stale branches
gt polecat gc <rig> --dry-run # Show what would be deleted
```

title: Polecats should not bd sync on startup
description:
Polecats all share the same beads database at the rig level. The refinery and mayor/witness manage syncing beads.

## Current Behavior
Polecat startup runs bd sync, causing:
- Contention when multiple polecats spawn simultaneously
- Unnecessary sync operations
- Potential race conditions

## Desired Behavior
- Polecats should NOT run bd sync on startup
- They read from the shared beads database
- Only refinery/witness/mayor sync beads

## Implementation
Remove bd sync from polecat spawn/startup sequence.
