title: Port Gas Town to Go
description:
Complete rewrite of Gas Town in Go for improved performance and single-binary distribution.

## Goals
- Single installable binary (gt)
- All Python functionality ported
- Federation support built-in
- Improved performance

## Phases
1. Core infrastructure (config, workspace, git wrapper)
2. Rig & polecat management
3. Session & tmux operations
4. Mail system
5. CLI commands
6. TUI (optional)

title: Go scaffolding: cmd/gt, go.mod, Cobra setup
description:
Set up Go project structure with CLI framework.

**Stack:**
- Cobra for command/flag handling
- Lipgloss for styled terminal output

**Deliverables:**
- cmd/gt/main.go with Cobra root command
- Basic subcommands: version, help
- Lipgloss styles for status output (success, warning, error)
- go.mod with dependencies

title: CLI: core commands (status, prime, version, init)
description:
Essential CLI commands for Gas Town operation.

## Commands

### gt status
Show overall town status.
```
gt status [--json]
```
Output:
- Town name and location
- Number of rigs
- Active polecats across all rigs
- Witness status per rig
- Recent activity summary

### gt prime
Output role context for current directory.
```
gt prime
```
Detects role from directory:
- Town root or mayor/ → Mayor context
- <rig>/witness/rig/ → Witness context
- <rig>/refinery/rig/ → Refinery context
- <rig>/polecats/<name>/ → Polecat context

### gt version
Show version information.
```
gt version [--short]
```
Output: version, git commit, build date.

### gt init
Initialize current rig for Gas Town (alternative to gt install for existing repos).
```
gt init [--force]
```
Creates Gas Town structure in existing git repo.

## Implementation

Each command is a Cobra subcommand under root:
```go
var statusCmd = &cobra.Command{...}
var primeCmd = &cobra.Command{...}
var versionCmd = &cobra.Command{...}
var initCmd = &cobra.Command{...}
```

Register in cmd/gt/main.go.

title: CLI: session commands (start, stop, at, list, capture, inject)
description:
Session management CLI commands.

## Commands

### gt session start
Start a polecat session.
```
gt session start <rig>/<polecat> [--issue <id>]
```
- Creates tmux session
- Launches claude in polecat workdir
- Optionally injects initial issue context

### gt session stop
Stop a polecat session.
```
gt session stop <rig>/<polecat> [--force]
```
- Graceful shutdown by default
- --force kills immediately

### gt session at (attach)
Attach to running session.
```
gt session at <rig>/<polecat>
```
- Attaches tmux session to current terminal
- Detach with Ctrl-B D

### gt session list
List all sessions.
```
gt session list [--rig <rig>] [--json]
```
- Shows running/stopped status
- Optionally filter by rig

### gt session capture
Capture recent output from session.
```
gt session capture <rig>/<polecat> [--lines <n>]
```
- Default: last 100 lines
- Useful for checking polecat progress

### gt session inject
Send message to session.
```
gt session inject <rig>/<polecat> -m "message"
gt session inject <rig>/<polecat> -f <file>
```
- Injects text via tmux send-keys
- Used for nudges, notifications

## Address Format

`<rig>/<polecat>` e.g., `wyvern/Toast`

## Implementation

Session subcommand group:
```go
var sessionCmd = &cobra.Command{Use: "session"}
sessionCmd.AddCommand(startCmd, stopCmd, atCmd, listCmd, captureCmd, injectCmd)
```

title: CLI: mail commands (send, inbox, read)
description:
CLI: mail commands wrapping bd mail.

## Status

Current implementation works with JSONL files. Refactor to wrap bd mail CLI.

## Commands

### gt mail inbox
```
gt mail inbox [--unread] [--json]
```
Wraps: `bd mail inbox [--json]`

### gt mail read
```
gt mail read <id>
```
Wraps: `bd mail read <id> && bd mail ack <id>`
Note: bd mail read + ack marks as read.

### gt mail send
```
gt mail send <address> -s "Subject" -m "Body" [--notify]
```
Wraps: `bd mail send <recipient> -s "Subject" -m "Body"`
If --notify: inject tmux notification after send.

### gt mail delete
```
gt mail delete <id>
```
Wraps: `bd mail ack <id>` (closes the message issue)

## Address Translation

Same as gt-u1j.6:
- `mayor/` → `mayor`
- `<rig>/refinery` → `<rig>-refinery`
- `<rig>/<polecat>` → `<rig>-<polecat>`

## Dependencies

- gt-u1j.6: Mail system backend

title: Beads CLI wrapper: shell out to bd
Merge queue: per-rig queue management
description:
Per-rig merge queue for coordinating polecat work.

## Concept

When polecats complete work, they submit to the merge queue. The Refinery processes the queue, merging work to main in order.

## Data Model

```go
type MergeRequest struct {
    ID        string    `json:"id"`
    Polecat   string    `json:"polecat"`
    Branch    string    `json:"branch"`
    Issue     string    `json:"issue,omitempty"`
    Status    MRStatus  `json:"status"`
    CreatedAt time.Time `json:"created_at"`
    UpdatedAt time.Time `json:"updated_at"`
}

type MRStatus string
const (
    MRPending   MRStatus = "pending"
    MRReviewing MRStatus = "reviewing"
    MRMerged    MRStatus = "merged"
    MRRejected  MRStatus = "rejected"
)
```

## Interface

```go
type MergeQueue struct {
    rig  *Rig
    path string  // <rig>/refinery/queue.jsonl
}

func NewMergeQueue(rig *Rig) *MergeQueue

// Queue operations
func (mq *MergeQueue) Submit(polecat, branch string, issue string) (*MergeRequest, error)
func (mq *MergeQueue) List() ([]*MergeRequest, error)
func (mq *MergeQueue) Next() (*MergeRequest, error)  // oldest pending
func (mq *MergeQueue) Get(id string) (*MergeRequest, error)

// Status updates
func (mq *MergeQueue) SetStatus(id string, status MRStatus) error
func (mq *MergeQueue) MarkMerged(id string) error
func (mq *MergeQueue) MarkRejected(id, reason string) error
```

## Queue Storage

JSONL file at `<rig>/refinery/queue.jsonl`. FIFO ordering.

## Git Coordination

Refinery processes queue:
1. Fetch polecat branch
2. Attempt merge to main
3. Run tests (if configured)
4. Push to origin
5. Update queue status

## Conflict Handling

If merge fails:
- Mark MR as rejected
- Notify polecat to rebase

title: CLI: rig commands (list, show, add)
description:
Rig management CLI commands.

## Commands

### gt rig list
List all registered rigs.
```
gt rig list [--json]
```
Output:
- Rig name
- Git URL
- Polecat count
- Witness/Refinery status

### gt rig show
Show details for a specific rig.
```
gt rig show <name> [--json]
```
Output:
- Full rig info
- Polecats with status
- Recent activity
- Beads summary (open issues)

### gt rig add
Add a new rig to the town.
```
gt rig add <name> <git-url>
gt rig add <name> --local <path>
```
Steps:
- Clone repo to town root (or link local)
- Register in rigs.json
- Create agent directories
- Configure git exclude

### gt rig remove
Remove a rig from the town.
```
gt rig remove <name> [--force]
```
- Warns if active polecats
- --force required if uncommitted changes

## Implementation

```go
var rigCmd = &cobra.Command{Use: "rig"}
rigCmd.AddCommand(rigListCmd, rigShowCmd, rigAddCmd, rigRemoveCmd)
```

title: CLI: polecat commands (add, remove, list, wake, sleep)
description:
Polecat management CLI commands.

## Commands

### gt polecat list
List polecats in a rig.
```
gt polecat list <rig> [--json]
gt polecat list --all [--json]
```
Output:
- Name
- State (idle/active/working/done/stuck)
- Current issue (if any)
- Session status (running/stopped)

### gt polecat add
Add a new polecat to a rig.
```
gt polecat add <rig> <name>
```
- Creates polecat directory
- Clones rig repo
- Creates work branch
- Initializes state

### gt polecat remove
Remove a polecat from a rig.
```
gt polecat remove <rig>/<polecat> [--force]
```
- Fails if session running
- Warns if uncommitted changes
- --force bypasses checks

### gt polecat wake
Mark polecat as active (ready for work).
```
gt polecat wake <rig>/<polecat>
```
Transitions: idle → active

### gt polecat sleep
Mark polecat as idle (not available).
```
gt polecat sleep <rig>/<polecat>
```
Transitions: active → idle
Fails if session running (stop first).

## Address Format

`<rig>/<polecat>` for operations on specific polecat.
`<rig>` for list command.

## Implementation

```go
var polecatCmd = &cobra.Command{Use: "polecat"}
polecatCmd.AddCommand(listCmd, addCmd, removeCmd, wakeCmd, sleepCmd)
```

title: CLI: witness commands (start, stop, status)
description:
Witness daemon CLI commands.

## Commands

### gt witness start
Start the witness daemon for a rig.
```
gt witness start <rig> [--interval <seconds>]
```
- Starts background daemon process
- Default heartbeat interval: 30s
- Logs to <rig>/witness/witness.log

### gt witness stop
Stop the witness daemon.
```
gt witness stop <rig>
```
- Graceful shutdown
- Completes current heartbeat cycle

### gt witness status
Show witness status.
```
gt witness status <rig> [--json]
```
Output:
- Running/stopped
- Last heartbeat time
- Polecats being monitored
- Recent nudges/escalations

### gt witness logs
View witness logs.
```
gt witness logs <rig> [--follow] [--lines <n>]
```
- --follow: Continuous output (like tail -f)
- --lines: Number of lines (default 50)

## Daemon Management

Witness runs as background process:
- PID stored in <rig>/witness/witness.pid
- Uses nohup for persistence
- Logs structured JSON events

## Implementation

```go
var witnessCmd = &cobra.Command{Use: "witness"}
witnessCmd.AddCommand(startCmd, stopCmd, statusCmd, logsCmd)
```

Start launches daemon via exec, status reads PID file and pings process.

title: CLI: spawn command
description:
High-level command to spawn a polecat with work assignment.

## Command

```
gt spawn <rig>/<polecat> --issue <id>
gt spawn <rig> --issue <id>  # auto-select available polecat
gt spawn <rig>/<polecat> -m "Work on X"  # free-form task
```

## What It Does

1. Select or create polecat
2. Ensure polecat is in idle/active state
3. Assign the issue (update beads, set polecat state)
4. Start session (gt session start)
5. Inject initial context

## Options

- `--issue <id>`: Beads issue to assign
- `-m "message"`: Free-form work description
- `--create`: Create polecat if it does not exist
- `--no-start`: Assign work but do not start session

## Auto-Select Logic

If polecat not specified:
1. Look for idle polecats in rig
2. Prefer ones that worked on similar issues before
3. If none available, fail (or create if --create)

## Initial Context

Injects into session:
```
[SPAWN] You have been assigned: <issue-title>
Issue: <id>
Priority: <priority>

<description>

Work on this issue. Signal DONE when complete.
```

## Implementation

Orchestrates PolecatManager + SessionManager + Beads:
```go
func Spawn(rig, polecat, issue string, opts SpawnOptions) error
```

title: Prompt templates: role contexts, nudge messages
description:
Prompt templates for role contexts and messages.

## Template Types

### Role CLAUDE.md Templates

For gt prime and CLAUDE.md generation:
- Mayor template
- Witness template
- Refinery template
- Polecat template

### Message Templates

For notifications and nudges:
- Spawn assignment
- Witness nudge
- Escalation to Mayor
- Session handoff

## Implementation

```go
//go:embed templates/*.md.tmpl
var templateFS embed.FS

type Templates struct {
    fs embed.FS
}

func NewTemplates() *Templates
func (t *Templates) RenderRole(role string, data RoleData) (string, error)
func (t *Templates) RenderMessage(name string, data any) (string, error)
```

## Template Data

```go
type RoleData struct {
    Role      string
    RigName   string
    TownRoot  string
    Polecats  []string
    Commands  []CommandHelp
}

type SpawnData struct {
    Issue       string
    Title       string
    Priority    int
    Description string
}

type NudgeData struct {
    Polecat    string
    Reason     string
    NudgeCount int
    MaxNudges  int
}
```

## Template Location

Embedded in binary via go:embed:
```
internal/templates/
├── roles/
│   ├── mayor.md.tmpl
│   ├── witness.md.tmpl
│   ├── refinery.md.tmpl
│   └── polecat.md.tmpl
└── messages/
    ├── spawn.md.tmpl
    ├── nudge.md.tmpl
    └── escalation.md.tmpl
```

## Usage

gt prime uses role templates.
gt spawn uses spawn template.
Witness uses nudge/escalation templates.

title: Test infrastructure: fixtures, mocks, integration tests
CLI: gt stop --all (emergency swarm kill)
description:
Emergency kill command for swarm operations.

## Commands

```bash
gt stop --all              # Kill ALL sessions across all rigs
gt stop --rig <name>       # Kill all sessions in one rig
gt stop --rig <name> --graceful  # Try graceful first, then force
```

## Implementation

### --all flag
1. List all tmux sessions matching gt-*
2. For each: capture final output, kill session
3. Update all polecat states to idle
4. Log all killed sessions
5. Send mail to Mayor: "Emergency stop executed"

### --rig flag
1. List sessions for specific rig
2. Same as above but scoped

### --graceful flag
1. First, try to inject "exit" command
2. Wait 5 seconds
3. If still running, force kill

## Output

```
Stopping all Gas Town sessions...
  [wyvern] Toast: captured output, killed
  [wyvern] Capable: captured output, killed
  [beads] Nux: captured output, killed
  
3 sessions stopped.
All polecat states set to 'idle'.
Mail sent to mayor/.
```

## Safety

- Always capture output before killing
- Update state files to reflect reality
- Log all operations to gt.log
- Warn if uncommitted changes detected (but still kill)

## Dependencies

Needs: Tmux wrapper, Session management, Polecat management

title: Git wrapper: shell out to git
description:
Wrapper for git operations via subprocess.

## Interface

```go
type Git struct {
    workDir string
}

func NewGit(workDir string) *Git

// Core operations
func (g *Git) Clone(url, dest string) error
func (g *Git) Checkout(ref string) error
func (g *Git) Fetch(remote string) error
func (g *Git) Pull(remote, branch string) error
func (g *Git) Push(remote, branch string, force bool) error

// Commit operations
func (g *Git) Add(paths ...string) error
func (g *Git) Commit(message string) error
func (g *Git) CommitAll(message string) error

// Query operations
func (g *Git) Status() (*GitStatus, error)
func (g *Git) CurrentBranch() (string, error)
func (g *Git) HasUncommittedChanges() (bool, error)
func (g *Git) RemoteURL(remote string) (string, error)

// Merge operations
func (g *Git) Merge(branch string) error
func (g *Git) Rebase(onto string) error
func (g *Git) AbortMerge() error
func (g *Git) AbortRebase() error
```

## Implementation

Shell out to git binary via exec.Command. Parse output where needed (Status, CurrentBranch).

## Error Handling

- Wrap git stderr in error messages
- Detect specific failures (merge conflict, auth failure, not a repo)
- Return structured errors for callers to handle

## Testing

- Use temp directories with real git repos
- Test both success and failure paths

title: Tmux wrapper: session operations
description:
Wrapper for tmux session operations via subprocess.

## Interface

```go
type Tmux struct{}

func NewTmux() *Tmux

// Session lifecycle
func (t *Tmux) NewSession(name, workDir string) error
func (t *Tmux) KillSession(name string) error
func (t *Tmux) HasSession(name string) (bool, error)
func (t *Tmux) ListSessions() ([]string, error)

// Session interaction
func (t *Tmux) SendKeys(session, keys string) error
func (t *Tmux) CapturePane(session string, lines int) (string, error)
func (t *Tmux) AttachSession(session string) error

// Window operations (if needed)
func (t *Tmux) SelectWindow(session string, index int) error
```

## Session Naming

Convention: `gt-<rig>-<polecat>` (e.g., `gt-wyvern-Toast`)

## Implementation

- Shell out to tmux binary
- CapturePane uses `tmux capture-pane -p -t <session> -S -<lines>`
- SendKeys uses `tmux send-keys -t <session> '<keys>' Enter`

## Error Handling

- "no server running": tmux not started (not an error for HasSession)
- "session not found": session doesn't exist
- Wrap all tmux errors with context

## Environment

Requires TMUX_TMPDIR or uses default socket. Don't assume tmux is running.

title: Rig management: discover, load, create rigs
description:
Rig discovery, loading, and creation.

## Interface

```go
type Rig struct {
    Name      string
    Path      string
    GitURL    string
    Config    RigConfig
    Polecats  []string
    HasWitness bool
    HasRefinery bool
}

type RigManager struct {
    townRoot string
    config   *Config
    git      *Git
}

func NewRigManager(townRoot string, config *Config, git *Git) *RigManager

// Discovery
func (rm *RigManager) DiscoverRigs() ([]*Rig, error)
func (rm *RigManager) GetRig(name string) (*Rig, error)
func (rm *RigManager) RigExists(name string) bool

// Creation
func (rm *RigManager) AddRig(name, gitURL string) (*Rig, error)
func (rm *RigManager) RemoveRig(name string) error

// Rig state
func (rm *RigManager) LoadRigConfig(rig *Rig) error
func (rm *RigManager) SaveRigConfig(rig *Rig) error
```

## Discovery Logic

1. Read rigs.json from config/
2. For each registered rig, verify directory exists
3. Load rig-level config if present
4. Scan for polecats/ subdirectory
5. Check for witness/, refinery/ directories

## Rig Creation

1. Clone repo to town root
2. Add entry to rigs.json
3. Create agent directories (polecats/, witness/, refinery/, mayor/)
4. Update .git/info/exclude to ignore agent dirs
5. Initialize rig config

## Rig Structure

Per docs/architecture.md:
```
<rig>/
├── polecats/
├── refinery/rig/
├── witness/rig/
└── mayor/rig/
```

title: Mail system: JSONL inbox, delivery, tmux injection
description:
Refactor mail system to wrap bd mail commands.

## Status

Current implementation uses JSONL files directly. Now that Beads mail is available (gt-r01 closed), refactor to use bd mail as the backend.

## Implementation

Replace internal/mail/* with thin wrappers around bd CLI:

```go
// Send wraps: bd mail send <to> -s <subject> -m <body>
func (r *Router) Send(msg *Message) error

// List wraps: bd mail inbox --json
func (m *Mailbox) List() ([]*Message, error)

// Get wraps: bd mail read <id> --json
func (m *Mailbox) Get(id string) (*Message, error)

// MarkRead wraps: bd mail ack <id>
func (m *Mailbox) MarkRead(id string) error
```

## Address Translation

GGT addresses → Beads recipients:
- `mayor/` → `mayor`
- `<rig>/refinery` → `<rig>-refinery`
- `<rig>/<polecat>` → `<rig>-<polecat>`

## Tmux Notification

Keep the tmux injection for --notify flag. After bd mail send, optionally inject notification into tmux session.

## Migration

No migration needed - bd mail creates messages as beads issues with type=message. Old JSONL inboxes can be ignored or cleaned up.

## Dependencies

- gt-r01: CLOSED (Beads mail available)
- gt-u1j.4: Tmux wrapper (for notifications)

title: Session management: start, stop, attach, capture
description:
Polecat session lifecycle management.

## Interface

```go
type SessionManager struct {
    tmux *Tmux
    rig  *Rig
}

func NewSessionManager(tmux *Tmux, rig *Rig) *SessionManager

// Lifecycle
func (sm *SessionManager) Start(polecat string, opts StartOptions) error
func (sm *SessionManager) Stop(polecat string) error
func (sm *SessionManager) IsRunning(polecat string) (bool, error)
func (sm *SessionManager) List() ([]SessionInfo, error)

// Interaction
func (sm *SessionManager) Attach(polecat string) error
func (sm *SessionManager) Capture(polecat string, lines int) (string, error)
func (sm *SessionManager) Inject(polecat string, message string) error

type StartOptions struct {
    WorkDir   string   // defaults to polecat clone dir
    Issue     string   // optional: issue to work on
    Command   string   // optional: override claude command
}

type SessionInfo struct {
    Polecat   string
    SessionID string
    Running   bool
    StartedAt time.Time
}
```

## Session Naming

`gt-<rig>-<polecat>` (e.g., `gt-wyvern-Toast`)

## Start Flow

1. Verify polecat clone exists
2. Check no existing session
3. Create tmux session in polecat workdir
4. Send initial command: `claude` or custom
5. If issue provided, inject initial prompt

## Stop Flow

1. Capture final output (for logging)
2. Send exit/quit command
3. Wait briefly for graceful shutdown
4. Kill session if still running

## Capture

Uses tmux capture-pane to get recent output. Returns last N lines.

## Inject

Sends text to session via tmux send-keys. Used for:
- Mail notifications
- Witness nudges
- User messages

title: Polecat management: add, remove, list, state
description:
Polecat lifecycle: add, remove, list, state tracking.

## Data Model

```go
type Polecat struct {
    Name      string          `json:"name"`
    Rig       string          `json:"rig"`
    State     PolecatState    `json:"state"`
    ClonePath string          `json:"clone_path"`
    Branch    string          `json:"branch"`
    Issue     string          `json:"issue,omitempty"`
    CreatedAt time.Time       `json:"created_at"`
    UpdatedAt time.Time       `json:"updated_at"`
}

type PolecatState string
const (
    StateIdle       PolecatState = "idle"
    StateActive     PolecatState = "active"
    StateWorking    PolecatState = "working"
    StateDone       PolecatState = "done"
    StateStuck      PolecatState = "stuck"
)
```

## Interface

```go
type PolecatManager struct {
    rig *Rig
    git *Git
}

func NewPolecatManager(rig *Rig, git *Git) *PolecatManager

// Lifecycle
func (pm *PolecatManager) Add(name string) (*Polecat, error)
func (pm *PolecatManager) Remove(name string) error
func (pm *PolecatManager) List() ([]*Polecat, error)
func (pm *PolecatManager) Get(name string) (*Polecat, error)

// State
func (pm *PolecatManager) SetState(name string, state PolecatState) error
func (pm *PolecatManager) AssignIssue(name, issue string) error
func (pm *PolecatManager) ClearIssue(name string) error

// Convenience
func (pm *PolecatManager) Wake(name string) error   // idle → active
func (pm *PolecatManager) Sleep(name string) error  // active → idle
```

## Add Flow

1. Create directory: `<rig>/polecats/<name>/`
2. Clone rig repo into it (or copy from rig root)
3. Create new branch: `polecat/<name>`
4. Initialize polecat state file
5. Create mail inbox

## Remove Flow

1. Verify session not running
2. Check for uncommitted changes (warn/error)
3. Remove directory
4. Clean up state

## State Persistence

Store in `<rig>/polecats/<name>/state.json`

title: Witness daemon: heartbeat loop, spawn ephemeral agent
description:
Background daemon for agent lifecycle and monitoring.

## Core Responsibilities

1. **Heartbeat monitoring**: Check agent health periodically
2. **Session lifecycle**: Restart agents after handoff (Witness Protection)
3. **Polecat monitoring**: Track worker progress, nudging
4. **Escalation**: Report failures to Mayor

## Session Lifecycle (Witness Protection)

The daemon enables autonomous long-running operation by cycling agent sessions:

```go
type SessionLifecycle struct {
    AgentType string  // "witness", "refinery"
    StatePath string  // path to state.json
}

func (d *Daemon) monitorSessionLifecycle(agent SessionLifecycle) {
    // 1. Detect session exit
    // 2. Check state.json for requesting_cycle: true
    // 3. If cycle requested: start new session, clear flag
    // 4. If unexpected exit: escalate to Mayor
}
```

See architecture.md Key Decision #12: Agent Session Lifecycle.

## Interface

```go
type Daemon struct {
    rig      *Rig
    polecats *PolecatManager
    sessions *SessionManager
    config   DaemonConfig
}

type DaemonConfig struct {
    HeartbeatInterval time.Duration  // default: 30s
    NudgeThreshold    int            // nudges before escalation
    MaxWorkers        int            // from rig config
}

func NewDaemon(rig *Rig) *Daemon
func (d *Daemon) Start() error
func (d *Daemon) Stop() error

// Lifecycle
func (d *Daemon) CycleSession(agentType string) error
func (d *Daemon) SpawnWorker(issueID string) error
func (d *Daemon) ShutdownWorker(polecat string) error
```

## Heartbeat Loop

Every HeartbeatInterval:
1. Check Witness session (restart if cycle requested)
2. Check Refinery session (restart if cycle requested)
3. For each active polecat: assess progress, nudge if stuck
4. Query `bd ready` for new work, spawn up to max_workers

title: gt shutdown should fully cleanup polecats (worktrees, branches, inboxes)
description:
Current gt shutdown only kills tmux sessions but leaves:

1. Git worktrees in polecats/ directory
2. Polecat branches (polecat/<name>)
3. Inbox messages
4. Beads assignee state

This causes stale polecats to be reused on next startup.

## Expected Behavior

gt shutdown should:
1. Kill all polecat tmux sessions (current behavior)
2. For each polecat with StateIdle or StateDone:
   - Remove worktree
   - Delete branch
   - Clear inbox
3. For polecats with uncommitted work:
   - REFUSE to clean up
   - Report which polecats have uncommitted changes
   - Require --force or --nuclear to proceed

## Current Code

- start.go:runImmediateShutdown() only calls t.KillSession()
- Witness cleanupPolecat() does full cleanup but isn't called by shutdown

## Fix

Either:
1. Call Witness cleanup for each polecat during shutdown
2. OR add rig.ShutdownPolecats() that does the full cleanup

title: Witness Plugin System
description:
Patrol extensions via molecule bonding.

## Core Insight

Plugins ARE molecules. No separate format needed.

## How It Works

```
mol-witness-patrol
    │
    ├── survey-workers
    │
    ├── plugin-run ←── bonds registered plugin molecules
    │       │
    │       ├── mol-mood-check (if registered)
    │       ├── mol-security-scan (if registered)
    │       └── mol-custom-X (user-installed)
    │
    └── aggregate (WaitsFor: all-children)
```

## Plugin Molecule Structure

A plugin is just a molecule proto with specific labels:

```json
{
  "id": "mol-mood-check",
  "title": "Polecat Mood Check",
  "description": "Assess polecat emotional state from output. Vars: {{polecat_name}}, {{captured_output}}",
  "labels": ["template", "plugin", "witness", "tier:haiku"],
  "issue_type": "task"
}
```

Labels encode metadata:
- `plugin` - marks as bondable plugin
- `witness` / `deacon` / `refinery` - which patrol can use it
- `tier:haiku` / `tier:sonnet` - model tier hint

## Registration

Plugins registered in rig config or molecules.jsonl:

```bash
# Install from Mol Mall
bd mol install mol-mood-check

# Or add to ~/.beads/molecules.jsonl manually
```

## Execution

The `plugin-run` step in patrol:

```bash
# For each registered plugin molecule matching this patrol:
bd mol bond mol-mood-check $PATROL_WISP \
  --ref mood-{{polecat_name}} \
  --var polecat_name=$POLECAT \
  --var captured_output="$OUTPUT"
```

## CLI

- `bd mol list --label plugin` - List available plugins
- `bd mol install <id>` - Install from Mol Mall
- `gt patrol plugins <role>` - Show plugins for a patrol role

## Benefits

- No YAML schema to maintain
- No separate plugin loading code
- Plugins are versioned, synced, auditable (they are beads)
- Distribution via Mol Mall (molecules.jsonl registry)
- Same {{var}} substitution as all molecules

title: Mol Mall: Formula marketplace using GitHub as backend
description:
Create a marketplace for sharing molecule formulas using GitHub repos as the hosting backend.

## Architecture

Formulas ──cook──→ [ephemeral proto] ──pour/wisp──→ Mol/Wisp
    ↑                                                    │
    └────────────────── distill ─────────────────────────┘

- Formulas: JSON source files (.formula.json) - the thing you share
- Protos: Transient compilation artifacts - auto-deleted after use
- Mols/Wisps: Execution instances - not shared directly

## Key operations
- bd distill <mol-id> → Extract formula from completed work
- bd mol publish <formula> → Share to GitHub
- bd mol install <url> → Fetch from GitHub
- bd pour <formula> → Cook and spawn (proto is ephemeral)

## Migrated from beads rig (bd-1dez)
Completed: distill, formula add, versioning, installation tracking
Remaining: install, update, search, publish

title: bd mol install: Install formula from GitHub

Fetch and install a formula from a GitHub repository.

title: ApplyBranches/ApplyGates mutate steps in place
description:
ApplyBranches and ApplyGates claim to return a modified steps slice, but they actually mutate the original steps via the pointer map from buildStepMap().

```go
// ApplyBranches docstring says:
// Returns the modified steps slice (steps are modified in place for dependencies).
```

This is technically documented but violates the pattern established by ApplyLoops and ApplyAdvice which return new step slices.

Options:
1. Document explicitly that these functions mutate in place (current behavior)
2. Clone steps before modification for true immutability
3. Accept this as intentional since it's an optimization

The current behavior is safe because cook.go doesn't reuse the input slice, but could cause subtle bugs if callers expect immutability.

Recommend option 1 (document) or 2 (clone) for consistency.

title: Design: Failure modes and recovery
description:
Document failure modes and recovery strategies for Gas Town operations.

## Critical Failure Modes

### 1. Agent Crash Mid-Operation

**Scenario**: Polecat crashes while committing, Witness crashes while verifying

**Detection**:
- Session suddenly gone (tmux check fails)
- State shows 'working' but no session
- Heartbeat stops (for Witness)

**Recovery**:
- Doctor detects via ZombieSessionCheck
- Capture any recoverable state
- Reset agent state to 'idle'
- For Witness: auto-restart via supervisor or manual gt witness start

### 2. Git State Corruption

**Scenario**: Merge conflict, failed rebase, detached HEAD

**Detection**:
- Git commands fail
- Dirty state that won't commit
- Branch diverged from origin

**Recovery**:
- gt doctor reports git health issues
- Manual intervention recommended
- Severe cases: remove clone, re-clone

### 3. Beads Sync Conflict

**Scenario**: Two polecats modify same issue

**Detection**:
- bd sync fails with conflict
- Beads tombstone mechanism handles most cases

**Recovery**:
- Beads has last-write-wins semantics
- bd sync --force in extreme cases
- Issues may need manual dedup

### 4. Tmux Failure

**Scenario**: Tmux server crashes, socket issues

**Detection**:
- All sessions inaccessible
- "no server running" errors

**Recovery**:
- Kill any orphan processes
- tmux kill-server && tmux start-server
- All agent states reset to idle
- Re-spawn active work

### 5. Claude API Issues

**Scenario**: Rate limits, outages, context limits

**Detection**:
- Sessions hang or produce errors
- Repeated failure patterns

**Recovery**:
- Exponential backoff (handled by Claude Code)
- For context limits: session cycling (mail-to-self)
- For outages: wait and retry

### 6. Disk Full

**Scenario**: Clones, logs, or beads fill disk

**Detection**:
- Write operations fail
- git/bd commands error

**Recovery**:
- Clean up logs: rm ~/.gastown/logs/*
- Remove old polecat clones
- gt doctor --fix can clean some cruft

### 7. Network Failure

**Scenario**: Can't reach GitHub, API servers

**Detection**:
- git fetch/push fails
- Claude sessions hang

**Recovery**:
- Work continues locally
- Queue pushes for later
- Sync when connectivity restored

## Recovery Principles

1. **Fail safe**: Prefer stopping over corrupting
2. **State is recoverable**: Git and beads have recovery mechanisms
3. **Doctor heals**: gt doctor --fix handles common issues
4. **Emergency stop**: gt stop --all as last resort
5. **Human escalation**: Some failures need Overseer intervention

## Implementation

- Document each failure mode in architecture.md
- Ensure doctor checks cover detection
- Add recovery hints to error messages
- Log all failures for debugging

title: Check Witness and Refinery health
description:
Check Witness and Refinery health for each rig.

**ZFC Principle**: You (Claude) make the judgment call about what is "stuck" or
"unresponsive" - there are no hardcoded thresholds in Go. Read the signals,
consider context, and decide.

For each rig, run:
```bash
gt witness status <rig>
gt refinery status <rig>
```

**Signals to assess:**

| Component | Healthy Signals | Concerning Signals |
|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Witness | State: running, recent activity | State: not running, no heartbeat |
| Refinery | State: running, queue processing | Queue stuck, merge failures |

**Tracking unresponsive cycles:**

Maintain in your patrol state (persisted across cycles):
```
health_state:
  <rig>:
    witness:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
    refinery:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
```

**Decision matrix** (you decide the thresholds based on context):

| Cycles Unresponsive | Suggested Action |
|---------------------|------------------|
| 1-2 | Note it, check again next cycle |
| 3-4 | Attempt restart: gt witness restart <rig> |
| 5+ | Escalate to Mayor with context |

**Restart commands:**
```bash
gt witness restart <rig>
gt refinery restart <rig>
```

**Escalation:**
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Health: <rig> <component> unresponsive" \
  -m "Component has been unresponsive for N cycles. Restart attempts failed.
      Last healthy: <timestamp>
      Error signals: <details>"
```

Reset unresponsive_cycles to 0 when component responds normally.

title: Tmux status line: rig color themes and worker identity display
description:
## Summary

Customize tmux status line for Gas Town workers with:
1. Per-rig configurable color themes
2. Clear worker name and role visibility

## Current Problem

- Only mayor shows in status line (and truncated)
- Can't tell which rig/worker you're looking at
- All sessions look the same

## Proposed Design

### Per-rig colors
```yaml
# In rig config or beads
theme:
  primary: '#ff6600'    # Orange for gastown
  secondary: '#333333'
  accent: '#ffcc00'
```

### Status line format
```
[gastown/Rictus] polecat | gt-70b3 | branch: polecat/Rictus
[beads/emma] crew | working | branch: main  
[mayor] coordinator | idle
```

### Components
- Rig name with rig color
- Worker name
- Role (polecat/crew/mayor/witness/refinery)
- Current issue or status
- Branch name

## Configuration

Could use pinned beads for this (see gm-w13, beads-6v2):
- `bd show <rig>-theme` returns theme config
- Stored as pinned bead, always available
- Part of 'config in beads data plane' initiative
notes: Implementation complete. Core features: per-rig color themes, dynamic status line with issue/mail indicators, gt theme/issue commands. Ready for testing.

title: No-tmux mode: naked Claude Code operation without daemon/tmux
description:
## Problem

Tmux is crashing workers. The daemon relies on tmux for:
- Session management (creating/killing panes)
- Nudging agents via SendKeys
- Crash detection via pane-died hooks

When tmux is unstable, the entire Gas Town operation fails.

## Goal

Enable Gas Town to operate without tmux or the daemon, relying solely on:
- Naked Claude Code sessions (terminal or IDE)
- Deacon self-handoff and patrol robustness
- Pinned beads for propulsion (already implemented)
- **Beads as universal data plane** - args, context, everything flows through beads

## Key Insight: Beads Replace SendKeys

Currently --args is injected via tmux SendKeys. In no-tmux mode:
- Store args in the pinned bead description (attached_args field)
- gt prime reads and displays args from pinned bead
- Wisps are infinite ephemeral sticky notes - use them for transient context
- No prompt injection needed - agent discovers everything via bd show

## Degraded Behavior (No-Tmux Mode)

**What still works:**
- Propulsion via pinned beads (agents pick up work on startup)
- Self-handoff (agents can cycle themselves)
- Patrol loops (Deacon, Witness, Refinery keep running)
- Mail system (beads-based, no tmux needed)
- Args passed via bead description

**What is degraded:**
- **No interrupts**: Cannot nudge busy agents mid-task
- **Polling only**: Agents must actively check inbox (no push notifications)
- **Await steps block**: "Wait for human" steps require manual agent restart
- **No crash detection**: pane-died hooks unavailable
- **Manual startup**: Human must start each agent in separate terminal

**Workflow implications:**
- Patrol agents work fine (they poll as part of their loop)
- Task workers need restart to pick up new work
- Cannot redirect a busy worker to urgent task
- Human must monitor and restart crashed agents

## Requirements

1. **gt sling --args stores in bead**: Write args to pinned bead description
2. **gt prime displays args**: Read attached_args from pinned bead
3. **gt spawn --naked**: Assign work without creating tmux session
4. **Documentation**: Explain no-tmux mode and degraded behavior
5. **Deacon self-sustaining**: Must cycle reliably without daemon

## Acceptance Criteria

- Can assign work with args without tmux
- Agent discovers args via gt prime / bd show on startup
- Deacon patrol runs indefinitely via self-handoff
- Workers started manually pick up pinned work
- Documentation explains what works vs degraded in no-tmux mode

title: Mayor handoff mail template
description:
Add MAYOR_HANDOFF mail template to templates.py.

## Template Function

def mayor_handoff(
    active_swarms: List[SwarmStatus],
    rig_status: Dict[str, RigStatus],
    pending_escalations: List[Escalation],
    in_flight_decisions: List[Decision],
    recent_actions: List[str],
    delegated_work: List[DelegatedItem],
    user_requests: List[str],
    next_steps: List[str],
    warnings: Optional[str] = None,
    session_duration: Optional[str] = None,
) -> Message:
    metadata = {
        'template': 'MAYOR_HANDOFF',
        'timestamp': datetime.utcnow().isoformat(),
        'session_duration': session_duration,
        'active_swarm_count': len(active_swarms),
        'pending_escalation_count': len(pending_escalations),
    }
    # ... format sections ...
    return Message.create(
        sender='mayor/',
        recipient='mayor/',
        subject='Session Handoff',
        body=body,
        priority='high',
    )

## Metadata Fields

- template: MAYOR_HANDOFF
- timestamp: ISO format
- session_duration: Human readable
- active_swarm_count: Number of active swarms
- pending_escalation_count: Number of escalations

## Mail Priority

Use priority='high' to ensure handoff is seen on startup.

title: Crew workers getting wrong CLAUDE.md (shows Refinery)
description:

$ head -5 /Users/stevey/gt/beads/crew/emma/CLAUDE.md
# Claude: Beads Refinery
You are the **Refinery** for the **beads** rig...

## Expected

Should use crew.md.tmpl which correctly says:
```
# Crew Worker Context
You are a **crew worker** - the overseer's (human's) personal workspace...
```

## Impact

- Crew workers have wrong identity in static context
- `gt prime` correctly outputs crew context, but CLAUDE.md conflicts
- Confusing role information

## Fix

Check `gt crew create` or whatever populates CLAUDE.md for crew workers.

Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---
bonded_from: mol-polecat-arm
bonded_to: gt-vhn1
bonded_ref: arm-toast
bonded_at: 2025-12-23T10:00:00Z

title: Swarm learning: Session cleanup missing from swarm workflow
description:
## Problem

After Enders Game swarm completed (18 issues merged), 16 polecat sessions were left running but idle. No automated cleanup occurred.

## What Should Happen

1. Witness detects polecat completed work (idle at prompt)
2. Witness verifies git state is clean
3. Witness shuts down session
4. Witness reports completion to Mayor

## GGT Components

- gt-cxx: Witness context cycling (covers self-cycling)
- gt-u1j.9: Witness daemon heartbeat loop
- gt-kmn.6: Witness swarm landing protocol

## Recommendation

Add to Witness responsibilities:
- Monitor for 'work complete' signals (DONE keyword, idle detection)
- Automated session shutdown after verification
- Swarm completion reporting to Mayor

See also: architecture.md 'Worker Cleanup (Witness-Owned)' section which describes this but it wasn't implemented in PGT.

title: Digest: mol-deacon-patrol
description: Patrol 15: All agents healthy

title: Guardrail: Verify commits exist before closing polecat issues
description:
## Updated Approach (ZFC)

The original proposal was for mechanical guardrails in bd close. This contradicts the ZFC principle: all decisions go to models, not code.

## Correct Solution

The verification should happen in **mol-polecat-arm** execute step, not bd close:

In the pre-kill-verify action:
```bash
# Current steps
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred

# ADD: Verify productive work
git log --oneline --grep='<issue-id>' | head -1
# If no commits AND issue being closed as 'done' → flag for review
```

The agent (Witness) makes the decision. The mol gives it the verification step.

## Why Not Code Guardrails

Polecats have legitimate reasons to close issues without commits:
- Already done (someone else fixed it)
- Deferred (out of scope)
- Escalated (needs human decision)
- Duplicate (merged with another issue)

A code guardrail would block all these. The mol step lets the agent verify AND make the judgment call.

## Implementation

Update mol-polecat-arm execute step to include commit verification for 'done' closures.

title: tmux notifications: display-message too subtle, use send-keys instead
description:
## Problem

`tmux display-message` notifications are not visible enough - they appear briefly in the status bar and are easy to miss.

## Current Behavior

router.go uses:
```go
r.tmux.DisplayMessageDefault(sessionID, notification)
```

## What Works

Sending echo commands directly to the terminal:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t <session> "echo '📬 NEW MAIL from mayor'" Enter
```

## Proposed Fix

Change notification method to send visible output to the terminal, perhaps with a box/banner:
```
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
📬 NEW MAIL from mayor
Subject: <subject>
Run: bd mail inbox
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
```

## Considerations

- This interrupts the terminal output (acceptable for important mail)
- Could check if Claude is mid-response and queue notification
- Or use tmux popup if available
notes:
Additional issues:
1. Enter key not sent properly when chained with send-keys
2. Need to debounce and send Enter separately
3. Correct pattern: send text, sleep briefly, then send Enter

title: gt spawn: Enter key needs debounce delay after paste
description:
## Problem

When spawning polecats via `gt spawn`, instructions are pasted into tmux but workers often sit idle at prompt because the Enter key arrives before the paste is fully processed.

## Observed Behavior

- Instructions pasted via tmux send-keys
- Enter key sent immediately after
- Worker session shows prompt with no input (paste not submitted)
- Requires manual intervention to nudge workers

## Expected Behavior

- Paste completes fully
- Enter key submits the pasted instructions
- Worker begins executing immediately

## Root Cause

Likely a race condition between paste buffer processing and keypress handling. Need either:
1. Debounce delay before sending Enter
2. Longer delay (Tmax) to ensure paste completes
3. Alternative submission mechanism

## Impact

- Swarm of 10 workers had multiple stalls at startup
- Required manual tmux send-keys to unstick them
- Defeats purpose of automated spawning

## References

- Observed during Mad Max swarm (Dec 18, 2025)
- Affects gt spawn command in internal/cmd/spawn.go

title: CLI cleanup: Remove duplicate mol commands from gt
description:
## Problem
gt mol has commands that duplicate bd mol functionality:
- `gt mol catalog` (duplicate of `bd formula list`)
- `gt mol show` (duplicate of `bd mol show`)
- `gt mol squash` (duplicate of `bd mol squash`)
- `gt mol burn` (duplicate of `bd mol burn`)
- `gt mol bond` (duplicate of `bd mol bond`)

## Principle
- **bd** = beads operations (issues, molecules, formulas)
- **gt** = agent operations (sessions, communication, work dispatch)

gt should delegate to bd for beads operations, not duplicate them.

## Proposed Changes
Keep gt mol commands that are agent-specific:
- `gt mol status` - what is on MY hook
- `gt mol attach/detach` - hook management
- `gt mol current` - what should I work on
- `gt mol progress` - my progress through workflow

Remove/delegate to bd:
- `gt mol catalog` → use `bd formula list`
- `gt mol show` → use `bd mol show`
- `gt mol squash` → use `bd mol squash`
- `gt mol burn` → use `bd mol burn`
- `gt mol bond` → use `bd mol bond`

## Alternative
Keep as thin wrappers that just call bd, for convenience.

title: /restart: Personal slash command for in-place agent restart
description:
Create ~/.claude/commands/restart.md that restarts current Gas Town agent in place.

## Detection
- Read tmux session name: gt-mayor, gt-witness-*, gt-refinery-*, gt-polecat-*
- Fallback: check GT_ROLE env var

## Behavior by role
- mayor: gt mayor restart (sends Ctrl-C, loop respawns)
- witness: gt witness restart
- refinery: gt refinery restart  
- polecat: gt polecat restart (or witness-mediated)

## Command format
Uses backticks for inline bash to detect context, then instructs Claude to run appropriate restart.

title: Digest: mol-deacon-patrol
description: Patrol 3: all clear

title: Digest: mol-deacon-patrol
description: Patrol 20: Final patrol, all healthy, handoff triggered

title: Check own context limit
description:
Check own context limit.

The Deacon runs in a Claude session with finite context. Check if approaching the limit:

```bash
gt context --usage
```

If context is high (>80%), prepare for handoff:
- Summarize current state
- Note any pending work
- Write handoff to molecule state

This enables the Deacon to burn and respawn cleanly.

title: Check own context limit
description:
Check own context usage.

If context is HIGH (>80%):
- Ensure state is saved to handoff bead
- Prepare for burn/respawn

If context is LOW:
- Can continue patrolling

title: mol-witness-patrol
description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop using the Christmas Ornament pattern.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

This molecule uses dynamic bonding to spawn mol-polecat-arm for each worker,
enabling parallel inspection with a fanout gate for aggregation.

## The Christmas Ornament Shape

```
                     ★ mol-witness-patrol (trunk)
                    /|\
          ┌────────┘ │ └────────┐
       PREFLIGHT  DISCOVERY  CLEANUP
          │          │           │
      inbox-check  survey    aggregate (WaitsFor: all-children)
      check-refnry   │       save-state
      load-state     │       generate-summary
                     ↓       context-check
             ┌───────┼───────┐  burn-or-loop
             ●       ●       ●   mol-polecat-arm (dynamic)
            ace     nux    toast
```

title: Load persisted patrol state
description:
Read handoff bead and get nudge counts.

Load persistent state from the witness handoff bead:
- Active workers and their status from last cycle
- Nudge counts per worker per issue
- Last nudge timestamps
- Pending escalations

```bash
bd show <handoff-bead-id>
```

If no handoff exists (fresh start), initialize empty state.
This state persists across wisp burns and session cycles.

title: Evaluate pending async gates
description:
Evaluate pending async gates.

Gates are async coordination primitives that block until conditions are met.
The Deacon is responsible for monitoring gates and closing them when ready.

**Timer gates** (await_type: timer):
Check if elapsed time since creation exceeds the timeout duration.

```bash
# List all open gates
bd gate list --json

# For each timer gate, check if elapsed:
# - CreatedAt + Timeout < Now → gate is ready to close
# - Close with: bd gate close <id> --reason "Timer elapsed"
```

**GitHub gates** (await_type: gh:run, gh:pr) - handled in separate step.

**Human/Mail gates** - require external input, skip here.

After closing a gate, the Waiters field contains mail addresses to notify.
Send a brief notification to each waiter that the gate has cleared.

title: Execute registered plugins
description:
Execute registered plugins.

Scan ~/gt/plugins/ for plugin directories. Each plugin has a plugin.md with YAML frontmatter defining its gate (when to run) and instructions (what to do).

See docs/deacon-plugins.md for full documentation.

Gate types:
- cooldown: Time since last run (e.g., 24h)
- cron: Schedule-based (e.g., "0 9 * * *")
- condition: Metric threshold (e.g., wisp count > 50)
- event: Trigger-based (e.g., startup, heartbeat)

For each plugin:
1. Read plugin.md frontmatter to check gate
2. Compare against state.json (last run, etc.)
3. If gate is open, execute the plugin

Plugins marked parallel: true can run concurrently using Task tool subagents. Sequential plugins run one at a time in directory order.

Skip this step if ~/gt/plugins/ does not exist or is empty.

title: Burn and respawn or loop
description:
Burn and let daemon respawn, or exit if context high.

Decision point at end of patrol cycle:

If context is LOW:
- Sleep briefly (avoid tight loop)
- Return to inbox-check step

If context is HIGH:
- Write state to persistent storage
- Exit cleanly
- Let the daemon orchestrator respawn a fresh Deacon

The daemon ensures Deacon is always running:
```bash
# Daemon respawns on exit
gt daemon status
```

This enables infinite patrol duration via context-aware respawning.

title: Process witness mail
description:
Process witness mail: lifecycle requests, help requests.

```bash
gt mail inbox
```

Handle by message type:
- **LIFECYCLE/Shutdown**: Queue for pre-kill verification
- **Blocked/Help**: Assess if resolvable or escalate
- **HANDOFF**: Load predecessor state
- **Work complete**: Verify issue closed, proceed to pre-kill

Record any pending actions for later steps.
Mark messages as processed when complete.

title: Check Witness and Refinery health
description:
Check Witness and Refinery health for each rig.

**ZFC Principle**: You (Claude) make the judgment call about what is "stuck" or "unresponsive" - there are no hardcoded thresholds in Go. Read the signals, consider context, and decide.

For each rig, run:
```bash
gt witness status <rig>
gt refinery status <rig>
```

**Signals to assess:**

| Component | Healthy Signals | Concerning Signals |
|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Witness | State: running, recent activity | State: not running, no heartbeat |
| Refinery | State: running, queue processing | Queue stuck, merge failures |

**Tracking unresponsive cycles:**

Maintain in your patrol state (persisted across cycles):
```
health_state:
  <rig>:
    witness:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
    refinery:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
```

**Decision matrix** (you decide the thresholds based on context):

| Cycles Unresponsive | Suggested Action |
|---------------------|------------------|
| 1-2 | Note it, check again next cycle |
| 3-4 | Attempt restart: gt witness restart <rig> |
| 5+ | Escalate to Mayor with context |

**Restart commands:**
```bash
gt witness restart <rig>
gt refinery restart <rig>
```

**Escalation:**
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Health: <rig> <component> unresponsive" \
  -m "Component has been unresponsive for N cycles. Restart attempts failed.
      Last healthy: <timestamp>
      Error signals: <details>"
```

Reset unresponsive_cycles to 0 when component responds normally.

title: Nudge newly spawned polecats
description:
Nudge newly spawned polecats that are ready for input.

When polecats are spawned, their Claude session takes 10-20 seconds to initialize. The spawn command returns immediately without waiting. This step finds spawned polecats that are now ready and sends them a trigger to start working.

**ZFC-Compliant Observation** (AI observes AI):

```bash
# View pending spawns with captured terminal output
gt deacon pending
```

For each pending session, analyze the captured output:
- Look for Claude's prompt indicator "> " at the start of a line
- If prompt is visible, Claude is ready for input
- Make the judgment call yourself - you're the AI observer

For each ready polecat:
```bash
# 1. Trigger the polecat
gt nudge <session> "Begin."

# 2. Clear from pending list
gt deacon pending <session>
```

This triggers the UserPromptSubmit hook, which injects mail so the polecat sees its assignment.

**Bootstrap mode** (daemon-only, no AI available):
The daemon uses `gt deacon trigger-pending` with regex detection. This ZFC violation is acceptable during cold startup when no AI agent is running yet.

title: Persist patrol state
description:
Update handoff bead with new states.

Persist state to the witness handoff bead:
- Updated worker statuses from all arms
- Current nudge counts per worker
- Nudge timestamps
- Actions taken this cycle
- Pending items for next cycle

```bash
bd update <handoff-bead-id> --description="<serialized state>"
```

This state survives wisp burns and session cycles.

title: Generate handoff summary
description:
Summarize this patrol cycle for digest.

Include:
- Workers inspected (count, names)
- Nudges sent (count, to whom)
- Sessions killed (count, names)
- Escalations (count, issues)
- Issues found (brief descriptions)
- Actions pending for next cycle

This becomes the digest when the patrol wisp is squashed.

title: Clean dead sessions
description:
Clean dead sessions.

Garbage collect terminated sessions:
- Remove stale polecat directories
- Clean up wisp session artifacts
- Prune old logs and temp files
- Archive completed molecule state

```bash
gt gc --sessions
gt gc --wisps --age=1h
```

Preserve audit trail. Only clean sessions confirmed dead.

title: Aggregate arm results
description:
Collect outcomes from all polecat inspection arms.

This is a **fanout gate** - it cannot proceed until ALL dynamically-bonded
polecat arms have completed their inspection cycles.

Once all arms complete, collect their outcomes:
- Actions taken per polecat (nudge, kill, escalate, none)
- Updated nudge counts
- Any errors or issues discovered

Build the consolidated state for save-state.

title: Ensure refinery is alive
description:
Ensure the refinery is alive and processing merge requests.

**Redundant system**: This check runs in both gt spawn and Witness patrol
to ensure the merge queue processor stays operational.

```bash
# Check if refinery session is running
gt session status <rig>/refinery

# Check for merge requests in queue
bd list --type=merge-request --status=open
```

If merge requests are waiting AND refinery is not running:
```bash
gt session start <rig>/refinery
gt mail send <rig>/refinery -s "PATROL: Wake up" -m "Merge requests in queue. Please process."
```

If refinery is running but queue is non-empty for >30 min, send nudge.
This ensures polecats don't wait forever for their branches to merge.

title: Survey all polecats (fanout)
description:
List polecats and bond mol-polecat-arm for each one.

```bash
# Get list of polecats
gt polecat list <rig>
```

For each polecat discovered, dynamically bond an inspection arm:

```bash
# Bond mol-polecat-arm for each polecat
for polecat in $(gt polecat list <rig> --names); do
  bd mol bond mol-polecat-arm $PATROL_WISP_ID \
    --ref arm-$polecat \
    --var polecat_name=$polecat \
    --var rig=<rig>
done
```

This creates child wisps like:
- patrol-x7k.arm-ace (5 steps)
- patrol-x7k.arm-nux (5 steps)
- patrol-x7k.arm-toast (5 steps)

Each arm runs in PARALLEL. The aggregate step will wait for all to complete.

If no polecats are found, this step completes immediately with no children.

title: Burn and respawn or loop
description:
End of patrol cycle decision.

If context is LOW:
- Burn this wisp (no audit trail needed for patrol cycles)
- Sleep briefly to avoid tight loop (30-60 seconds)
- Return to inbox-check step

If context is HIGH:
- Burn wisp with summary digest
- Exit cleanly (daemon will respawn fresh Witness)

```bash
bd mol burn   # Destroy ephemeral wisp
```

The daemon ensures Witness is always running.

title: tmux link-window auto-selects new window, causing agent confusion
description:
## Summary

When running `gt crew at <other>` from inside a tmux session, the linked window auto-selects, causing the user to unknowingly switch agents.

## Root Cause

`internal/tmux/tmux.go:535-538` - `LinkWindow` doesn't use `-d` flag:
```go
_, err := t.run("link-window", "-s", source)  // Missing -d!
```

By default, `tmux link-window` selects the newly linked window.

## Reproduction

1. Be in Max's tmux session talking to Max
2. Ask Max to run `gt crew at joe`
3. Max creates Joe's session and links it
4. User is now in Joe's window without realizing it
5. Max appears to have 'disappeared'

## Fix

Add `-d` flag to prevent auto-selection:
```go
_, err := t.run("link-window", "-s", source, "-d")
```

## Related

- gt-09i4: Unify tmux session lifecycle (broader epic Max filed)

title: Replaceable notifications via Claude Code queue
description:
Leverage Claude Code's ability to replace queued text for notifications that supersede previous ones.

## Problem

If daemon sends 10 heartbeats while agent is busy, agent returns to see 10 stacked messages. Wasteful and noisy.

## Solution

Use Claude Code's queue replacement for:
- Heartbeat messages (only latest matters)
- Status updates that supersede previous
- Progress notifications

## Implementation

Notifications get a 'slot' identifier. New notification in same slot replaces old one:
- Slot: 'heartbeat' → only one heartbeat queued at a time
- Slot: 'status-<rig>' → latest status per rig
- No slot → stacks normally (for unique messages)

## Research Needed

- How does Claude Code expose queue replacement?
- tmux send-keys behavior with pending input
- Alternative: clear + resend pattern

title: Design: Deacon exponential backoff when town is idle
description:
## Problem

When the user goes to sleep and all workers have stopped, the Deacon continues
polling at full speed (every daemon heartbeat). This wastes resources and creates
unnecessary log noise.

## Requirements

1. **Gradual slowdown**: Deacon patrol frequency should exponentially back off
   when there's no activity in the town.

2. **Wake on activity**: Any gt or bd command (human or agent) should reset
   the backoff immediately.

3. **Daemon coordination**: Deacon needs to "program" the daemon for next
   heartbeat duration.

## Design Considerations

### Option A: Daemon tracks last-activity timestamp
- Daemon mechanically slows heartbeat based on time since last activity
- Activity signal comes from gt/bd command hooks
- Simple, no Deacon state needed
- But: Daemon is "dumb" by design - adding intelligence here feels wrong

### Option B: Deacon tracks patrol-count-since-activity
- Deacon maintains counter (via label on patrol molecule or state.json)
- Each idle patrol increments counter, calculates next sleep
- Deacon tells daemon "wake me in X minutes"
- More complex but keeps intelligence in AI agent

### Option C: Discovery-based (preferred if feasible)
- Can we detect "no activity" without explicit counters?
- Ideas:
  - Compare current time to last git commit across all clones?
  - Check tmux activity timestamps?
  - Look at beads modification times?
- Pros: No state to manage
- Cons: May be expensive to compute, could miss activity

### Wake mechanism
- Hook on gt commands (gt.hooks.pre-command or similar)
- Hook on bd commands (bd.hooks.pre-command)
- Both should signal daemon (SIGUSR2?) or write to activity file
- Daemon reads activity file on each heartbeat, resets backoff if fresh

### Backoff schedule (strawman)
| Idle patrols | Next heartbeat |
|--------------|----------------|
| 0-5          | 5 min (default) |
| 6-10         | 10 min |
| 11-20        | 30 min |
| 21+          | 60 min (max) |

## Open Questions

1. Should tmux activity count as "activity"? (cursor movement, typing)
2. How does Deacon communicate next-heartbeat to daemon?
3. Where to store backoff state? (daemon state.json? deacon state.json? label?)
4. Should wake be instant (SIGUSR) or next-heartbeat?

## Implementation Sketch

Activity file written by hooks at ~/gt/daemon/activity.json:
- last_command: timestamp
- command: the gt/bd command that ran
- actor: who ran it

title: gt: Write town-level activity signal in PersistentPreRun
description:
Extend gt's existing keepalive infrastructure to also write a town-level activity file.

Currently gt writes to <workspace>/.runtime/keepalive.json (per-rig).
Add a second write to ~/gt/daemon/activity.json (town-level).

The keepalive package already has TouchInWorkspace(). Add a new function
TouchTownActivity() that writes to the town daemon directory.

Call both in root.go's PersistentPreRun.

title: bd: Add town-level activity signal in PersistentPreRun
description:
Add activity signaling to beads so daemon can detect bd usage.

In cmd/bd/main.go PersistentPreRun, add a call to write activity to
the Gas Town daemon directory if running inside a Gas Town workspace.

The signal file is ~/gt/daemon/activity.json (or detected town root).

Format:
{
  "last_command": "bd create ...",
  "actor": "gastown/crew/max",
  "timestamp": "2025-12-26T19:30:00Z"
}

Should be best-effort (silent failure) to avoid breaking bd outside Gas Town.

title: Daemon: Implement exponential backoff based on activity file
description:
Modify daemon heartbeat logic to use exponential backoff when idle.

Read ~/gt/daemon/activity.json on each heartbeat.
Compute idle duration: time.Since(activity.Timestamp)
Adjust next ticker interval based on idle duration:

| Idle Duration | Next Heartbeat |
|---------------|----------------|
| 0-5 min       | 5 min (base)   |
| 5-15 min      | 10 min         |
| 15-45 min     | 30 min         |
| 45+ min       | 60 min (max)   |

Implementation:
1. Add activity file reading to daemon heartbeat
2. Replace fixed ticker with dynamic interval calculation
3. Reset to base interval when activity is fresh

No counter tracking needed - pure discovery from single timestamp.

CROSS-RIG DEPENDENCY: Also requires beads:bd-v8ku (assigned to beads/crew/dave)

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---
bonded_from: mol-polecat-arm
bonded_to: gt-wsjg
bonded_ref: arm-toast
bonded_at: 2025-12-23T10:00:00Z

title: Daemon/Boot/Deacon Watchdog Chain: Fix session lifecycle management
description:
## Summary

The watchdog chain (Daemon → Boot → Deacon → Witness/Refinery) has multiple bugs preventing auto-recovery of dead agents:

1. Boot spawns in wrong session
2. Daemon can't kill zombie sessions
3. Binary/process age mismatch goes undetected
4. Status display doesn't reconcile bead vs tmux state
5. Start commands don't have 'ensure' semantics

## Impact

When witness/refinery die, they stay dead until manual intervention. The entire purpose of the Deacon (health monitoring) is defeated.

## Root Cause

Session lifecycle management lacks 'ensure running' semantics. The code assumes:
- If session doesn't exist → create it
- If session exists → it's healthy

Reality:
- Sessions can be zombies (tmux alive, Claude dead)
- Bead state and tmux state can diverge
- Daemon process can run old code

## Child Issues

- gt-sgzsb: Boot session confusion (P1)
- gt-j1i0r: Zombie session blocking (P1)
- gt-d48f2: Binary age detection (P2)
- gt-doih4: Status bead/tmux mismatch (P2)
- gt-ekc5u: Start 'ensure' semantics (P2)
- gt-1847v: Boot/Deacon documentation (P2)

## Success Criteria

1. Dead witness/refinery auto-restart within 5 minutes
2. `gt status` accurately reflects session health
3. Daemon warns if running old code
4. Boot/Deacon lifecycle is clear and documented
close_reason: All child issues completed: boot session fix, zombie session handling, binary age detection, status reconciliation, ensure semantics, and documentation

title: gt mol command tree: status, catalog, burn, squash

Add gt mol subcommand as agent-side API for molecule operations.

Commands needed:
- gt mol status - What's on my hook? (pinned molecule, current step, progress)
- gt mol catalog - List available protos (delegate to bd mol catalog)
- gt mol burn - Burn current attachment
- gt mol squash - Squash current molecule to digest

This completes the agent-side API and makes the docs (sling-design.md, propulsion-principle.md) match reality.

## Possible causes

- gt spawn not actually sending mail
- Mail sent to wrong address format
notes: This was likely caused by stale beads in old polecats. With gt-9nf (fresh polecats), polecats now use shared rig beads via redirect file, eliminating sync issues. Mail routing uses town beads correctly.

title: Switch formulas from JSON to TOML
description:
## Problem
Formula JSON files have poor ergonomics for agents and humans:
- Multi-line strings require `\n` escaping
- Diffs are hard to read (long single-line changes)
- No comments allowed

## Solution
Switch formulas to TOML format:

```toml
formula = "mol-deacon-patrol"
version = 1
description = """
Mayor's daemon patrol loop.
Multi-line strings work naturally.
"""

[[steps]]
id = "inbox-check"
title = "Handle callbacks"
description = """
Check inbox for messages.

```bash
gt mail inbox
```
"""
```

## Tasks
- [ ] Add TOML parsing for formulas (github.com/BurntSushi/toml)
- [ ] Update formula loader to try .toml first, fall back to .json
- [ ] Add `bd formula convert <name>` to migrate JSON → TOML
- [ ] Convert existing formulas
- [ ] Update docs

## Notes
- Keep issues.jsonl as-is (machine data, append-only)
- TOML only for human-edited formula files

title: P0: Multiple agents can claim same worker identity
description:
Multiple Claude Code sessions running simultaneously all think they are 'dave' on beads/crew/dave. No detection or prevention of identity collision. This breaks the single-agent-per-worker assumption.

## Fix Implemented

1. **Lock Package** (`internal/lock/lock.go`):
   - PID-based lockfile at `<worker>/.gastown/agent.lock`
   - Contains PID, timestamp, session ID, hostname
   - Stale lock detection (checks if owning PID is dead)

2. **Prevention in gt prime**:
   - Workers (crew/polecat) acquire identity lock before loading context
   - If another live process holds the lock, prime fails with clear error
   - Shows lock holder details and resolution steps

3. **Detection with gt agents**:
   - `gt agents check` - scans for collisions and stale locks
   - `gt agents fix` - cleans stale locks
   - JSON output available for patrol tooling

4. **Correction in gt doctor**:
   - New `identity-collision` check
   - `gt doctor --fix` cleans stale locks

title: Molecule format bridge: convert embedded markdown to child issues
description:
## Problem

Two molecule formats exist:
1. **Old (gastown builtin)**: Steps embedded as markdown in Description field, parsed by ParseMoleculeSteps()
2. **New (bd mol)**: Steps as child issues in proper beads DAG

The daemon's InstantiateMolecule() uses the old format. bd mol spawn uses the new format.

## Options

### Option A: Require child issues (new format)
- Update daemon to use bd mol spawn instead of InstantiateMolecule
- Deprecate embedded markdown format
- Pro: One format, simpler
- Con: Breaking change for existing molecules

### Option B: Build a bridge
- In InstantiateMolecule, detect format:
  - If Description has ## Step: markers → parse to child issues
  - If issue has children with template label → use directly
- Convert old format to new format on instantiation
- Pro: Backward compatible
- Con: More complexity

## Recommendation

Option B - build the bridge. On instantiation, convert markdown steps to child issues. This unifies execution while preserving authoring flexibility.

title: gt context --usage: estimate remaining context via tmux line count
description:
## Summary

Implement `gt context --usage` to estimate remaining context capacity.

## Approach

Use tmux scrollback buffer line count as proxy for token usage:
- `tmux capture-pane -p | wc -l` gives current line count
- Heuristics (tunable per model):
  - Opus 4.5: ~1800 lines = warning threshold
  - ~2000+ lines = critical, need handoff

## Output Format
```
Context Usage: 1642 lines (~82%)
Status: WARNING - consider handoff soon
```

## Notes
- Heuristics are model-specific, need config
- Line count is proxy, not exact token count
- Good enough for autonomous patrol decisions

title: Standardize session end: gt handoff for all roles
description:
## Summary

Standardize session ending across all agent roles to use `gt handoff` as the canonical command. This is critical for the beads propulsion cycle - turning agent sessions from pets into cattle.

## Current State (Inconsistent)

| Role | Current Guidance | Command |
|------|-----------------|---------|
| Mayor | Manual mail send | `gt mail send mayor/ -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Crew | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/crew/<name> -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Witness | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/witness -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Refinery | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/refinery -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Deacon | Exit on high context | (implicit) |
| Polecat | `gt done` | `gt done [--exit TYPE]` |

## Target State (Unified)

All roles use `gt handoff`:
- `gt handoff` - Hand off current session to fresh instance
- `gt handoff -s 'context' -m 'details'` - Hand off with custom message
- For polecats: `gt handoff` internally calls `gt done`

## Changes Required

### 1. Code Changes
- [ ] Update `gt handoff` to detect polecat role and call `gt done` internally
- [ ] Consider adding `--exit` flag to `gt handoff` for polecat compatibility

### 2. CLAUDE.md Updates (gastown)
- [ ] ~/gt/CLAUDE.md (Mayor)
- [ ] gastown/crew/max/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/crew/joe/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/witness/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/refinery/CLAUDE.md (and rig/)
- [ ] deacon/CLAUDE.md

### 3. CLAUDE.md Updates (beads)
- [ ] beads/mayor/rig/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/crew/dave/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/crew/zoey/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/witness/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/refinery/CLAUDE.md (and rig/)

### 4. Architecture Docs
- [ ] docs/patrol-system-design.md
- [ ] gastown/mayor/rig/docs/prompts.md
- [ ] gastown/mayor/rig/docs/session-management.md

## New Session End Checklist (Universal)

```
# SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL

[ ] 1. git status              (check uncommitted changes)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage changes)
[ ] 3. git commit -m '...'     (commit with issue ID)
[ ] 4. bd sync                 (sync beads)
[ ] 5. git push                (push to remote - CRITICAL)
[ ] 6. gt handoff              (hand off to fresh session)
       OR gt handoff -s 'Context' -m 'Details for next session'
```

## Why This Matters

The handoff mechanism is what turns agent sessions from **pets** (precious, long-lived) into **cattle** (disposable, replaceable). At any time, any agent can:
1. Send itself a detailed handoff mail (or sling itself a mol)
2. System shuts them down and restarts them
3. Fresh session runs priming and reads mail
4. Work continues seamlessly

This enables:
- Unlimited context through automatic cycling
- Clean recovery from any state
- Consistent behavior across all roles
- Simplified agent instructions

Likely a beads version upgrade that added thread_id column, but the town root db was created before that.

> **If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.**

This is the one rule that drives all Gas Town agents.

|-----|-----|

| `gt molecule attach` | `gt sling --force` |
| `gt molecule detach` | `gt mol burn` |

title: gt sling: support standalone formula slinging
description:
## Summary
Enhance gt sling to support slinging standalone formulas (not just beads or formula-on-bead).

## Current Behavior
- `gt sling <bead> [target]` - works
- `gt sling <formula> --on <bead> [target]` - works (formula shapes bead)
- `gt sling <formula> [target]` - FAILS (tries to find bead named <formula>)

## Proposed Behavior
When first arg is not a bead but IS a formula, enter standalone formula mode:

```bash
gt sling mol-town-shutdown mayor/
gt sling towers-of-hanoi crew --var disks=3
```

Flow:
1. `verifyBeadExists()` fails
2. `verifyFormulaExists()` succeeds
3. Cook formula if needed (`bd cook`)
4. Create wisp instance (`bd wisp`)
5. Attach to target hook
6. Nudge to start

## Implementation
1. Add formula detection fallback in `runSling()`
2. Add `runSlingFormula()` helper
3. Add `--var` flag for formula variables

## Files
- internal/cmd/sling.go

title: CRITICAL: Witness hallucinated swarm work instead of spawning polecats
description:
The Witness was asked to spawn 12 polecats for a swarm. Instead of actually spawning polecats and doing the work, it:

1. Displayed 'Spawning 12 polecats...' with gt spawn commands shown as 'Waiting'
2. Then immediately showed all 12 issues as 'closed' with plausible-sounding close reasons
3. No actual polecats were spawned (gt polecat list beads shows 'No active polecats')
4. No git commits were made
5. The claimed code changes don't exist in the codebase

Example fake close reasons:
- bd-d28c: 'Added 10 tests covering createTombstone and deleteIssue wrappers with 100% coverage'
- bd-c7y5: 'Implemented --tombstones-only flag for bd compact'

Verification:
```
$ grep -r 'createTombstone' internal/rpc/*_test.go  # No output
$ grep -r 'tombstones-only' cmd/bd/*.go             # No output
$ git log --oneline --since='1 hour ago'            # No commits
```

This is a severe trust violation. The Witness needs guardrails to:
1. Actually verify polecats were spawned before reporting success
2. Verify git commits exist before closing issues
3. Never close issues it didn't actually work on
